Catalogue number: 61
Object name: STEEL CHAIN.
Maker/Donor: Made by Ramsden. Lent by the Royal Society.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This chain was first used by General Roy in measuring the Hounslow Heath base in 1784. Although it was only used as a preliminary to more precise measurements with both fir and glass rods, General Roy was so impressed by its accuracy that, in measuring the base of verification on Romney Marsh in 1787, he used the chain only, and discarded the wooden and glass rods. The chain has 100 links, each 1 ft. long. The joints at every 10 ft. are at right angles to the remainder, which permits the chain to be folded so as to fit into a box about 14 in. by 8 in. by 8 in. for transport. Brass plates are attached at the joints to indicate 10 ft. lengths along the chain. In the rough measurement of the Hounslow Heath base, the chain appears to have been simply stretched along the ground, but in the measurement at Romney Marsh it was supported on deal coffers, 20 ft. long, resting on carefully aligned posts driven into the ground every 20 ft. along the base. Thus supported, the chain was stretched by a weight of 28 lb., the temperature being measured by thermometers laid in the coffers near the chain.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1900–156.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 62
Object name: BONING TELESCOPE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by the Royal Society.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: In measuring the Hounslow Heath base in 1784, General Roy divided the base into sections of 200 yd. and erected tripods of fixed height for supporting the measuring rods at each division point; these sections were subdivided into segments of 20 ft., corresponding to the lengths of the deal measuring rods used, and intermediate tripods set up at the subdivision points with their platforms adjusted so as to be in the line connecting the platforms of the tripods at each end of the section. The telescope here exhibited was used to sight between the two terminal tripods upon boning rods set up at the subdivision points. The movable vanes of these rods being adjusted until their index lines lay on the axis of sight of the telescope, the height of the intermediate tripods was thus ascertained. The telescope has a rack-focussing objective lens of 1·2 in. aperture and 13 in. focal length, and a fixed eyepiece of the Huygens type, with a fixed cross-wire diaphragm between the two lenses. The magnifying power of the eyepiece is small, and the telescope can be focussed down to a few feet. It has square brass collars shrunk on to its tube near each end to support it upon the platform of the tripod. (See Phil. Trans. Roy. Soc., 1785.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1900–157.

Maker/Donor: Presented by the Ordnance Survey.
Object entry information: Plate I, Fig. 2, p. 15. This apparatus was designed by Major-General Colby, R.E., in order to eliminate the errors in measuring bases caused by the impossibility of estimating accurately the temperature of the measuring bars at the time of observation. The device of Colby consists in so connecting two bars, one of brass and the other of iron, that two reference marks on metal tongues attached to them remain at an invariable distance apart whatever the temperature. Two bases have been measured with this apparatus, one in the North of Ireland in 1827-28, and the other on Salisbury Plain in 1849. Ten bases have been measured with similar apparatus in India. In this apparatus two bars, one of brass and the other of iron, each 10 ft. 1.5 in. long, 0.3 in. broad and 1.5 in. deep at a certain temperature, are placed in a deal box, and firmly connected at their centres by two small transverse steel cylinders, nearly in contact. Near each extremity of the double-bar is a metal tongue, 6.2 in. long, which is connected to each bar by pivots so as to permit expansion, but no other movement of the bars. On a silver plug at the extremity of each tongue is engraved a dot—the compensation point. Since the lengths of the tongue between the dot and either bar is proportional to the coefficient of expansion of that bar, no joint expansion of the bars due to temperature changes will affect the position of the dot. Consequently the dots are 10 ft. apart at all temperatures. The compound bar is placed in a deal box, and is kept from moving lengthwise by a brass stay fixed firmly to the bottom of the box at the centre and projecting upwards between the two small steel cylinders connecting the bars. A long steel cross-wise level is fixed to the top of the brass bar and read through a glass covered opening in the top of the box. The tongues carrying the compensation points project beyond the box, but are carefully protected. In measuring, the boxes are supported at their quarter and three-quarter points on stands which permit lateral and longitudinal motion. The dots on two adjacent bars are brought to the precise distance of 6 in. apart by means of a compensation microscope. This latter is formed by uniting two microscopes by parallel bars of iron and brass in such a manner that the distance between their outer foci remains exactly 6 in., whatever the temperature. The whole apparatus consists of six bars and seven microscopes, of which two bars and three microscopes are exhibited. The rate of measurement with this apparatus was six bars per hour on the Lough Foyle base. (See Ordnance Survey “Report on Measurement of Lough Foyle Base,” pp. 163, 164.)

Maker/Donor: Presented by the Survey of Egypt.
Object entry information: This apparatus for measuring geodetic bases is of the type first employed by Jäderin in Sweden in 1885, and was used in Egypt for determining second order bases from 1901 to 1907. In Jäderin’s system, the massive rigid base-bars hitherto employed were replaced by light metallic wires or tapes freely suspended under a constant tension. The saving in labour and time thus effected easily outweighs the slight loss in accuracy sustained. Independent measurements of each section of the base are made with two wires of different metallic structure, and the effect of temperature variations is thus calculated. The apparatus exhibited comprises two tripods and two pairs of wires, 25 and 50 metres long respectively, each pair consisting of one brass and one steel wire. The tripods are provided with steel observing pins mounted upon double ball and socket joints, which permit slight displacements of the pins when the tripods are fixed. The wires are nickel-plated, and are provided at each end with decimetre scales, graduated in millimetres. The centimetre divisions of these scales are numbered from 5 to 15, and the length of the wire between the “10” division at each end is the characteristic length. The wires terminate beyond the scales in loops, to which are attached the flexible cords carrying the straining weights. The tension may be applied by hand, and measured by a spring balance, or by attaching weights to the cords. The cord at each end passes over a pulley or trestle, which serves to take the end strain and to adjust the scale of the wire during the actual measurement into close proximity to the side of the observing pin. Observations of the positions of each pin with respect to the corresponding scale are simultaneously recorded. Several dual observations are made with each wire of a pair, the wire being slightly displaced before each observation. Previous to the actual measurement of any bay, the pins of the tripods marking the ends of that bay are carefully aligned and their heights determined by a transit theodolite and level. With this apparatus, various bases in Egypt were measured with probable errors between 1 in 200,000 and 1 in 1,000,000 at a speed of about 1,000 metres per day. The higher degree of accuracy was consistently attained when the 'constants' of the wires were known properly, and the observing parties had gained experience in correctly applying the tension to the wires. Recently the invention of 'invar' has obviated the employment of two wires in the Jäderin system, and with improved straining mechanism, it is now possible to measure bases with Jäderin 'invar' wires or tapes with an accuracy high enough for first order triangulation purposes. (See "Geodätische Längenmessung mit Stahlbänden und Metaldiäptern," E. Jäderin, Stockholm, 1885; also U.S. C. & G. S. Report, 1893, Part II, Appendix 5.)

Maker/Donor: Presented by the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey.
Object entry information: These three photographs illustrate a base-measuring apparatus constructed in July, 1891, and employed by the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey Department in measuring the Holton (Indiana) Base in 1891, the Salina (Kansas) Base in 1896, and the Versailles (Missouri) Base in 1897 in connection with the Transcontiaental (Primary) Triangulation of the 39th Parallel of Latitude. The apparatus consists of two precisely similar base-bars, known as the U.S. C. & G. S. Nos. 13 and 14 measuring bars. Each bar is of the contact-slide metallic-thermometer type, and is 5 m. long at a certain temperature. The actual measuring unit is a steel rod 8 mm. in diam., terminating at one end in an agate plane, and at the other in a contact-slide which itself ends in an agate knife-edge. The slide is connected to the rod by a spring, and has a mark engraved upon it corresponding to a mark engraved upon the rod, so that when these two knife-edge and plane terminal points are the correct distance apart. Two zinc tubes, 9.5 mm. in diam., are soldered one to each end of the steel rod, their other ends being free to expand or contract relatively to this rod. The relative expansion is measured by means of a vernier on each zinc tube moving over a scale fixed to the steel rod, and the compound rod thus formed enables the mean temperature to be determined. The compound measuring rod rests upon rollers in a rectangular wooden case, which itself rests upon tripods during the measurement and is provided at its rear end with a telescope for aligning the bar. When the forward bar has been aligned and adjusted as a whole on its trestles to within a small distance of the preceding bar, its measuring rod is slowly drawn backwards upon the rollers by a milled screw at its rear end, until the contact-slide touches the agate plane of the preceding bar and is forced gently over the steel rod until the two engraved lines coincide. During this motion, the wooden case remains stationary upon its trestles, and the only pressure upon the rear bar is that due to the spring of the contact-slide, which is quite powerless to disturb the bar. Each bar is provided with a mercurial thermometer for use when comparing it with the standard bar. The average rate of measurement with this apparatus on the Holton Base was 155 m. per hr., with a probable error of about 1 in 1,500,000. (See Special Publication No. 4, U. S. C. & G. S. Department).

Object entry information: These three photographs illustrate a bimetallic contact-slide apparatus designed by W. Eimbeck, and used by the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey Department in measuring the Salt Lake Base (Utah) in 1896 in connection with the Transcontinental Triangulation of the 39th Parallel of Latitude. It consists of two similar bars, each 5 m. long, known as U. S. C. & G. S. Nos. 15 and 16 duplex bars. The rate of measuring with this apparatus in Utah was about 250 m. per hr., with a probable error of 1 in 5,000,000. Each bar consists of two measuring units of precisely similar construction, one of steel and one of brass, each 5 m. long, and weighs complete 118 lb. The measuring units are made of tubing of $\frac{3}{4}$ in. diam., each having a thickness of wall corresponding to the conductivity and specific heat of the material of which it is made, so that under changing conditions each tube shall keep the same temperature as the other one. The two measuring tubes are carried on rollers in a brass protecting casing, which turns on its longitudinal axis in an outer brass protecting casing which remains stationary. The inner casing is rotated 180° from time to time to equalize temperature distribution. Object name: PHOTOGRAPHS OF EIMBECK'S DUPLEX BASE APPARATUS.
Maker/Donor: Presented by the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey. Designed by W. Eimbeck.
Date of creation: Used in measuring the Salt Lake Base (Utah) in 1896.
Object entry information: These three photographs illustrate a bimetallic contact-slide apparatus designed by W. Eimbeck, and used by the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey Department in measuring the Salt Lake Base (Utah) in 1896 in connection with the Transcontinental Triangulation of the 39th Parallel of Latitude. It consists of two similar bars, each 5 m. long, known as U. S. C. & G. S. Nos. 15 and 16 duplex bars. The rate of measuring with this apparatus in Utah was about 250 m. per hr., with a probable error of 1 in 5,000,000. Each bar consists of two measuring units of precisely similar construction, one of steel and one of brass, each 5 m. long, and weighs complete 118 lb. The measuring units are made of tubing of $\frac{3}{4}$ in. diam., each having a thickness of wall corresponding to the conductivity and specific heat of the material of which it is made, so that under changing conditions each tube shall keep the same temperature as the other one. The two measuring tubes are carried on rollers in a brass protecting casing, which turns on its longitudinal axis in an outer brass protecting casing which remains stationary. The inner casing is rotated 180° from time to time to equalize temperature distribution. The two measuring units are entirely disconnected, and contact is always made brass to brass and steel to steel; hence two independent measurements of the base are obtained, their difference determining the average temperature during the measuring, so that each can be corrected accordingly. To overcome the difficulty due to one rod gradually gaining on the other, owing to the different coefficients of expansion of brass and steel, each measuring unit is provided with vernier scales, and the brass bar is occasionally readjusted by an amount thus measured and allowed for in the final calculations. Telescopes are affixed to each base-bar for aligning, whilst the tripods are provided with special heads for quick and slow adjustment in the horizontal and vertical planes. The contact slide is similar to the one described in connection with the Secondary Base-Apparatus. (See Appendix II, Report for 1897, and Special Publication, No. 4. U.S. C. & G. S. Department.)

The higher degree of accuracy was consistently attained when the 'constants' of the wires were known properly, and the observing parties had gained experience in correctly applying the tension to the wires. Recently the invention of 'invar' has obviated the employment of two wires in the Jäderin system, and with improved straining mechanism, it is now possible to measure bases with Jäderin 'invar' wires or tapes with an accuracy high enough for first order triangulation purposes. (See "Geodätische Längenmessung mit Stahlbänden und Metaldiäptern," E. Jäderin, Stockholm, 1885; also U.S. C. & G. S. Report, 1893, Part II, Appendix 5.)

Catalogue number: 66.
Object name: PHOTOGRAPHS OF SECONDARY (STEEL) BASE-APPARATUS.
Maker/Donor: Presented by the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey.
Date of creation: Used 1891 (Holton Base), 1896 (Salina Base), 1897 (Versailles Base).
Object entry information: These three photographs illustrate a base-measuring apparatus constructed in July, 1891, and employed by the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey Department in measuring the Holton (Indiana) Base in 1891, the Salina (Kansas) Base in 1896, and the Versailles (Missouri) Base in 1897 in connection with the Transcontiaental (Primary) Triangulation of the 39th Parallel of Latitude. The apparatus consists of two precisely similar base-bars, known as the U.S. C. & G. S. Nos. 13 and 14 measuring bars. Each bar is of the contact-slide metallic-thermometer type, and is 5 m. long at a certain temperature. The actual measuring unit is a steel rod 8 mm. in diam., terminating at one end in an agate plane, and at the other in a contact-slide which itself ends in an agate knife-edge. The slide is connected to the rod by a spring, and has a mark engraved upon it corresponding to a mark engraved upon the rod, so that when these two knife-edge and plane terminal points are the correct distance apart. Two zinc tubes, 9.5 mm. in diam., are soldered one to each end of the steel rod, their other ends being free to expand or contract relatively to this rod. The relative expansion is measured by means of a vernier on each zinc tube moving over a scale fixed to the steel rod, and the compound rod thus formed enables the mean temperature to be determined. The compound measuring rod rests upon rollers in a rectangular wooden case, which itself rests upon tripods during the measurement and is provided at its rear end with a telescope for aligning the bar. When the forward bar has been aligned and adjusted as a whole on its trestles to within a small distance of the preceding bar, its measuring rod is slowly drawn backwards upon the rollers by a milled screw at its rear end, until the contact-slide touches the agate plane of the preceding bar and is forced gently over the steel rod until the two engraved lines coincide. During this motion, the wooden case remains stationary upon its trestles, and the only pressure upon the rear bar is that due to the spring of the contact-slide, which is quite powerless to disturb the bar. Each bar is provided with a mercurial thermometer for use when comparing it with the standard bar. The average rate of measurement with this apparatus on the Holton Base was 155 m. per hr., with a probable error of about 1 in 1,500,000. (See Special Publication No. 4, U. S. C. & G. S. Department).
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–388.

Object entry information: These three photographs illustrate a bimetallic contact-slide apparatus designed by W. Eimbeck, and used by the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey Department in measuring the Salt Lake Base (Utah) in 1896 in connection with the Transcontinental Triangulation of the 39th Parallel of Latitude. It consists of two similar bars, each 5 m. long, known as U. S. C. & G. S. Nos. 15 and 16 duplex bars. The rate of measuring with this apparatus in Utah was about 250 m. per hr., with a probable error of 1 in 5,000,000. Each bar consists of two measuring units of precisely similar construction, one of steel and one of brass, each 5 m. long, and weighs complete 118 lb. The measuring units are made of tubing of $\frac{3}{4}$ in. diam., each having a thickness of wall corresponding to the conductivity and specific heat of the material of which it is made, so that under changing conditions each tube shall keep the same temperature as the other one. The two measuring tubes are carried on rollers in a brass protecting casing, which turns on its longitudinal axis in an outer brass protecting casing which remains stationary. The inner casing is rotated 180° from time to time to equalize temperature distribution. The two measuring units are entirely disconnected, and contact is always made brass to brass and steel to steel; hence two independent measurements of the base are obtained, their difference

Maker/Donor: Presented by the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey.
Object entry information: These three photographs illustrate a form of tape-stretching apparatus which is an improvement upon the one used by the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey in measuring the Stanton Base, Texas, in 1908–09. It consists of an iron tube 1·35 m. long and 32 mm. diam., along which is movable a short collar fitted with a frame to carry the spring balance, and a weight to counterpoise it. The position of the sliding collar is easily adjusted by means of a friction lever device. The bottom of the tube ends in a round conical point, which permits it to rotate about its axis, thus allowing the tension to put the balance into alignment with the tape. A short iron projection near the bottom of the tube is used for forcing the latter into the ground by means of the foot. The total weight of the stretcher is 11 1/4 lb. The rear end of the tape is attached by a strap to a simple wooden staff fitted with a metal shoe, as shown in the left-hand photograph. The tension normally applied by this means to an "invar" tape for primary base-measure-ment is, in the United States, 15 kg. (See U.S. C. & G. S. Report, 1910, Appendix 4.)

Catalogue number: 69.
Object name: "INVAR" MEASURING TAPE.
Maker/Donor: Made by J. H. Agar Bough.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The name "invar" has been given to a nickel-steel alloy containing from 35 per cent, to 36 per cent. nickel, discovered by Dr. C. E. Guillaume in 1896, owing to its low coefficient of expansion for temperature, which is not greater than 1·0 x 10⁻⁶ per °C. The application of this alloy to geodesy arises from the difficulty of ascertaining the exact mean temperature of a metal measuring unit, and consequently the precise length of the unit at the time of measurement. As the effect of an error of this type is directly proportional to the expansibility of the metal, the importance of a low coefficient of expansion is obvious. The use of "invar" wires or tapes, suspended under a constant tension of about 10 kg., according to Jäderin’s method, is now almost universal in measuring bases for triangulation of the first or second order. The tape exhibited is just over 100 ft. long, and has scales divided to read two-hundredths of a foot at each end. According to the National Physical Laboratory certificate of examination, the length between its zero marks at each end is 100·001 ft. at 58·5° F., under a tension of 10 kg., with an accuracy of 1 in 100,000. The width of the tape is 5 mm. and its thickness 0·5 mm. It is wound upon an aluminium drum of 16 in. diam., which can rotate upon its pivot as the reel is unwound. (See "Les nouveaux appareils pour la mesure rapide des bases géodésiques." Guillaume et Benoit. Paris, 1916.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1912-245.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 70.
Object name: PHOTOGRAPHS OF BASE MEASUREMENT WITH "INVAR" WIRES.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Major G. G. Waterhouse, R.E.
Date of creation: Measurement in 1912.
Object entry information: These four photographs of the measurement of the Narguta base in 1912, during the survey of Northern Nigeria, illustrate the general process of using flexible wires, suspended according to Jäderin’s method, and the superiority of such apparatus over rigid rods in difficult country. In this case a river, the Delimi, having fairly steep banks, was successfully negotiated without any special preparation of the ground. Two of the photographs illustrate the approach to the Delimi and its crossing, a third shows the crossing of a deep irrigation channel, and the fourth shows the completion of a section of the base, the terminal point being marked by a ground pin.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-655.

Maker/Donor: Made by W. Heath. Presented by the Admiralty.
Object entry information: This instrument was designed by Capt. G. H. Blakey, R.N. for determining the distance of a ship on the assumption that the height of its mast is known, and that the mast is perpendicular to the direction of the ship from the observer. It is merely a telescopic sighting tube having a pin-hole aperture and pairs of parallel wires set at known intervals apart near the object end of the tube. The distance of these wires from the aperture is given by the graduated scales on the telescopic tube. In using the instrument, the mast of the distant ship is viewed and the sighting tube telescoped until the mast lies exactly between a pair of wires. On reading the length of the tube, i.e. from aperture to wires, the range of the mast will be in the same ratio to this length as the mast is to the interval between the wires. As these last two lengths are known, the range is readily calculated, or can be obtained directly from the tables supplied with the instrument. Two mutually perpendicular pairs of parallel wires are fitted in the instrument exhibited, at intervals of one tenth and one twentieth of a foot respectively. A table corresponding to the former interval for lengths of masts between 100 and 200 ft., and all possible lengths of sighting tube is printed on the tube and gives the corresponding ranges in yards. For the smaller interval, these ranges are of course to be doubled. Measurements of distance by this apparatus can only be very approximate owing to the absence of magnification, uncertainty as regards the length of the mast and its inclination to the line of sight, etc.

Object name: N/A (Continuation describing Rangefinder Principles)
Maker/Donor: G. Forbes (mentioned for the specific type referenced)
Date of creation: 1901
Object entry information: was effected by the lateral movement of a deflecting prism interposed between the central telescope and one of the fixed end reflectors. The same firm have since introduced many improvements in their original type of rangefinder, whilst preserving the deflecting prism as an essential feature. A different principle is involved in the stereoscopic type of rangefinder, in which the capacity of the human eyes to "converge" upon a distant object is utilized to measure its distance. In such an instrument the muscular effort of the eyes during convergence is a delicate measure of the required range, and the optical systems employed merely enhance the range within which this effort can be accurately distinguished. The foundations of stereoscopic measurement were laid by Wheatstone in 1832 and by Helmholtz in 1855-58, but the first rangefinder utilizing this principle was conceived by De Grousilliers in 1893 and developed by Messrs. Zeiss in the subsequent years. Stereoscopic rangefinders, whilst very accurate and rapidly manipulated in the hands of a skilled observer, necessitate a power of stereoscopic perception not possessed by everybody. A rangefinder of this type, devised by G. Forbes in 1901 for infantry use, is exhibited in the Collection (No. 80).

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 72
Object name: STUART’S DISTANCE METER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by T. H. Court, Esq.
Date of creation: 1895
Object entry information: Assuming that the length of a distant ship’s mast is known, its range can be found by this instrument, which was designed in 1895 for use at sea. Two images of the mast are seen in the field of the telescope, one formed by light rays traversing a fixed prism of constant angle, and the other by rays traversing a movable prism of varying angle. These images are made to approach each other until the lower limit of one is level with the upper limit of the other by sliding the movable prism, when the position of an index attached to this permits the range to be read. The movable prism consists of a thin piece of glass, ground concave on both faces, and is attached to a slide worked by a tangent screw. It thus forms a prism of varying angle in front of one half of the telescope, the other half being occupied by the fixed constant angle prism. Ranges up to 3 miles can be read to the nearest tenth of a mile. (See British Patent Specification, No. 23834, 1895.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915-399

Object name: N/A (Continuation describing Rangefinder Principles)
Maker/Donor: G. Forbes (mentioned for the specific type referenced)
Date of creation: 1901
Object entry information: was effected by the lateral movement of a deflecting prism interposed between the central telescope and one of the fixed end reflectors. The same firm have since introduced many improvements in their original type of rangefinder, whilst preserving the deflecting prism as an essential feature. A different principle is involved in the stereoscopic type of rangefinder, in which the capacity of the human eyes to "converge" upon a distant object is utilized to measure its distance. In such an instrument the muscular effort of the eyes during convergence is a delicate measure of the required range, and the optical systems employed merely enhance the range within which this effort can be accurately distinguished. The foundations of stereoscopic measurement were laid by Wheatstone in 1832 and by Helmholtz in 1855-58, but the first rangefinder utilizing this principle was conceived by De Grousilliers in 1893 and developed by Messrs. Zeiss in the subsequent years. Stereoscopic rangefinders, whilst very accurate and rapidly manipulated in the hands of a skilled observer, necessitate a power of stereoscopic perception not possessed by everybody. A rangefinder of this type, devised by G. Forbes in 1901 for infantry use, is exhibited in the Collection (No. 80).
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 71
Object name: STADIOMETER
Maker/Donor: Made by W. Heath. Presented by the Admiralty.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This instrument was designed by Capt. G. H. Blakey, R.N. for determining the distance of a ship on the assumption that the height of its mast is known, and that the mast is perpendicular to the direction of the ship from the observer. It is merely a telescopic sighting tube having a pin-hole aperture and pairs of parallel wires set at known intervals apart near the object end of the tube. The distance of these wires from the aperture is given by the graduated scales on the telescopic tube. In using the instrument, the mast of the distant ship is viewed and the sighting tube telescoped until the mast lies exactly between a pair of wires. On reading the length of the tube, i.e. from aperture to wires, the range of the mast will be in the same ratio to this length as the mast is to the interval between the wires. As these last two lengths are known, the range is readily calculated, or can be obtained directly from the tables supplied with the instrument. Two mutually perpendicular pairs of parallel wires are fitted in the instrument exhibited, at intervals of one tenth and one twentieth of a foot respectively. A table corresponding to the former interval for lengths of masts between 100 and 200 ft., and all possible lengths of sighting tube is printed on the tube and gives the corresponding ranges in yards. For the smaller interval, these ranges are of course to be doubled. Measurements of distance by this apparatus can only be very approximate owing to the absence of magnification, uncertainty as regards the length of the mast and its inclination to the line of sight, etc.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876-1209

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 72
Object name: STUART’S DISTANCE METER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by T. H. Court, Esq.
Date of creation: 1895
Object entry information: Assuming that the length of a distant ship’s mast is known, its range can be found by this instrument, which was designed in 1895 for use at sea. Two images of the mast are seen in the field of the telescope, one formed by light rays traversing a fixed prism of constant angle, and the other by rays traversing a movable prism of varying angle. These images are made to approach each other until the lower limit of one is level with the upper limit of the other by sliding the movable prism, when the position of an index attached to this permits the range to be read. The movable prism consists of a thin piece of glass, ground concave on both faces, and is attached to a slide worked by a tangent screw. It thus forms a prism of varying angle in front of one half of the telescope, the other half being occupied by the fixed constant angle prism. Ranges up to 3 miles can be read to the nearest tenth of a mile. (See British Patent Specification, No. 23834, 1895.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1915-399
title: Marine distance meter
description: Stuart's Distance Meter for use at sea, 1895

Object entry information: This is a pocket rangefinder suitable for military reconnaissance. To determine ranges up to 3,000 m. two observations are made with it, one from each end of a 30 m. base, which is set off approximately at right angles to the direction of the object. The instrument consists of a short metal tube having a pin-hole sight at one end and a rectangular window in one side. Opposite this window within the tube are two small plane mirrors inclined at an angle of 45° to each other. Both mirrors can be rotated slightly. The observer views the object A whose range is required directly through the pin-hole sight, and rotates one mirror until he sees, after double reflection, the image of an object B whose direction is nearly perpendicular to A's. He measures off the base in the direction of B, and again views A directly. By rotating the second mirror he once more gets a doubly reflected image of B. This latter rotation is effected by turning a milled drum in the eye end of the instrument, and the position of this drum when B is again sighted is a measure of the range of A. The drum is calibrated to give this range immediately. A thin cord of the base length is supplied with the instrument. (See “Fieldwork and Instruments,” 1900, pp. 236-239, by A. T. Walmisley.)

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 74.
Object name: THREE-PRISM TELEMETER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by T. H. Court, Esq.
Date of creation: Inv. 1911-151.
Object entry information: This instrument is used to measure ranges in the ordinary manner, by solving a very acute right-angled triangle. The angle subtended at the distant point is constant, whilst the base is variable, and is measured by pacing. Three reflecting right-angled prisms are mounted by hinged joints near the objective of a small telescope, so that any one of the three can be set to reflect rays axially along the telescope from directions at 90°, 88° 51′ 15″ and 74° 53′ 15″ respectively. The first prism is used to set off the base at right angles to the direction of the distant object. The observer paces in the line of the base until, using one of the other two prisms, he again sees the object by reflection. For both observations the telescope is directed to view another distant point at right angles to the target, i.e., in the direction of the base. The number of paces taken between the two observations, multiplied by a constant depending upon the length of pace and the reflecting angle of the second prism used, gives the required range. The constant is determined experimentally.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911-151.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 75.
Object name: GAUTIER’S POCKET TELEMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Tavernier-Gravet, Paris.
Date of creation: about 1865.
Object entry information: This rangefinder was designed by Capt. Gautier, a French artillery officer, about 1865, and has been extensively used in the French army. Its main feature is a thin prism mounted in a ring at the object end of the sighting tube. By rotating the ring the deviation of rays in the plane of the distant object and the horizontal through the instrument can be varied continuously, and the ring calibrated correspondingly. The sighting tube is about 5 in. long by 1·5 in. diam. and has a protecting tube which can be fitted underneath to serve as a hand-grip when observations are being made. The sighting tube, in addition to the movable ring containing the prism, has a pair of plane mirrors having their faces inclined to each other at an angle of about 45°, and so inclined to the optical axis that rays incident through a window in the side of the tube in a direction nearly perpendicular to the axis, are doubly reflected at the mirrors into the line of the axis, and pass through a small telescope at the eye end of the tube. In the instrument shown, two such telescopes of different powers are fixed side by side. One of the mirrors can be slightly rotated so as to vary the angle of deviation of the reflected rays. In using the instrument, the observer sets the range scale on the movable ring at “infinity” and the index of the movable mirror at the centre. He views the distant object by double reflection at the mirrors and looks directly through the tube and prism for a convenient aiming mark. If such a mark is not quite co-incident with the image of the distant object, he rotates the mirror until coincidence occurs. Then the object and the aiming mark are in directions nearly perpendicular to each other. Next he paces out a convenient distance in the direction of the aiming mark and takes a second observation similar to the first, but this time effects the coincidence by means of the movable prism. He reads off the scale calibrated on that ring when coincidence is effected and multiplies the distance of his base. The result is the range of the distant object. The movable ring is really calibrated to record the reciprocal of the angle of deviation caused by the prism, which is the same as the reciprocal of the angle subtended.
Object/Inventory number: N/A.

The sighting tube, in addition to the movable ring containing the prism, has a pair of plane mirrors having their faces inclined to each other at an angle of about 45°, and so inclined to the optical axis that rays incident through a window in the side of the tube in a direction nearly perpendicular to the axis, are doubly reflected at the mirrors into the line of the axis, and pass through a small telescope at the eye end of the tube. In the instrument shown, two such telescopes of different powers are fixed side by side. One of the mirrors can be slightly rotated so as to vary the angle of deviation of the reflected rays. In using the instrument, the observer sets the range scale on the movable ring at “infinity” and the index of the movable mirror at the centre. He views the distant object by double reflection at the mirrors and looks directly through the tube and prism for a convenient aiming mark. If such a mark is not quite co-incident with the image of the distant object, he rotates the mirror until coincidence occurs. Then the object and the aiming mark are in directions nearly perpendicular to each other. Next he paces out a convenient distance in the direction of the aiming mark and takes a second observation similar to the first, but this time effects the coincidence by means of the movable prism. He reads off the scale calibrated on that ring when coincidence is effected and multiplies the distance of his base. The result is the range of the distant object. The movable ring is really calibrated to record the reciprocal of the angle of deviation caused by the prism, which is the same as the reciprocal of the angle subtended. by the base at the object. As this base has been made nearly perpendicular to the direction of the object, the product of its length and the reciprocal of the angle gives the range. Thus any convenient base length can be used subject to the condition that it subtends an angle of not more than 3° at the distant object. (See “ Notice sur le Télémètre de Poche,” by A. Gautier, Paris.)

Maker/Donor: Made and lent by T. Cooke and Sons, Ltd., York.
Object entry information: This standard rangefinding set is used by infantry units. It comprises two optical sighting instruments, known as the “Right Angle” and “Reading” instruments, and two reels of cord, each 25 yd. long, for setting off the base. The observer at one end of the base uses the “Right Angle” instrument to make the base line perpendicular to the line joining his position to the distant object, after which the other observer uses his “Reading” instrument to measure the angle between the base line and the direction of the object from his position. The Right Angle instrument has two fixed vertical mirrors inclined to each other at an angle of 45°. The observer using this sees the target directly and the vane on the Reading instrument after double reflection at the two mirrors. He adjusts his position, keeping the base line fully extended, until the two images coincide. The Reading instrument differs only in that one of its mirrors can be rotated, and the rotation recorded upon a graduated drum, so that the images of the target (viewed directly) and the vane of the Right Angle instrument (viewed by double reflection on the two mirrors) can be made to coincide. The graduated drum is calibrated to record the range directly. (See “ Handbook of the Mekometer.”)

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 77.
Object name: ADIE TELEMETER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by the Admiralty. (Designed by P. Adie in 1860).
Date of creation: Designed in 1860.
Object entry information: This type of rangefinder was designed by P. Adie in 1860, and was extensively used by the Admiralty until superseded by the Barr and Stroud pattern. The example shown was used on H.M.S. “Triton” from 1885 to 1904 during the survey of the East Coast of England. The rangefinder consists of two systems of lenses and right-angled reflecting prisms mounted in a 3-ft. metal tube of square section. Each system forms a “broken” telescope, the objectives being at each end of the tube, along which the rays, originally perpendicular to it, are deflected by right-angled prisms to the centre, where they are again reflected at right angles into the common central eye-piece. In this manner two images of a distant object whose direction is nearly perpendicular to the axis of the tube are obtained, one through each system. These images will be separated laterally by an interval which diminishes continuously as the range increases, but does not become zero until the object is at an infinite distance. If the objective lens and two prisms of one system are separately mounted and can be rotated with respect to the other system, the two images may be made to coincide by such a rotation, and the angle of rotation necessary will vary inversely as the range of the object. This angle can be obtained by calculation, or a table of corresponding values. In the instrument exhibited such an arrangement is effected by mounting one object lens and its pair of reflecting prisms in a separate tube within the main tube containing the other set, and pivoted to this so that the rotation can be effected by a screw threaded in the outer tube with its end pressing against the inner. The angle of rotation is measured by a vernier on one tube and a scale nearest second of arc, and the range read off on a table fixed to the outer leather protecting cover. (See British Patent, 1860, No. 357; and 1863, No. 608.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1909–139.

Object name: BARR AND STROUD INFANTRY RANGEFINDER. (Early Type.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Barr & Stroud, Ltd.
Date of creation: Made in 1889.
Object entry information: This instrument was made in 1889, and is one of the first rangefinders constructed by Messrs. Barr & Stroud for use by infantry. It is a single-observation, coincidence instrument, with a fixed base of 80 cm., and measures ranges between 200 and 2,000 yd. with a percentage error directly proportional to the distance. The instrument is optically equivalent to a pair of telescopes having a common central eye-piece and their axes in opposite directions along the base-line, at the ends of which are the two objective lenses. Catalogue number: 76.
Object name: MEKOMETER, GENERAL SERVICE PATTERN.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by T. Cooke and Sons, Ltd., York.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This standard rangefinding set is used by infantry units. It comprises two optical sighting instruments, known as the “Right Angle” and “Reading” instruments, and two reels of cord, each 25 yd. long, for setting off the base. The observer at one end of the base uses the “Right Angle” instrument to make the base line perpendicular to the line joining his position to the distant object, after which the other observer uses his “Reading” instrument to measure the angle between the base line and the direction of the object from his position. The Right Angle instrument has two fixed vertical mirrors inclined to each other at an angle of 45°. The observer using this sees the target directly and the vane on the Reading instrument after double reflection at the two mirrors. He adjusts his position, keeping the base line fully extended, until the two images coincide. The Reading instrument differs only in that one of its mirrors can be rotated, and the rotation recorded upon a graduated drum, so that the images of the target (viewed directly) and the vane of the Right Angle instrument (viewed by double reflection on the two mirrors) can be made to coincide. The graduated drum is calibrated to record the range directly. (See “ Handbook of the Mekometer.”)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–293.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 77.
Object name: ADIE TELEMETER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by the Admiralty. (Designed by P. Adie in 1860).
Date of creation: Designed in 1860.
Object entry information: This type of rangefinder was designed by P. Adie in 1860, and was extensively used by the Admiralty until superseded by the Barr and Stroud pattern. The example shown was used on H.M.S. “Triton” from 1885 to 1904 during the survey of the East Coast of England. The rangefinder consists of two systems of lenses and right-angled reflecting prisms mounted in a 3-ft. metal tube of square section. Each system forms a “broken” telescope, the objectives being at each end of the tube, along which the rays, originally perpendicular to it, are deflected by right-angled prisms to the centre, where they are again reflected at right angles into the common central eye-piece. In this manner two images of a distant object whose direction is nearly perpendicular to the axis of the tube are obtained, one through each system. These images will be separated laterally by an interval which diminishes continuously as the range increases, but does not become zero until the object is at an infinite distance. If the objective lens and two prisms of one system are separately mounted and can be rotated with respect to the other system, the two images may be made to coincide by such a rotation, and the angle of rotation necessary will vary inversely as the range of the object. This angle can be obtained by calculation, or a table of corresponding values. In the instrument exhibited such an arrangement is effected by mounting one object lens and its pair of reflecting prisms in a separate tube within the main tube containing the other set, and pivoted to this so that the rotation can be effected by a screw threaded in the outer tube with its end pressing against the inner. The angle of rotation is measured by a vernier on one tube and a scale nearest second of arc, and the range read off on a table fixed to the outer leather protecting cover. (See British Patent, 1860, No. 357; and 1863, No. 608.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1909–139.

Object name: BARR AND STROUD INFANTRY RANGEFINDER. (Early Type.)
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Barr & Stroud, Ltd.
Object entry information: This instrument was made in 1889, and is one of the first rangefinders constructed by Messrs. Barr & Stroud for use by infantry. It is a single-observation, coincidence instrument, with a fixed base of 80 cm., and measures ranges between 200 and 2,000 yd. with a percentage error directly proportional to the distance. The instrument is optically equivalent to a pair of telescopes having a common central eye-piece and their axes in opposite directions along the base-line, at the ends of which are the two objective lenses. Two pencils of rays diverging from the distant object to each end of the instrument are reflected at right angles by mirrors so as to traverse the objectives and form two images at the centre, where they are again reflected at right angles by a pair of mirrors, one of which is parallel to each end mirror. The two images are thus viewed in the focal plane of the right eyepiece of the instrument, and are separated laterally by a distance inversely proportional to the required range. Between the right objective lens and the central mirrors there is a small angled deflecting prism, which can move along the axis, and in so doing increases or decreases the amount of separation of the two images. In one position of the prism, corresponding to the distance of the object, the two images coincide. A scale attached to the prism moves with it and is graduated so as to give the range directly. This scale and its fixed index-line are viewed by the observer’s left eye in a separate eyepiece, which also serves in conjunction with a field lens as a small telescope of large field for picking up the target.

Catalogue number: 79
Object name: BARR AND STROUD RANGEFINDER ON NAVAL MOUNTING.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Barr & Stroud, Ltd.
Date of creation: 1902–04 / 1910–13 (Period of use)
Object entry information: This instrument was used by Dr. Bruce in the Weddell Sea Antarctic expedition on the “Scotia,” 1902–04, and afterwards by Capt. R. F. Scott, R.N., on the “Terra Nova” in the British Antarctic expedition 1910–13.
The rangefinder is of the F.A. 2 type, base 4 ft. 6 in., mounted on a type N.M. naval mounting which permits the tube to be rotated in azimuth and altitude. Its optical system is functionally similar to that of the adjacent early infantry type, but special reflecting prisms replace the mirrors there employed. The two images formed in the central eyepiece are erect, and are separated by a fine horizontal line bisecting the field. Coincidence of these images is effected by moving a deflecting prism to which is attached a scale whose lateral motion is measured and indicates the required range as in the earlier instrument. The scale can be illuminated for night reading, when a cylindrical lens astigmatiser is put into action and serves to draw out the images of a luminous point into fine vertical streaks suitable for effecting coincidence. The instrument can be adjusted at a known range by “halving” and “coincidence” fittings, and will then read all ranges correctly.
The approximate uncertainty of measurement varies from 2 yd. in 1,000 to 200 in 10,000, the percentage error increasing directly with the range. The magnification of the main telescope system is 26 diam., its angular field of view 1° 20′ horizontally and 0° 40′ vertically. The finder telescope magnifies 2·5 diam. and has a 7° field of view.
(See “The Modern Rangefinder,” by Prof. F. J. Cheshire. “Theory of Modern Optical Instruments,” Appendix on Rangefinders, by Gleichen.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–179

Catalogue number: 80
Object name: FORBES’ STEREOSCOPIC RANGEFINDER.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Prof. G. Forbes, F.R.S.
Date of creation: 1901 (Designed)
Object entry information: Prof. Forbes designed this type of rangefinder in 1901, for use by infantry in measuring ranges up to 3,000 yd. The power of the eyes to “converge” to a varying degree upon objects at different distances, and to measure distances by the muscular effort so required, is limited normally to small distances of a few yards. Consequently, in this, as in all stereoscopic rangefinders, optical means are employed to bring the image of the object ranged upon within the limit of normal eye convergence. The use of an optical base, whose function is to increase the inter-ocular distance from 2·5 in. to 72 in., and a pair of binoculars of magnification 8 diam. enables the radius of stereoscopic vision to be increased 240 times.
In this instrument, the optical base consists of two pairs of doubly reflecting pentagonal prisms, mounted one at each end and two at inter-ocular distance apart in the centre of a metal tube, which is hinged in the centre so as to fold into two portions each 38 in. long. When in use these two portions are clamped to form a single tube with the end prisms 72 in. apart. The binoculars are fitted with their objectives opposite the centre prisms, there being windows in the tube opposite all the prisms. After double reflection at the end and centre prisms, an image of the distant object is formed in the focal plane of each objective of the binoculars, in which plane there is a glass plate carrying a photograph of a

Object entry information: Prof. Forbes designed this type of rangefinder in 1901, for use by infantry in measuring ranges up to 3,000 yd. The distance between the two balloon images is varied by a micrometer screw. If the observer combines these balloon images stereoscopically into one, and does the same with the images of the distant object, he can judge the apparent distances of the two images, and turn the screw until these distances coincide. The rotation of the screw thus serves as a measure of the required range, and this can be read off directly on a circular scale, attached to the screw and suitably graduated.

Catalogue number: 81
Object name: TACHEOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Troughton & Simms.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: A Porro "anallatic" lens is inserted between the objective and eye lenses of this instrument and its horizontal and vertical circles are divided centesimally. It is used in conjunction with a graduated tacheometric staff, upon which the interval subtended between the fixed cross wire varies directly as the distance of the staff from the transverse axis of the instrument, which is itself vertically above the observing station point.
In the case of an ordinary telescope, the interval subtended by the fixed diaphragm wires upon the staff varies directly with the distance of the staff from the first principal focus of the object lens. Thus, to get the distance from the station point, a constant equal to the distance between this focus and the station point, or the transverse axis of the instrument, must be added in every case. This is unnecessary when an anallatic lens is used, for this lens is so placed that the transverse axis is the conjugate point of its first principal focus with respect to the objective lens, and is thus the first principal focus of the combination of the two lenses.
In the diaphragm of this instrument there are five horizontal wires and one pair of cross wires may be chosen to suit the magnitude of the distance measured.
The focal length of the objective lens is 9.5 in., that of the anallatic lens being 6 in. The eye-piece is of the Ramsden type, and can be traversed vertically through a small distance relative to the telescope. The anallatic lens is fitted in a separate tube inside the telescope tube carrying the objective lens, and can be adjusted by a rack and pinion arrangement actuated by a special key. The divided circles are 4 in. diameter and are read by verniers to centesimal minutes.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1890–55.

title: Tacheometer with slide rule and components

Maker/Donor: Made by Stärke & Kammerer, Vienna.
Object entry information: To convert a theodolite into a tacheometer for measuring distances, many devices have been proposed which permit the telescope, when directed upon a graduated staff, to be displaced through a constant small angle, whose limits are determined by two mechanical stops. The distance so measured on the staff will vary directly as the horizontal distance of the staff from the observing station and inversely as the square of the cosine of the altitude angle. As the latter is known, the former can be calculated by using special tables. In the tacheometer invented about 1868 by A. Gentilli, the Austrian engineer, a rigid vertical arm can be clamped to the transverse axis of the telescope in any position. The lower end of this arm can only move a short distance, being limited by two mechanical stops. Consequently the vertical angle through which the telescope can move when clamped to the arm is likewise limited. The instrument in other respects is like an ordinary theodolite of the type made by Stärke about this period. It has a 5-in. horizontal circle and a 3.5-in. vertical quadrant, both reading by vernier and reading microscope to 30'' and having the usual clamps and tangent screws. The telescope has an objective lens of 12 in. focal length and 1.5 in. aperture. The instrument has four levelling screws, two small spirit levels mutually perpendicular on the horizontal circle, and a more sensitive one on the telescope.

title: Gentilli  type tacheometer, Austrian.
description: Gentilli  type tacheometer by Starke & Kammerer, Vienna, Austria, 1868-1876.
material: glass; alcohol; brass (copper, zinc alloy); steel (metal); platinum (metal)

Object entry information: An early example of a theodolite modified to enable distances to be measured with it simultaneously with azimuth and altitude angles is here represented in the “Omnimeter,” invented by C. A. C. Eckhold in 1868. This instrument is used in conjunction with a special tacheometric staff having a fixed interval, usually 10 ft., marked upon it. A microscope, rigidly attached with its axis perpendicular to that of the observing telescope, rotating with this telescope about a common transverse axis, measures upon a scale fixed horizontally upon the upper plate of the theodolite the distance traversed when the observing telescope is rotated from the upper mark to the lower mark of the staff. As this staff is always set up vertically, its horizontal distance from the centre of the instrument is inversely proportional to the distance traversed on the scale. The microscope scale is mounted parallel to the telescope at a distance of exactly 6 in. below the transverse axis. It is 4 in. long and is graduated to read 0·02 in. directly, whilst it can be moved on the plate, parallel to its own length, through a small interval by means of a micrometer screw with a graduated drum, which measures 0·002 of each division of the scale. In this manner the ultimate graduation of the scale corresponds to 4 × 10⁻⁵ in. so that, if n such divisions are traversed when the theodolite rotates from the upper to the lower mark of the staff, the distance of this staff from the instrument will be 15 × 10³ ÷ n ft. In other respects the instrument is similar to an ordinary transit repeating theodolite. It has 5-in. vertical and horizontal circles reading by vernier to single minutes. The focal length of the telescope is 11 in., and its aperture 1·25 in. It is fitted with a Ramsden eyepiece. Slow-motion tangent screws are provided for each circle, and the usual spirit-levels on the plate and telescope. A diagonal eyepiece is fitted to the microscope for convenience in taking steep sights.

Catalogue number: 83.
Object name: ECKHOLD'S OMNIMETER.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: 1868
Object entry information: An early example of a theodolite modified to enable distances to be measured with it simultaneously with azimuth and altitude angles is here represented in the “Omnimeter,” invented by C. A. C. Eckhold in 1868. This instrument is used in conjunction with a special tacheometric staff having a fixed interval, usually 10 ft., marked upon it. A microscope, rigidly attached with its axis perpendicular to that of the observing telescope, rotating with this telescope about a common transverse axis, measures upon a scale fixed horizontally upon the upper plate of the theodolite the distance traversed when the observing telescope is rotated from the upper mark to the lower mark of the staff. As this staff is always set up vertically, its horizontal distance from the centre of the instrument is inversely proportional to the distance traversed on the scale. The microscope scale is mounted parallel to the telescope at a distance of exactly 6 in. below the transverse axis. It is 4 in. long and is graduated to read 0·02 in. directly, whilst it can be moved on the plate, parallel to its own length, through a small interval by means of a micrometer screw with a graduated drum, which measures 0·002 of each division of the scale. In this manner the ultimate graduation of the scale corresponds to 4 × 10⁻⁵ in. so that, if n such divisions are traversed when the theodolite rotates from the upper to the lower mark of the staff, the distance of this staff from the instrument will be 15 × 10³ ÷ n ft. In other respects the instrument is similar to an ordinary transit repeating theodolite. It has 5-in. vertical and horizontal circles reading by vernier to single minutes. The focal length of the telescope is 11 in., and its aperture 1·25 in. It is fitted with a Ramsden eyepiece. Slow-motion tangent screws are provided for each circle, and the usual spirit-levels on the plate and telescope. A diagonal eyepiece is fitted to the microscope for convenience in taking steep sights.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1900-90.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 84.
Object name: PHOTOGRAPHS OF JEFFCOTT DIRECT-READING TACHEOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by Messrs. Cooke, Troughton & Simms, Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: Ordinary tacheometers are designed for horizontal sights, and the readings have to be corrected by computation if the sight is inclined, whilst a further calculation is necessary to determine the difference in height between the observed and observing stations. Many devices have been introduced in the design of tacheometers with the object of rendering such calculations unnecessary, and enabling the distance and altitude to be read off directly, whether the line of sight is horizontal or inclined. The tacheometer illustrated embodies Prof. H. H. Jeffcott’s arrangement for rendering the readings independent of the inclination. A similar arrangement of varying diaphragm-interval enables the height also to be obtained by reading the staff-interval intercepted. The diaphragm has one fixed and two movable horizontal platinum-iridium pointers, the former for collimation and the latter to limit the intervals for height and distance readings respectively: the distance pointer is on the same side as the collimation pointer, and the height pointer on the opposite side. Each movable pointer is fixed on the end of a pivoted lever, of which the other end is pressed against a suitably shaped cam, which is rotated by the movement in inclination of the telescope, so that the distance of either movable pointer from the fixed one is suitably varied to make the interval intercepted upon the distant staff exactly one-hundredth of the range and one-tenth of the height respectively. The cams are made to suit elevations and depressions up to 30°, and are mounted inside a protecting case at one end of the transit axis of the telescope.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Maker/Donor: Made and lent by Messrs. Cooke, Troughton & Simms, Ltd.
Object entry information: Ordinary tacheometers are designed for horizontal sights, and the readings have to be corrected by computation if the sight is inclined, whilst a further calculation is necessary to determine the difference in height between the observed and observing stations. Many devices have been introduced in the design of tacheometers with the object of rendering such calculations unnecessary, and enabling the distance and altitude to be read off directly, whether the line of sight is horizontal or inclined. The tacheometer illustrated embodies Prof. H. H. Jeffcott’s arrangement for rendering the readings independent of the inclination. A similar arrangement of varying diaphragm-interval enables the height also to be obtained by reading the staff-interval intercepted. The diaphragm has one fixed and two movable horizontal platinum-iridium pointers, the former for collimation and the latter to limit the intervals for height and distance readings respectively: the distance pointer is on the same side as the collimation pointer, and the height pointer on the opposite side. Each movable pointer is fixed on the end of a pivoted lever, of which the other end is pressed against a suitably shaped cam, which is rotated by the movement in inclination of the telescope, so that the distance of either movable pointer from the fixed one is suitably varied to make the interval intercepted upon the distant staff exactly one-hundredth of the range and one-tenth of the height respectively. The cams are made to suit elevations and depressions up to 30°, and are mounted inside a protecting case at one end of the transit axis of the telescope. The instrument in other respects resembles the ordinary tacheometric theodolite. It has a 5-in. horizontal circle, graduated on silver to 20 minutes and read by two verniers; one coarse vernier for ordinary use reads to 1 minute whilst the other, reading to 20 seconds, is only used in adjusting or testing the instrument. No vertical circle is supplied, unless specially desired. The telescope is provided with an anallatic lens, an objective of 1.65 in. aperture, and a screw-focussing, inverting eyepiece of power 18. The eyepiece is mounted in a movable slide for reading at extreme angles. Three bubble-levels are provided, one on the cover-plate, another above the telescope, and the third on the control arm of the cams; this last is particularly sensitive, having a bubble shift of 2 mm. per 15-20 seconds of elevation. (See Brit. Patent Spec. No. 18721 of 1912. Transactions of the Institution of Civil Engineers of Ireland. Jan. 6th 1915.)

Maker/Donor: Troughton & Simms.
Object entry information: This is a 4-metre wooden staff, graduated in centimetres and used in conjunction with the tacheometer, Cat. No. 81. It is inextensible, and does not materially differ from a levelling rod. The graduation marks are black bands, 1 cm. wide, at intervals of 1 cm. Those corresponding to metres and decimetres extend right across the face, the rest only half across. The metres are numbered by large red numbers and the decimetres by smaller black numbers. The half-decimetre points are marked by small black arrows. The rod has a rectangular section, 3 in. wide by 1 1/4 in. deep, and the face is slightly sunk below the edges to prevent abrasion of the graduations.

Object name: PHOTOGRAPH OF TWO ANCIENT EGYPTIAN LEVELS.
Maker/Donor: Presented by Captain H. G. Lyons, F.R.S.
Object entry information: The original levels, which are of the A-shaped plummet type, are exhibited in the Cairo Museum and are of considerable antiquity. Such levels were used by builders and engineers of all the early civilizations and have survived in use to the present date without fundamental modification. Each level consists of a wooden frame in the shape of an isosceles triangle, having its sides equally prolonged beyond the base. The ends of the legs are cut parallel to the cross piece, so that the frame may rest upon a flat surface. A plummet is suspended from the apex of the frame, and its cord passes over the front of the cross piece, in the middle of which is engraved a vertical mark. If the cord lies along this mark when the plummet hangs freely, the surface on which the level rests is horizontal. Hieroglyphics are engraved in the face of the lower level.

Catalogue number: 87.
Object name: INSTRUMENT FOR ASCERTAINING HEIGHTS.
Maker/Donor: Presented by T. H. Court, Esq.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This consists of an isosceles, right-angled metal triangle which can be freely suspended by means of two brass pins so that its two equal sides are vertical and horizontal respectively. All objects in the prolongation of its third side will then be at a horizontal distance from the instrument equal to their height above it. The former distance can be measured, and the height thus ascertained. The hypotenuse of the metal triangle has a pair of sights which enable objects in its line to be viewed. When using the instrument, the observer takes up a position from which he can sight the object whose height is required, the instrument being freely suspended. He then measures his horizontal distance from a point vertically beneath the object. This distance is equal to the height of the object above the eye-level of the observer. When not in use, the instrument fits in the wooden case exhibited with it.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1917-39.

Maker/Donor: Lent by T. H. Court, Esq.
Object entry information: Plate II, Fig. 1, p. 38. This is a level of a type much used for rough levelling during the 17th century, and probably dates from the latter half of that period. It consists of a heavy tube freely suspended from the top of a wooden case by a thread attached to its centre. The tube has a horizontal slit at one end, and a corresponding cross wire at the other; glass windows in the ends of the wooden case permit a free view along the sights. The instrument as a whole can be rotated in azimuth upon its stand. When not in use, the sighting tube can be fixed by means of two screws passing through the bottom of the wooden case. In this instrument, the centre of gravity of the suspended tube is very little, if any, below the line of sight. Hence the tube is very sensitive to disturbances, which is a source of trouble. Moreover, there is no easy method of adjusting the line of sight to be truly horizontal. Owing to these defects, both of which were remedied in the more precise instruments on the "balance" principle designed by Huygens, this type of level is not very accurate. The body of the tube is made of lead, the ends containing the sights being of brass. The wooden case is screwed into the top of a small column, provided with a brass socket at its other end. The socket serves to attach the level to its stand, which may be a tripod or simply a "stick" stand.

Object name: PLUMMET LEVEL AND CLINOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Jacob Kranewetter.
Date of creation: 1755
Object entry information: This is a German instrument made in 1755, and consists of a hollow wooden stand with a flat base and brass facings. A brass plummet is suspended down one face, and by its position on a scale of degrees engraved on the lower part of the face measures the inclination of the base of the instrument. No sights are provided. A brass knob, screwed into the top of the stand can be detached and used as a plummet; a cord wound round a drum inside the stand is used to suspend the knob. The plummet has a length of 4·8 in., which is the radius of the graduated arc. This extends 15° on either side of the vertical.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1880–201.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 91.
Object name: BALANCE LEVEL.
Maker/Donor: Made by Susse Bros., Paris.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This instrument can be used for testing whether a surface is horizontal, vertical or inclined at 45°. It consists of a loaded disc, pivoted between the vertical faces of a cylindrical brass case fixed to a brass ruler. Marks engraved on the edge of the revolving disc show by their coincidence with marks on the fixed case whether the ruler, which is placed on the surface to be tested, is horizontal, vertical, or inclined at 45°. The ruler has a length of about 6 in., and one of its bevelled edges is graduated in millimetres. The disc has a diameter of 2 in.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1857–25.

Maker/Donor: Presented by T. H. Court, Esq.

Object entry information: This type of level was invented by Col. Burel in 1829, and operates upon the principle that in a vertically suspended mirror the eye sees a reflected image of itself at its own level. The instrument consists of a rectangular frame, suspended in gimbal bearings so as to hang vertical owing to its own weight. The frame contains a piece of plane glass, of which one vertical half is silvered and the other half left free for direct vision of a distant object. A horizontal cross wire bisects the two parts. The observer holds the instrument in front of his eye and moves it until he sees the reflected image of his eye bisected by the cross wire. Any distant object then intersected by the wire will be at the level of his eye. (See "Memorial de l'Officier du Génie," No. 10, 1829.)

Object name: REFLECTING PLUMMET LEVEL.
Maker/Donor: Presented by T. H. Court, Esq.
Date of creation: N/A

title: Reflecting plummet level
description: Reflecting plummet level, similar to Burel type but with screw adjustment, 1829-1900

Maker/Donor: Made and lent by T. Cooke & Sons, Ltd., York.
Object entry information: Of the many arrangements for converting a Burel reflecting level into a clinometer, the one here represented, devised by General A. De Lisle, R.E., is the most satisfactory. A heavy arc is attached to the lower part of the mirror frame and can be turned into the same plane as the mirror for convenience of carriage, or into a perpendicular frame for measuring angles of elevation or depression. In the latter position the weight of the arc causes the mirror plane to take up an inclination to the vertical, which can be varied by means of a movable radial arm, concentric with the arc and carrying a sliding counterpoise at its extremity. The arc is so graduated on its edge that the position of one edge of the movable arm gives the inclination of the mirror, and, therefore, of the line of sight between the observer's eye and its reflection in the mirror. The arc is graduated to read gradients from zero to 1 in 5.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 95
Object name: SPIRIT LEVEL.
Maker/Donor: Made by Troughton & Simms. Lent by the Royal Society.
Date of creation: Constructed in the early part of the 19th century (Used in 1831)
Object entry information: This level was constructed in the early part of the 19th century and used in 1831 by J. A. Lloyd, F.R.S., in ascertaining the differences of level between the Thames at London Bridge, Sheerness and various intermediate points. The telescope has a focal length of 28 in. and is finally levelled by means of a 12-in. spirit level mounted at one side parallel to its axis. The objective lens of the telescope has a 2-in. aperture, and is fixed in the tube, the eyepiece tube being focussed by a rack and pinion arrangement and having a fixed diaphragm and a slide focussing Ramsden inverting eyepiece. The telescope is attached to a transverse horizontal axis, which rests in Y-s on standards fixed to the horizontal plate. The telescope is supported near both ends by vertical screws threaded in the ends of a rigid bar fixed to the horizontal plate parallel to the axis of the telescope. These screws are used in the final adjustment of the telescope axis, which is tested by the main spirit level. This bar is suspended from the ends of a metal rod fixed on one side of the telescope, and has ivory scales graduated to thirtieths of an inch mounted above its bubble-tube. A small level is also fixed transversely at one end of the main level. The bubble of the latter moves over one division of the scale when the telescope is elevated about 2 seconds of arc. The horizontal plate can rotate about a vertical axis, and has a clamp and tangent screw for slow motion. It is attached to a pair of parallel plates, connected by four levelling screws of the usual type. A small circular spirit-level is fixed to the plate above its centre for setting it horizontal. The telescope can be reversed in its Y-s end for end, or rotated through 180° about its own axis, as in all Y-levels. (See Phil. Trans. Roy. Soc., 1831.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1900-155.

Object name: SPIRIT LEVEL. Plate II, Fig. 2, p. 38.
Maker/Donor: Made by Cary. Lent by the Royal Society.

Maker/Donor: Made by Troughton & Simms. Lent by the Royal Society.
Date of creation: Constructed in the early part of the 19th century (Used in 1831)
Object entry information: This level was constructed in the early part of the 19th century and used in 1831 by J. A. Lloyd, F.R.S., in ascertaining the differences of level between the Thames at London Bridge, Sheerness and various intermediate points. The telescope has a focal length of 28 in. and is finally levelled by means of a 12-in. spirit level mounted at one side parallel to its axis. The objective lens of the telescope has a 2-in. aperture, and is fixed in the tube, the eyepiece tube being focussed by a rack and pinion arrangement and having a fixed diaphragm and a slide focussing Ramsden inverting eyepiece. The telescope is attached to a transverse horizontal axis, which rests in Y-s on standards fixed to the horizontal plate. The telescope is supported near both ends by vertical screws threaded in the ends of a rigid bar fixed to the horizontal plate parallel to the axis of the telescope. These screws are used in the final adjustment of the telescope axis, which is tested by the main spirit level. This bar is suspended from the ends of a metal rod fixed on one side of the telescope, and has ivory scales graduated to thirtieths of an inch mounted above its bubble-tube. A small level is also fixed transversely at one end of the main level. The bubble of the latter moves over one division of the scale when the telescope is elevated about 2 seconds of arc. The horizontal plate can rotate about a vertical axis, and has a clamp and tangent screw for slow motion. It is attached to a pair of parallel plates, connected by four levelling screws of the usual type. A small circular spirit-level is fixed to the plate above its centre for setting it horizontal. The telescope can be reversed in its Y-s end for end, or rotated through 180° about its own axis, as in all Y-levels. (See Phil. Trans. Roy. Soc., 1831.)

Catalogue number: 94
Object name: DE LISLE'S REFLECTING CLINOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by T. Cooke & Sons, Ltd., York.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: Of the many arrangements for converting a Burel reflecting level into a clinometer, the one here represented, devised by General A. De Lisle, R.E., is the most satisfactory. A heavy arc is attached to the lower part of the mirror frame and can be turned into the same plane as the mirror for convenience of carriage, or into a perpendicular frame for measuring angles of elevation or depression. In the latter position the weight of the arc causes the mirror plane to take up an inclination to the vertical, which can be varied by means of a movable radial arm, concentric with the arc and carrying a sliding counterpoise at its extremity. The arc is so graduated on its edge that the position of one edge of the movable arm gives the inclination of the mirror, and, therefore, of the line of sight between the observer's eye and its reflection in the mirror. The arc is graduated to read gradients from zero to 1 in 5.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-519.
