Object name: SPIRIT LEVEL. Plate II, Fig. 2, p. 38.
Maker/Donor: Made by Cary. Lent by the Royal Society.
Date of creation: Made about the year 1830 and was used in 1831
Object entry information: This level was made about the year 1830 and was used in 1831 by J. A. Lloyd, F.R.S., in measuring the differences of level between the Thames at London Bridge, Sheerness and various intermediate points. It has a 30-in. telescope mounted in Y-s in a manner similar to the ordinary Y-level, but is fitted with an extra spirit level suspended above the telescope, and also has a circular supporting base resembling that of a large theodolite and resting on three footscrews. The objective lens of the telescope has a 2-in. aperture and is fixed in the tube, the eyepiece tube having a rack and pinion focussing movement. The eyepiece is of the Ramsden inverting type and is also focussed by a rack and pinion movement. Gun-metal collars are shrunk on to the telescope near its extremities and rest in Y-s fixed to the horizontal circle. One of these Y-s can be adjusted vertically by means of a screw. This adjustment serves to level the telescope more precisely than is possible with the footscrews. The 14-in. horizontal circle can rotate about a vertical axis, and has a clamp and tangent screw. It also carries a central 31-in. compass, graduated in degrees, and a small thermometer. The supporting base of the instrument consists of two horizontal circles of 14 in. diameter connected by three vertical pillars to which the three foot-screws are fixed. Beneath the telescope a 17-in. spirit level is mounted in adjustable bearings, and a 22-in. level of similar construction can be suspended above the telescope from pivots carried by brackets fixed to the end of the tube. Both pivots are adjustable. Each level has ivory scales, graduated to twentieths of an inch mounted above its tube. Small transverse levels are also fixed to the telescope and at one end of the suspended level. (See Phil. Trans. Roy. Soc., 1831.)

Maker/Donor: Presented by A. Stannard, Esq., A.M.I.C.E.
Object entry information: This level was formerly the property of George Stephenson, and was used by him at Chat Moss in the survey for the Manchester and Liverpool Railway, 1829. It is of the type designed and constructed by Troughton, the spirit-level being rigidly fixed in the telescope, which is not reversible, as in the Ramsden type. Such an instrument, whilst incapable of preliminary adjustment, is very simple and rigid in construction, and is well suited for engineering surveys. A small compass, supported on four pillars, is provided for traversing. The telescope has an aperture of 1 1/4 in. and a focal length of 15 in., and is provided with stops. The eyepiece tube is focussed by a rack and pinion arrangement actuated by a screw. The diaphragm can easily be disclosed for examination by removing the eyepiece. There are two eyepieces provided, one erect and the other inverting. The bubble-tube is 10 in. long, and has a radius of curvature of about 50 ft., giving a motion of the bubble of 1/5 in. for every minute of arc. The compass ring is 2 1/2 in. in diameter, and is graduated to read single degrees.

Catalogue number: 98.
Object name: SPIRIT LEVEL.
Maker/Donor: Made by Troughton & Simms. Lent by the Ordnance Survey.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This instrument was made about the middle of the 19th century, and was used until 1907 for levelling minor lines. The spirit level is attached by adjusting screws to the telescope, which fits in Y-shaped bearings, and can be rotated or reversed in these for adjustment of the line of collimation. The parallel plate arrangement for levelling the instrument is of the usual type, with four levelling-screws, axis clamp and tangent-screw for slow-motion. The telescope has a focal length of 12 in. and an aperture of 1.25 in., and is provided with stops. The focussing is carried out at the objective end by means of a rack and pinion arrangement, actuated by an external screw. The diaphragm containing a horizontal and vertical wire is easily accessible after unscrewing the eyepiece, which is arranged to give an erect image of the staff. The bubble-tube is 7 3/4 in. long, and is graduated in tenths of an inch. The internal radius of curvature of the tube is about 80 ft., giving a movement of the bubble of 0.1 in., corresponding to a change of elevation of 20 seconds.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1912-197.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 99.
Object name: SPIRIT LEVEL.
Maker/Donor: Made by Troughton & Simms. Lent by the Ordnance Survey.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This level was made between 1840 and 1850 and was used for levelling of second-order lines. The spirit level is graduated to read 5 seconds of elevation, and is attached to the telescope, which rests in Y-shaped bearings, and can be rotated or reversed for adjustment of the line of collimation. A compass is provided for rough traversing, and an elevating screw permits the telescope to be finally levelled with great accuracy. In the diaphragm are two vertical and one horizontal wires. The telescope has a focal length of 18 in. and an erecting eyepiece. The aperture is 1.5 in. The eyepiece is adjusted for parallax by a sliding tube arrangement, whilst the telescope is focussed on the staff by a rack and pinion which moves the objective. The compass-ring has a diameter of 3 1/4 in. and is graduated to read single degrees. The spirit level tube is 10 in. long, and is graduated at intervals of 1/4 in., each interval corresponding to 5 seconds of arc. The parallel plate arrangement is of the usual type, and a slow-motion tangent screw is provided for azimuth setting.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1912-198.

The bubble-tube is 7 3/4 in. long, and is graduated in tenths of an inch. The internal radius of curvature of the tube is about 80 ft., giving a movement of the bubble of 0.1 in., corresponding to a change of elevation of 20 seconds.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1912-197.

Object name: SPIRIT LEVEL.

Object entry information: This level was made between 1840 and 1850 and was used for levelling of second-order lines. The spirit level is graduated to read 5 seconds of elevation, and is attached to the telescope, which rests in Y-shaped bearings, and can be rotated or reversed for adjustment of the line of collimation. A compass is provided for rough traversing, and an elevating screw permits the telescope to be finally levelled with great accuracy. In the diaphragm are two vertical and one horizontal wires. The telescope has a focal length of 18 in. and an erecting eyepiece. The aperture is 1.5 in. The eyepiece is adjusted for parallax by a sliding tube arrangement, whilst the telescope is focussed on the staff by a rack and pinion which moves the objective. The compass-ring has a diameter of 3 1/4 in. and is graduated to read single degrees. The spirit level tube is 10 in. long, and is graduated at intervals of 1/4 in., each interval corresponding to 5 seconds of arc. The parallel plate arrangement is of the usual type, and a slow-motion tangent screw is provided for azimuth setting.

title: Surveying level, British, 1826-1866
description: 18-inch level used for levelling second order lines, Troughton & Simms, London, England, 1826-66.

Maker/Donor: Made by Troughton & Simms. Lent by the Ordnance Survey.
Object entry information: This level was made in 1841 and was used in first-order levelling for the Ordnance Survey. It has a telescope of 2·2-in. aperture and 23-in. focal length, with a 12-in. spirit level attached, reading to single seconds of arc. The telescope rests in Y bearings, in which it can be rotated and also reversed end for end, for adjustments. A small transverse level is also provided on the telescope for rough levelling, whilst the final accurate setting is performed by means of an elevating screw, which moves one bearing. The instrument has a 5⅛-in. compass fitted to its alidade for rough traversing, the compass being graduated in single degrees. There is also the usual parallel-plate levelling arrangement, with four screws, for setting the alidade approxi- mately horizontal. A slow motion tangent screw is provided for setting the instru- ment accurately in azimuth. The telescope has a micrometer eyepiece, and is focussed on the staff by moving the eyepiece tube. The spirit level has an ivory scale above each end, graduated in 1/20 in., each division corresponding to about 2 seconds of arc of elevation.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 101.
Object name: SPIRIT LEVEL.
Maker/Donor: Made by C. Sickler. Presented by T. H. Court, Esq.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: A level of this type, serving also for measuring inclines and distances by means of the elevating screw, is particularly adapted by reason of its compactness and simplicity of construction for preliminary surveys where no great accuracy is required. It consists of a small telescope and spirit-level separately mounted upon a platform connected with a tripod by means of a ball-and-socket joint of a special type, often employed in small surveying instruments of German construction. This joint permits the orientation of the platform to be varied, whilst leaving it perfectly free to rotate in azimuth about the socket, which is fixed to the tripod. The platform terminates underneath in a metal ball, at the lower end of which is a cylindrical pin. The socket consists of two parts screwed together, an upper spherical dome enclosing the ball, and a lower tubular sheath surrounding the pin. Two levelling screws, set perpendicularly to each other, work in threads in this sheath, and impinge upon a metal collar which encircles the pin sufficiently tightly to prevent shake, but not to hinder the free azimuthal rotation of the pin, and consequently the platform. Opposite the two screws, and likewise impinging on the collar is a spring which takes the pressure of the screws. By means of these screws the platform can be set level in all directions. The spirit level can be adjusted upon the platform by the small screws at one end of its case, whilst the telescope can be elevated or depressed about an axis at one end fixed in the platform by means of a fine-threaded screw at the other end. The pitch of the screw-threads is half a millimetre, and the movement of this end of the telescope is read to a tenth of a millimetre with the aid of a graduated disc and vertical millimetre scale. For every tenth-millimetre, the line of sight of the telescope moves through an angle whose circular measure is one-thousandth. By this means, as in tacheometry, distances can be measured with fair accuracy.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913-256.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 102.
Object name: SPIRIT LEVEL.
Maker/Donor: Made by Zimmer Bros., Stuttgart.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This instrument, primarily designed for levelling, can also be employed for measuring angles in any plane, and is likewise provided with stadia lines in the diaphragm of the telescope for measuring distances. It is thus a type of cheap, portable, universal instrument, specially adapted for surveys of minor precision. The special features which distinguish it from an ordinary small level are the graduated semicircle and the peculiar method of attaching the spirit level to the telescope and the whole instrument to the tripod. The lower parallel plate is not attached directly to the tripod head, but to an intermediate knuckle-joint piece, which permits the instrument as a whole to be set with the semicircle in any plane. The spirit level can also be attached to the telescope in two places, one serving when the semicircle is horizontal and the other when it is vertical. The telescope can rotate on the semicircle, which is graduated to 30 minutes and reads by vernier to 2 minutes, and the semicircle can likewise rotate irrespective of the telescope, thus permitting angles to be “repeated.” The diameter of the graduated semicircle is 18 cm. The parallel plate arrange- ment is of the usual type, with four levelling screws.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876-1196.

title: Spirit level graphometer, German, 1870-1876
description: Spirit level graphometer by Zimmer Brothers Stuttgart, Germany, 1870-1876

Maker/Donor: Made by F. W. Breithaupt and Son, Cassel.
Object entry information: This is a later modification of a level designed and constructed by F. W. Breithaupt in 1845, with the idea of minimizing the instrumental adjustments usually necessary as a preliminary to taking levels. The method of weighting the main spirit level and suspending it freely in pin bearings attached to the telescope enables the surveyor to compensate by double readings the errors arising from non-parallelism of the spirit-level axis, telescope axis, and line of sight. In this level the telescope can be rotated in its collars through a complete half-turn, the extreme positions being determined by mechanical stops. The spirit level, whilst revolving with the telescope, does not rotate, but is kept with its engraved scale uppermost. Consequently the bubble is always visible against the scale, and its variation during the rotation measures the extent to which the axis of the spirit level is inclined to the axis of rotation of the telescope. Such an inclination, if small, will be automatically rendered ineffective provided two readings of the levelling staff are made with the spirit level “centred,” one before the telescope is rotated in its collars through 180°, and the other after. This double reading also corrects for lack of coincidence between the mechanical axis of rotation of the telescope and the line of sight. The mean of the two readings will be the true reading which would be obtained if the three axes of spirit level, telescope rings and vision were mutually parallel. Thus it is not necessary to adjust the instrument beforehand for this parallelism. It is, however, essential that the spirit level itself should be so adjusted that when its bubble is central, its own axis of rotation reversing the spirit level in its bearings should be horizontal. This can be tested by centring the bubble, and reading the bubble again. Half the difference is removed by the means of the two capstan-headed screws which fix one end of the bubble tube to its case. To enable the spirit level to be so reversed, one bearing pin can be withdrawn from its supporting bracket. The lower part of the instrument is provided with a circular box level, which serves to set the main axis nearly vertical by means of the footscrews. No attempt is made to render this axis exactly vertical, as the telescope is always finally levelled by means of the elevating screw. The head of this latter is divided, and serves to measure very accurately small gradients. The diaphragm of the telescope has two horizontal subtense wires in addition to the central levelling wires, so that the instrument can be used to measure distances. The “suspension” spirit level of the type here shown was soon superseded in compensating levels by Amsler’s two-sided “reversion” level, which is much less liable to be injured by shocks than Breithaupt’s pattern. See “Dingler’s Polytechnisches Journal,” Bd. 133, p. 401, 1859.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 104.
Object name: COOKE’S REVERSIBLE LEVEL (14-in.).
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by T. Cooke & Sons, Ltd., York.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The Y-s of an ordinary reversible level are replaced in this instrument by a strong and rigid socket, from which the telescope can be bodily withdrawn and replaced after reversion end for end in the “ collimation ” adjustment. Accurately turned flanges on the telescope fit in collars fixed at the ends of the socket. A stop flange at the eyepiece end of the telescope abuts against the end of the socket when the telescope is in the correct position, and can be fixed to the socket by a screw. The socket is fixed to the horizontal rotating arm by end fittings which permit it to be adjusted on this arm by elevating or depressing one end. The main spirit level is similarly attached in adjustable bearings above the socket, parallel to its axis. A small cross level is fitted at right angles to the axis above the socket at one end. Each division of the main level is 0·1 in. long, corresponding to 20 seconds of elevation. The rotating arm carries a central circular compass, of 3·5 in. diameter, graduated in half-degrees, and read by a prismatic reader. The needle can be lifted from its pivot and clamped by turning a screw at one end of the arm. The conical socket carrying the axis of rotation is fixed to the tribrach, in the arms of which engage three footscrews. The feet of these are firmly attached to a trivet stage which can be screwed to the tripod head. This stage has three pointed feet which serve to fix the instrument to a platform when the tripod is inconvenient. The telescope has an objective of 14 in. focal length and 1·55 in. clear aperture, and an inverting screw-focussing eyepiece magnifying 28 times. The objective end of the telescope is focussed by a rack and pinion arrangement actuated by a screw at one side of the eye end. The glass diaphragm has two vertical and one horizontal lines engraved upon it, whilst short horizontal lines etched parallel to the sight line can be used for stadia observations.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-360.

The spirit level, whilst revolving with the telescope, does not rotate, but is kept with its engraved scale uppermost. Consequently the bubble is always visible against the scale, and its variation during the rotation measures the extent to which the axis of the spirit level is inclined to the axis of rotation of the telescope. Such an inclination, if small, will be automatically rendered ineffective provided two readings of the levelling staff are made with the spirit level “centred,” one before the telescope is rotated in its collars through 180°, and the other after. This double reading also corrects for lack of coincidence between the mechanical axis of rotation of the telescope and the line of sight. The mean of the two readings will be the true reading which would be obtained if the three axes of spirit level, telescope rings and vision were mutually parallel. Thus it is not necessary to adjust the instrument beforehand for this parallelism. It is, however, essential that the spirit level itself should be so adjusted that when its bubble is central, its own axis of rotation reversing the spirit level in its bearings should be horizontal. This can be tested by centring the bubble, and reading the bubble again. Half the difference is removed by the means of the two capstan-headed screws which fix one end of the bubble tube to its case. To enable the spirit level to be so reversed, one bearing pin can be withdrawn from its supporting bracket. The lower part of the instrument is provided with a circular box level, which serves to set the main axis nearly vertical by means of the footscrews. No attempt is made to render this axis exactly vertical, as the telescope is always finally levelled by means of the elevating screw. The head of this latter is divided, and serves to measure very accurately small gradients. The diaphragm of the telescope has two horizontal subtense wires in addition to the central levelling wires, so that the instrument can be used to measure distances. The “suspension” spirit level of the type here shown was soon superseded in compensating levels by Amsler’s two-sided “reversion” level, which is much less liable to be injured by shocks than Breithaupt’s pattern. See “Dingler’s Polytechnisches Journal,” Bd. 133, p. 401, 1859.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876-1198

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 104.
Object name: COOKE’S REVERSIBLE LEVEL (14-in.).
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by T. Cooke & Sons, Ltd., York.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The Y-s of an ordinary reversible level are replaced in this instrument by a strong and rigid socket, from which the telescope can be bodily withdrawn and replaced after reversion end for end in the “ collimation ” adjustment. Accurately turned flanges on the telescope fit in collars fixed at the ends of the socket. A stop flange at the eyepiece end of the telescope abuts against the end of the socket when the telescope is in the correct position, and can be fixed to the socket by a screw. The socket is fixed to the horizontal rotating arm by end fittings which permit it to be adjusted on this arm by elevating or depressing one end. The main spirit level is similarly attached in adjustable bearings above the socket, parallel to its axis. A small cross level is fitted at right angles to the axis above the socket at one end. Each division of the main level is 0·1 in. long, corresponding to 20 seconds of elevation. The rotating arm carries a central circular compass, of 3·5 in. diameter, graduated in half-degrees, and read by a prismatic reader. The needle can be lifted from its pivot and clamped by turning a screw at one end of the arm. The conical socket carrying the axis of rotation is fixed to the tribrach, in the arms of which engage three footscrews. The feet of these are firmly attached to a trivet stage which can be screwed to the tripod head. This stage has three pointed feet which serve to fix the instrument to a platform when the tripod is inconvenient. The telescope has an objective of 14 in. focal length and 1·55 in. clear aperture, and an inverting screw-focussing eyepiece magnifying 28 times. The objective end of the telescope is focussed by a rack and pinion arrangement actuated by a screw at one side of the eye end. The glass diaphragm has two vertical and one horizontal lines engraved upon it, whilst short horizontal lines etched parallel to the sight line can be used for stadia observations.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-360.

Maker/Donor: C. F. Casella & Co., Ltd.
Object entry information: The compactness and rigidity which are the chief features of the dumpy level have been increased in instruments of recent construction by the employment of an internal focussing lens, which moves between the fixed objective and diaphragm. The telescope tube can thus be rendered more compact, dust-proof and water-tight, whilst the act of focussing is less likely to disturb the line of collimation. In the instrument exhibited, the telescope has a focal length of 9 in. and a clear aperture of 1·4 in. and is provided with a tribrach mounting, with three levelling screws. A 2-in. ring, divided every 2°, is fitted round the upper rim of the tribrach and enables the azimuth angle to be read by means of an index on the telescope socket. A tangent clamp and fine motion screw are also fitted to the tribrach. The feet of the levelling screws pass through a locking plate having a threaded central aperture to receive the clamping piece which attaches the instrument to its tripod. A sensitive tube level, the casing of which also supports a small circular box level, is mounted in adjustable bearings at one side of the telescope. The eyepiece of the telescope is inverting and screw focussing, and has a magnification of 24 diameters.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 106
Object name: DUMPY LEVEL (10-in.)
Maker/Donor: E. R. Watts and Son, Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a modern dumpy level having a fixed objective of 1·5 in. aperture and a fixed glass diaphragm sealing the other end of the 10-in. telescope tube, which is thereby rendered dustproof; a movable internal concave lens is actuated by an external milled head for focussing, and a screw-focussing inverting eyepiece is provided. A 5-in. bubble tube is adjustably mounted on the left of the telescope and has a sensitivity of 20 seconds of elevation per 0·1 in. division of its scale; by means of a hinged reflecting mirror mounted above its scale, it is read by the operator without moving his other eye from the telescope. The telescope tube is permanently fixed to the inner vertical axis of the instrument and rotates within the conical socket of the tribrach levelling base, which has the usual three footscrews connecting it to the trivet stage; dustproof caps are fitted above the heads of the footscrews and their feet are firmly gripped in the grooves of the trivet stage; this latter has a central screwed aperture for attachment to the tripod head, but has also three pointed feet for mounting on a platform without the tripod. The axis clamp and tangent screw of the azimuth motion are of the usual type.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922–443

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 107
Object name: ZEISS PATTERN LEVEL
Maker/Donor: E. R. Watts and Son, Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The optical arrangements for adjusting the collimation axis of the telescope and viewing the bubble are the same in this instrument as in the well-known Zeiss Wild level, but the elevating screw mechanism and tribrach are of the makers’ own design. In order to obviate the necessity for reversing the telescope end for end in the collimation adjustment, it is provided with two similar objectives, one fixed at each end of the tube, and an internal focussing lens. The eyepiece can be fitted at either end, and the nearer objective lens then becomes the diaphragm; each lens is graticuled for this purpose. A screw-focussing eyepiece tube is fitted at the normal eyepiece end, and the objective cap has a central sheath aperture in which the eyepiece can slide at the other end. The normal diaphragm lens has horizontal stadia lines as well as the usual cross lines; the other lens has only a simple cross. The telescope is supported in a central horizontal socket, in which it can rotate through 180° about its own axis. The bubble tube is adjustably fixed at one side of the telescope and rotates with it in the socket; it has apertures at the top and bottom for reading its bubble before and after rotation. A system of prisms mounted above the bubble tube permits the observer to view the two ends of the bubble in his normal position for observing the staff, the bubble being viewed with the left eye and the staff with the right. The socket supporting the telescope is itself mounted upon an elevating platform, which can turn in azimuth about the vertical axis of the tribrach. The telescope socket is pivoted centrally to this platform about a horizontal axis intersecting the main vertical axis of rotation, and can be rotated about this pivot by means of a micrometer elevating screw threaded in the platform at one end;

Maker/Donor: E. R. Watts and Son, Ltd.
Object entry information: The optical arrangements for adjusting the collimation axis of the telescope and viewing the bubble are the same in this instrument as in the well-known Zeiss Wild level, but the elevating screw mechanism and tribrach are of the makers’ own design. In order to obviate the necessity for reversing the telescope end for end in the collimation adjustment, it is provided with two similar objectives, one fixed at each end of the tube, and an internal focussing lens. The eyepiece can be fitted at either end, and the nearer objective lens then becomes the diaphragm; each lens is graticuled for this purpose. A screw-focussing eyepiece tube is fitted at the normal eyepiece end, and the objective cap has a central sheath aperture in which the eyepiece can slide at the other end. The normal diaphragm lens has horizontal stadia lines as well as the usual cross lines; the other lens has only a simple cross. The telescope is supported in a central horizontal socket, in which it can rotate through 180° about its own axis. The bubble tube is adjustably fixed at one side of the telescope and rotates with it in the socket; it has apertures at the top and bottom for reading its bubble before and after rotation. A system of prisms mounted above the bubble tube permits the observer to view the two ends of the bubble in his normal position for observing the staff, the bubble being viewed with the left eye and the staff with the right. The socket supporting the telescope is itself mounted upon an elevating platform, which can turn in azimuth about the vertical axis of the tribrach. The telescope socket is pivoted centrally to this platform about a horizontal axis intersecting the main vertical axis of rotation, and can be rotated about this pivot by means of a micrometer elevating screw threaded in the platform at one end; the screw does not impinge on the socket, but on an intermediate lever arm pivoted horizontally at the other end of the platform and in contact with the socket near this pivot. A spring connecting the socket and platform keeps the former pressed against the lever arm. By this arrangement the weight of the telescope is taken off the elevating screw and its rotation about the central pivot is only a small part of what it would be without the lever arm.

Catalogue number: 108.
Object name: V-LEVEL (14-in.).
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by E. R. Watts and Son, Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The telescope of this level has a rack-focussing objective of 1.3-in. aperture and 14-in. focal length. A 6-in. bubble-tube is mounted adjustably beneath it and has a sensitivity of 22 seconds per 0.1 in. division of its graduations.
The telescope is supported in Y-s by means of gun-metal collars, 8 in. apart, and can be rotated in its Y-s or reversed end for end in the usual manner. The Y-s are permanently fixed to a supporting platform of very rigid construction, but two screws threaded in the arms of one Y permit the telescope to be raised or lowered in that bearing to take up wear. The hinged retaining clips of the Y-s have metal springs attached which keep the collars pressed down on their bearings; one of these springs has a pointed toe which engages in a groove notched in the collar when the telescope is in the normal observing position, *i.e.*, the bubble vertically below its axis.
The supporting platform has a conical axis and can rotate in azimuth within the tribrach levelling base; an axis clamp and tangent screw are provided. Three footscrews are threaded in the tribrach and have their feet firmly clamped in a trivet stage, which can be screwed to a tripod head or can stand on a platform by means of its three pointed feet. The footscrews have dustproof caps threaded in the tribrach to protect their heads and to take up wear.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922–442.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 109.
Object name: PRECISE LEVEL (16-in.).
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by T. Cooke & Sons, Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: A “precise” level, designed for work of the highest possible degree of accuracy, in addition to its greater sensitivity and power, possesses several features not found in ordinary levels. The chief characteristics are the additional facilities for finally levelling the telescope by means of a micrometer screw and a very sensitive bubble, which is read by a supplementary optical arrangement at the same time as the staff, and the protection of the bubble and all movable parts from temperature changes. In the level exhibited, which was introduced by the U.S. Coast and Geodetic Survey about the year 1900, the main bubble tube is sunk well inside the outer telescope tube, which is also covered by felt cloth. A system of mirrors and a supplementary telescope with its eyepiece at binocular distance from the main telescope, enable the observer to read at the same time the staff with his right eye and the ends of the bubble with his left.
The main telescope has an objective of 1.7-in. aperture and 16-in. focal length, mounted in a tube containing the rack focussing eye-piece tube. The objective tube is pivoted near the object end to the cloth-covered outer tube and near the eyepiece end rests on a micrometer screw. By turning this the objective tube can be slightly inclined in the vertical plane through the staff and station point until the bubble, which is fixed to it, is centred. The outer tube itself can rotate about the vertical axis of the instrument and has a tangent clamp and screw for slow-motion in azimuth. A tribrach with three footscrews supports the whole instrument and serves to level it approximately, with the aid of a small box level on the outer telescope tube. The telescope can be lifted from contact with the micrometer screw and clamped inside the outer tube by a lever bar near the micrometer. This arrangement preserves the micrometer from unnecessary use and friction. The micrometer drum is graduated in 100 divisions, each corresponding to the 2-mm. divisions on the main bubble, *i.e.*, to 2 seconds of elevation. The eyepiece tube of the main telescope has a cross-wire diaphragm, with two horizontal stadia lines; two inverting eyepieces, of magnifications 32 and 44, are supplied. The supplementary telescope has a plain aperture eyepiece and two diagonal reflecting prisms which, in conjunction with a plane mirror fixed to the outer telescope tube, reflect the image of each end of the bubble and scale down the axis of the telescope. All the parts of the main telescope which affect the adjustment of its line of collimation are made of “invar.”
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922–206.

A system of mirrors and a supplementary telescope with its eyepiece at binocular distance from the main telescope, enable the observer to read at the same time the staff with his right eye and the ends of the bubble with his left.
The main telescope has an objective of 1.7-in. aperture and 16-in. focal length, mounted in a tube containing the rack focussing eye-piece tube. The objective tube is pivoted near the object end to the cloth-covered outer tube and near the eyepiece end rests on a micrometer screw. By turning this the objective tube can be slightly inclined in the vertical plane through the staff and station point until the bubble, which is fixed to it, is centred. The outer tube itself can rotate about the vertical axis of the instrument and has a tangent clamp and screw for slow-motion in azimuth. A tribrach with three footscrews supports the whole instrument and serves to level it approximately, with the aid of a small box level on the outer telescope tube. The telescope can be lifted from contact with the micrometer screw and clamped inside the outer tube by a lever bar near the micrometer. This arrangement preserves the micrometer from unnecessary use and friction. The micrometer drum is graduated in 100 divisions, each corresponding to the 2-mm. divisions on the main bubble, *i.e.*, to 2 seconds of elevation. The eyepiece tube of the main telescope has a cross-wire diaphragm, with two horizontal stadia lines; two inverting eyepieces, of magnifications 32 and 44, are supplied. The supplementary telescope has a plain aperture eyepiece and two diagonal reflecting prisms which, in conjunction with a plane mirror fixed to the outer telescope tube, reflect the image of each end of the bubble and scale down the axis of the telescope. All the parts of the main telescope which affect the adjustment of its line of collimation are made of “invar.”
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922–206.

Maker/Donor: Made and lent by E. R. Watts and Son, Ltd.
Object entry information: The special features of this level are the bubble-tube and an optical arrangement mounted in front of the objective lens to enable the staff to be read accurately to 0·001 ft. and by estimation to 0·0001 ft. : both these fittings are modified examples of the ones originally mounted on the Zeiss Precise Levels about 1913. The telescope has a screw-focussing inverting eyepiece and a fixed glass diaphragm, engraved with cross lines and horizontal stadia lines. The horizontal cross line is in the form of a very narrow Y, having its stem horizontal and its arms intersecting at a small angle on the vertical line; by this arrangement the division of the staff is bisected by one half and enclosed by the other half of the Y. If the telescope axis, when levelled, does not bisect a staff division, the optical axis is displaced slightly along the staff by means of the ante-objective fitting until a division is accurately bisected. The fitting consists of a plane glass slab of cylindrical shape, pivoted horizontally within a cap-sheath fixed over the objective end of the telescope; the slab can be rotated about its pivot axis by means of a radial lever fixed on the axis and having a pinion wheel at its outer end, which engages in the toothed face of a fixed arc mounted on the cap sheath. The opposite face of this arc is visible to the observer, and is graduated into 20 parts, each division representing 0·001 ft. on the staff, i.e., the optical axis is displaced vertically by this amount when the slab is pivoted through the corresponding arc; an index mark on the rotating lever serves to measure the arc to a tenth division, i.e., to 0·0001 ft. The telescope objective has an aperture of 1·8 in. and is fixed in the tube; an internal lens operated by an external milled head is provided for focussing the staff image on the diaphragm. The micrometer elevating mechanism of the telescope, the Zeiss pattern bubble-tube and the tribrach mountings, with clamp and tangent screw for slow azimuth rotation, are of the same type in this instrument as in the small Zeiss pattern level by the same makers, and are described in connection with the adjacent exhibit (Cat. No. 107). The micrometer drum of the elevating screw is graduated into 20 parts, each corresponding to an elevation of 1 : 10,000, whereby distances can be accurately estimated. This type of level is used in conjunction with an Invar Precise Levelling Staff of the type represented in an adjacent exhibit (Cat. No. 125).

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 111
Object name: CLINOMETER
Maker/Donor: Made by W. Bandermann, Berlin. Presented by T. H. Court, Esq.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This clinometer is not provided with sights, but has two plane edges at right angles and a movable spirit-level with a vernier at one end. The instrument is set on the face of the rod and the level rotated until the bubble is centred, when the zero mark of the vernier gives the inclination to a sixteenth of a degree. The arc over which the vernier moves is graduated in half degrees, each of the eight intervals between the vernier graduations being seven-eighths of a half degree. An instrument of this type is principally used for setting levelling-rods vertical, or for measuring the gradient of a rod used for determining distances in cadastral surveys. It can be set upon some kind of sighting rod and used for measuring gradients or for levelling. The spirit level is very sensitive, and the bubble moves about 0·5 cm. for every variation of a sixteenth of a degree in the inclination.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1917–38.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 112
Object name: CLINOMETER
Maker/Donor: Made by Thos. Jones, London. Presented by the Admiralty.
Date of creation: first half of the 19th century.
Object entry information: This instrument was made in the first half of the 19th century, and is used for measuring the elevation to the horizontal of any inclined plane on which it can be set. It is not provided with sights. It consists of two brass rulers, hinged at one end. The upper ruler carries a sensitive 6-in. spirit level and an index, which moves over a graduated brass arc fixed to the lower ruler. This latter is placed upon the surface to be measured and the other ruler revolved until the bubble of the level is centred, when it can be clamped by a screw on the index plate and the reading taken. The arc is graduated in degrees from 0° to 50°.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911–174A.

title: Two Clinometer rule, British Antarctic Expedition, 1901
description: Two clinometers, jointed-rule type, one by Thomas Jones, first half 19th century, ex Antartic Expedition 1901, the other unsigned
place: Charing Cross, City of Westminster, London, England, United Kingdom

Maker/Donor: Presented by the Admiralty.
Object entry information: In this instrument two brass rulers are hinged together at one end. The upper one has perpendicular sights at each end, of which has both an aperture backsight and a cross-wire foresight, and carries an index plate which moves over a graduated arc fixed to the lower ruler and can be clamped to this arc by a screw. A 3-in. spirit level is supported parallel to the upper ruler in bearings on the sights. The lower ruler has a socket for fixing the instrument to a stand. In using the instrument, the upper ruler is lowered until it rests on the lower and the instrument is levelled by the spirit level, after which the upper ruler is raised until the object whose angular elevation is required is sighted, and the reading of the arc taken. The arc has a radius of 4 in. and is graduated from 0° to 30° in degrees, read by estimation to tenths.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 114.
Object name: ABNEY LEVEL AND CLINOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Cary, London. Presented by Captain H. G. Lyons, F.R.S.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: In a hand-level it is desirable that the object sighted and the levelling mechanism should be simultaneously visible. The combined level and clinometer designed by Capt. Abney, R.E., about the year 1870, utilizes the idea of reflecting the bubble of a spirit level into the line of sight of the sighting tube by means of a diagonal mirror fixed in one half of the latter, the other half being left free for sighting the object. This device had been previously used on a sextant. In the instrument exhibited, a graduated semicircle is rigidly fixed to the rectangular sighting tube, which has a pin-hole aperture and a diagonal mirror fixed beneath a slit in its upper face, vertically beneath the centre of the arc. Through this centre passes an axis, carrying a small transversely mounted spirit level at one extremity and a vernier arm near the other, which terminates in a large milled wheel. On rotating this wheel the spirit level is set at any angle to the line of sight, the angle being measured by the position of the vernier on the graduated arc. The cover of the spirit level has apertures above and below, the latter permitting an image of the bubble to be seen after reflection on the mirror, whilst the former is used when the clinometer is set on the surface whose gradient is required. The arc is graduated in degrees up to 60° on both sides of the vertical, and reads by vernier on the movable arm to 10 minutes. It also has a scale of gradients to 1 in 1, read by the edge of the vernier. The sighting tube is 4 3/8 in. long and the graduated arc has an effective radius of 1 in.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–220.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 115.
Object name: ABNEY LEVEL AND CLINOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Elliott Bros., London. Presented by T. H. Court, Esq.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This example differs from the preceding one in minor details. The graduated arc is fixed to the spirit level and revolves with it, being read for angles up to 45° either way by means of a fiducial mark on the supporting bracket, which is fixed to the sighting tube. Scales of gradients up to 1 in 1 are also marked on the arc beyond the degree graduations and are read by the bevelled edges of the supporting bracket. The edge of the arc is milled, and gears with a small pinion wheel centred in the fixed bracket and rotated by a milled screw. This permits the spirit level and arc to be rotated more slowly and evenly than in the other form. The sighting tube has a circular section, which is not so convenient when the instrument is to be placed on the slope as the rectangular type.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913–254.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 116.
Object name: ABNEY LEVEL AND CLINOMETER.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is similar to the preceding examples, but has also a 1 1/2-in. compass fixed on the upper surface of the sighting tube. The compass ring is graduated in degrees, numbered every 10° by quadrants from the N–S line.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1887–62.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 117.
Object name: FIELD CLINOMETER (Mark III).
Maker/Donor: Made by J. Casartelli & Son.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a modern Service clinometer for measuring to the nearest minute the angle of elevation of a plane surface. The angle is measured to the nearest degree by a rotating arm which traverses a fixed graduated sector attached to the base. The arm is slightly curved on its upper and lower surfaces, and carries a sliding spirit level whose position, when the bubble is central with respect to the scale graduated on the arm, gives the number of minutes in the angle.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Object entry information: This example differs from the preceding one in minor details. The graduated arc is fixed to the spirit level and revolves with it, being read for angles up to 45° either way by means of a fiducial mark on the supporting bracket, which is fixed to the sighting tube. Scales of gradients up to 1 in 1 are also marked on the arc beyond the degree graduations and are read by the bevelled edges of the supporting bracket. The edge of the arc is milled, and gears with a small pinion wheel centred in the fixed bracket and rotated by a milled screw. This permits the spirit level and arc to be rotated more slowly and evenly than in the other form. The sighting tube has a circular section, which is not so convenient when the instrument is to be placed on the slope as the rectangular type.

Catalogue number: 113.
Object name: CLINOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Presented by the Admiralty.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: In this instrument two brass rulers are hinged together at one end. The upper one has perpendicular sights at each end, of which has both an aperture backsight and a cross-wire foresight, and carries an index plate which moves over a graduated arc fixed to the lower ruler and can be clamped to this arc by a screw. A 3-in. spirit level is supported parallel to the upper ruler in bearings on the sights. The lower ruler has a socket for fixing the instrument to a stand. In using the instrument, the upper ruler is lowered until it rests on the lower and the instrument is levelled by the spirit level, after which the upper ruler is raised until the object whose angular elevation is required is sighted, and the reading of the arc taken. The arc has a radius of 4 in. and is graduated from 0° to 30° in degrees, read by estimation to tenths.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911–174B.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 114.
Object name: ABNEY LEVEL AND CLINOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Cary, London. Presented by Captain H. G. Lyons, F.R.S.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: In a hand-level it is desirable that the object sighted and the levelling mechanism should be simultaneously visible. The combined level and clinometer designed by Capt. Abney, R.E., about the year 1870, utilizes the idea of reflecting the bubble of a spirit level into the line of sight of the sighting tube by means of a diagonal mirror fixed in one half of the latter, the other half being left free for sighting the object. This device had been previously used on a sextant. In the instrument exhibited, a graduated semicircle is rigidly fixed to the rectangular sighting tube, which has a pin-hole aperture and a diagonal mirror fixed beneath a slit in its upper face, vertically beneath the centre of the arc. Through this centre passes an axis, carrying a small transversely mounted spirit level at one extremity and a vernier arm near the other, which terminates in a large milled wheel. On rotating this wheel the spirit level is set at any angle to the line of sight, the angle being measured by the position of the vernier on the graduated arc. The cover of the spirit level has apertures above and below, the latter permitting an image of the bubble to be seen after reflection on the mirror, whilst the former is used when the clinometer is set on the surface whose gradient is required. The arc is graduated in degrees up to 60° on both sides of the vertical, and reads by vernier on the movable arm to 10 minutes. It also has a scale of gradients to 1 in 1, read by the edge of the vernier. The sighting tube is 4 3/8 in. long and the graduated arc has an effective radius of 1 in.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–220.

title: Combined Abney Level and Clinometer, 1882-1887
description: Combined Abney level and clinometer, brass, by S. Henson, 277 Strand, London, England, 1882-1887.
material: brass (copper, zinc alloy); glass; alcohol; paper (fibre product)
object_name: abney level; level; clinometer; abney level; level; clinometer
maker: Abney, Sir William de Wiveleslie; Henson, S.

Maker/Donor: Made by J. Casartelli & Son.
Object entry information: This is a modern Service clinometer for measuring to the nearest minute the angle of elevation of a plane surface. The angle is measured to the nearest degree by a rotating arm which traverses a fixed graduated sector attached to the base. The arm is slightly curved on its upper and lower surfaces, and carries a sliding spirit level whose position, when the bubble is central with respect to the scale graduated on the arm, gives the number of minutes in the angle. There are two flat mutually perpendicular base plates, one painted black and the other red, and the sector of degrees is graduated on both sides, one set numbered in black from o to 44 and the other in red from 50 to 89, for use with the corresponding base. The black base is used for angles below 45° and the red for those above. The radial arm has a radius of 5 in., and is pivoted at the centre of the graduated sector. The other end of the arm has a spring clutch, with a toothed face engaging in the teeth on the face of the sector and locking the arm in any desired position. The scale of minutes on the arm extends through a complete degree and occupies a length of 2 in. The arm is thus curved in a circle of radius about 9.5 ft. There are such scales of minutes on the front face and the rear face of the arm, the former numbered with the zero nearest the pivot and the latter in the reverse direction. The front scale is used with the black base and the rear scale with the red one.

title: Field clinometer, British, 1916
description: Field clinometer Mk III by J. Casartelli & Son, Manchester, England, 1916
material: steel (metal); glass; alcohol; brass (copper, zinc alloy); paint

Maker/Donor: Made and lent by Messrs. Cooke, Troughton & Simms, Ltd.
Object entry information: Instead of a graduated arc, this type of clinometer is provided with a rotatable drum, upon the face of which is a graduated spiral groove, upon which is recorded the amount of elevation of the surface tested. The bubble level is mounted within a gunmetal frame which has two surfaces accurately machined at right angles to each other. One end of the level is pivoted to the frame, and the other end is kept pressed against the base of the drum which rotates upon a threaded screw carried by the frame. As the drum rotates, an index on the scale the resulting elevation of the free end of the level above the pivoted end, and hence, when the bubble is centred, the elevation of the plane upon which the frame is set. No sights are provided with this instrument, which is designed for recording the slope of a plane surface with respect to the vertical or horizontal, according to which of the two plane surfaces of the instrument is in contact with the surface tested. The range of the drum scale is from 40 minutes below to 45° above zero, the first 5° being subdivided by dots to 1 minute; thereafter lines indicate every 5 minutes.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 119.
Object name: INDIAN CLINOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by Messrs. Cooke, Troughton & Simms, Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: In this clinometer, one sight is fixed and the other is movable over a graduated scale engraved upon the vane; the position of the movable sight registers the inclination of the line of sight. The instrument consists of a hollow bubble arm mounted upon a gunmetal base, which has three studs on its lower face. The bubble arm is pivoted at one end to the base, and carries an adjusting screw at its other end for setting the bubble central. A folding sight vane is fitted to each end of the bubble arm, the shorter vane having a fixed aperture backsight and the longer one carrying the sliding foresight. The latter vane has two scales engraved upon it, one of degrees, subdivided to 20 minutes, and the other of tangents. The range of the scale is 0°-23° of elevation or depression.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1925-5.

Object name: AXIS LEVEL.
Maker/Donor: Lent by the Royal Society.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: In large astronomical and surveying instruments, specially long and sensitive levels are generally provided for testing the horizontality of the telescope axis. The levels are usually fitted above the axis by bearing forks, but are sometimes suspended from it by curved brackets. The one exhibited is of the latter type, and was probably made in the early part of the 19th century. It has a bubble tube about 15 in. long by 1 1/4 in. diameter, and an ivory scale mounted on the casing and divided in tenth-inches. The brass casing of the bubble tube has end plates which fit loosely upon screwed vertical pins and can be clamped in any desired position by upper and lower capstan nuts threaded on the pins. The latter project from a horizontal brass tube, somewhat longer than the bubble tube and having the suspension brackets fastened to its ends. The upper portions of these brackets are curved

Maker/Donor: Lent by the Royal Society.
Object entry information: In large astronomical and surveying instruments, specially long and sensitive levels are generally provided for testing the horizontality of the telescope axis. The levels are usually fitted above the axis by bearing forks, but are sometimes suspended from it by curved brackets. The one exhibited is of the latter type, and was probably made in the early part of the 19th century. It has a bubble tube about 15 in. long by 1 1/4 in. diameter, and an ivory scale mounted on the casing and divided in tenth-inches. The brass casing of the bubble tube has end plates which fit loosely upon screwed vertical pins and can be clamped in any desired position by upper and lower capstan nuts threaded on the pins. The latter project from a horizontal brass tube, somewhat longer than the bubble tube and having the suspension brackets fastened to its ends. The upper portions of these brackets are curved and their ends turned over and provided with inverted V-plates which rest on the telescope axis. The scale divisions are numbered symmetrically from the centre. A small transverse spirit level is mounted on one end of the casing of the main level. The vertical pin at one end of the base tube is slightly adjustable by means of capstan nuts.

Object entry information: There are two flat mutually perpendicular base plates, one painted black and the other red, and the sector of degrees is graduated on both sides, one set numbered in black from o to 44 and the other in red from 50 to 89, for use with the corresponding base. The black base is used for angles below 45° and the red for those above. The radial arm has a radius of 5 in., and is pivoted at the centre of the graduated sector. The other end of the arm has a spring clutch, with a toothed face engaging in the teeth on the face of the sector and locking the arm in any desired position. The scale of minutes on the arm extends through a complete degree and occupies a length of 2 in. The arm is thus curved in a circle of radius about 9.5 ft. There are such scales of minutes on the front face and the rear face of the arm, the former numbered with the zero nearest the pivot and the latter in the reverse direction. The front scale is used with the black base and the rear scale with the red one.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922-42.

Catalogue number: 118.
Object name: WATKIN CLINOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by Messrs. Cooke, Troughton & Simms, Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: Instead of a graduated arc, this type of clinometer is provided with a rotatable drum, upon the face of which is a graduated spiral groove, upon which is recorded the amount of elevation of the surface tested. The bubble level is mounted within a gunmetal frame which has two surfaces accurately machined at right angles to each other. One end of the level is pivoted to the frame, and the other end is kept pressed against the base of the drum which rotates upon a threaded screw carried by the frame. As the drum rotates, an index on the scale the resulting elevation of the free end of the level above the pivoted end, and hence, when the bubble is centred, the elevation of the plane upon which the frame is set. No sights are provided with this instrument, which is designed for recording the slope of a plane surface with respect to the vertical or horizontal, according to which of the two plane surfaces of the instrument is in contact with the surface tested. The range of the drum scale is from 40 minutes below to 45° above zero, the first 5° being subdivided by dots to 1 minute; thereafter lines indicate every 5 minutes.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1925-4.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 119.
Object name: INDIAN CLINOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by Messrs. Cooke, Troughton & Simms, Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: In this clinometer, one sight is fixed and the other is movable over a graduated scale engraved upon the vane; the position of the movable sight registers the inclination of the line of sight. The instrument consists of a hollow bubble arm mounted upon a gunmetal base, which has three studs on its lower face. The bubble arm is pivoted at one end to the base, and carries an adjusting screw at its other end for setting the bubble central. A folding sight vane is fitted to each end of the bubble arm, the shorter vane having a fixed aperture backsight and the longer one carrying the sliding foresight. The latter vane has two scales engraved upon it, one of degrees, subdivided to 20 minutes, and the other of tangents. The range of the scale is 0°-23° of elevation or depression.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1925-5.

title: Bubble level for checking the horizontality of telescope axis
description: Bubble level for checking the horizontality of telescope axis, early 19th century

Maker/Donor: Made and lent by T. Cooke & Sons, York.
Object entry information: This exhibit comprises twenty-two bubble tubes of various shapes, sizes and sensitivities, all except two being unmounted. Six are of the circular or “pill-box” type, the upper surface of the container being internally ground spherical, so that the bubble, when centred, occupies the space inside a circle engraved on the glass. Two of this type, which are not very sensitive and are only used for rough levelling, are shown mounted in brass cases, attached to the base-board. The remaining sixteen are tube levels, six of them having their glass containers bent as a whole into a circular shape, and the other ten being straight tubes, internally ground to various curvatures according to the desired sensitivity. The first six are not very sensitive, and are of the type used by carpenters, masons, etc. The other ten are used on surveying instruments, etc., and are usually mounted in brass cases, attached to the instrument by adjustable screws. On the larger levels of this type, division marks are graduated at 0·1 in. interval for reading the positions of the ends of the bubble, and the sensitivity is indicated by the angle of elevation of the level necessary to cause the bubble to move over one division. The most sensitive one exhibited has a sensitivity of 1 division per 5·5 seconds of elevation. This particular bubble tube has also a separate chamber at one end. When the bubble expands owing to increasing temperature, a portion of the air can be detached and transferred to the supplementary chamber through a small aperture in the separating wall, and the bubble thus reduced to its normal size.

Catalogue number: 122.
Object name: LEVELLING ROD.
Maker/Donor: Lent by T. H. Court, Esq.
Date of creation: 18th century
Object entry information: This staff was made in the 18th century and consists of a graduated wooden rod 6 ft. long, 1 in. wide, and in. deep, over which can slide a sighting vane, which has a sharply defined diamond of dark wood inlaid upon a face of light wood, and fits closely to the face of the rod. The vane is moved by the observer signals that it is in line with the telescope, when the former takes the reading of an index mark on the bevelled edge of a small opening in the vane. This method of levelling was superseded about 1835 by the modern one, in which the observer himself reads the staff through the telescope, an improvement rendered possible by the improved telescopes used. The face of the staff is graduated both in inches, divided to tenths, and also in hundredths of a foot along its whole length save the top 3 in. Another rod of slightly smaller section can slide along the back of the first, being retained in position by a metal band which serves as a friction clamp. This second rod is not divided and merely serves as a stand for extending the graduated rod. Both are tipped with brass at their ends. A second vane, similar to the first, is supplied. Each has a circular shape, of diameter 5 in. The inlaid diamond has diagonals 5 in. and 2 in., the longer bisecting the vane horizontally. Pins and a metal spring fixed to the back of the vane keep it in position on the rod.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1917-107.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 123.
Object name: LEVELLING STAFF.
Maker/Donor: Lent by the Ordnance Survey.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is an inextensible wooden staff 10·5 ft. long, having a rectangular section 2 in. wide by 1 in. deep, and is graduated in hundredths of a foot so as to be read through the telescope by the observer himself. The face of the staff is sunk slightly below the edges to preserve the graduations from abrasion. The graduation marks consist of black horizontal bands 0·01 ft. wide at uniform intervals of 0·01 ft. apart. The 0·1-ft. bands stretch right across the staff, the remainder occupying the left portion only, save at the 0·05-ft. points, where there is an additional black mark to the right of the corresponding white band. Large black numbers, horizontally set, mark the feet, the tenths being marked by smaller black numbers set vertically. A diamond is used instead of the number “five” on the latter graduations, and a dot is placed near the “nine” to distinguish it from the “six” when the numbers are seen inverted in the field of the telescope. (15814)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914-422.

title: Levelling staff, 1914
description: Levelling staff, 1914

Maker/Donor: Made and lent by E. R. Watts & Son, Ltd.
Object entry information: This exhibit illustrates the method of engraving wooden and invar rules for their levelling rods now adopted by Messrs. Watts. The portions to be painted black on the white surface of the rule are first gouged out to a sufficient depth and the black filled in nearly flush with the white surface; the black bands are thus rendered very durable. Two of the rules are portions of those used in the ordinary Sopwith type of staff, one showing the graduations cut and the strips gouged out, the other the finished rule, with the strips filled in and figured. The third rule is made of invar, for use in a precise levelling rod, and the bands of black at 0.02-ft. intervals are not so wide as in the other type of rod, where they are exactly 0.01 ft. wide. In the latter case the lower edges of the bands define the odd hundredths of a foot and the upper edges the even hundredths; in the invar rod, only the upper edges are used, the cross wire of the telescope being made to coincide with this edge in taking a reading. The graduations are not figured on the invar strip, but on the surrounding wood of the rod, as in the adjacent exhibit of a portion of the complete rod.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 125
Object name: PORTION OF INVAR PRECISE LEVELLING ROD.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by E. R. Watts & Son, Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The advantages of a metal scale for levelling staves have until recently been counterbalanced by the tendency of such scales to expand when heated, and the difficulty of ascertaining their temperature in order to apply the necessary correction. The invention of “invar”—a nickel-steel alloy of negligible temperature coefficient—has now led to its employment in levelling rods used in precise surveys. The example shown is the lower portion of such a rod. The invar rule is painted white and engraved with black bands at intervals of 0.02 ft., every fifth band extending over the complete width (about 2 cm.) of the rule, and the others over half its width. The rule is then screwed into a central recess in the face of the wooden rod, which has an I section for strength and lightness, and is shod with a metal shoe terminating in a flat base plate; the bottom of the invar rule is flush with this plate. The face of the wooden rod is painted white and numbered opposite the marks corresponding to intervals of 0.1 ft. on the invar rule. The numbers are in black, and are inverted so as to be seen erect in the telescope of the level; a V is used instead of 5 and an N instead of 9. At the divisions of the rule corresponding to an integral number of feet from the base plate, large red numbers are painted on the wood, and are twice repeated in smaller sized numbers on the opposite side of the face so that the observer has always one of the red numbers in the telescope field. In estimating the position of the cross wire with respect to the graduated scale of the rod, the nearest 0.02-ft. mark is taken and the remaining interval found either by elevating or depressing the telescope by a fine-motion screw, or by moving an optical device which causes the image of the rod to be raised or lowered in the telescope field. The position of the cross wire is thus readily found to 0.001 ft.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922-467.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 126
Object name: MOUNTAIN BAROMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by West. Lent by G. J. Symons, F.R.S.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This instrument is a closed cistern mercury barometer of the type common in the late 18th and early 19th centuries; it is specially adapted for portability and thus capable of employment in measuring altitudes. When it is being transported, the mercury can be forced up so as to fill the tube completely by turning an adjusting screw, which depresses the flexible leather base of the cistern. The aperture in the wooden case, used for reading the height of the mercury and the temperature, can also be closed by a rotating brass sheath. The barometer is graduated in inches, and reads by a vernier index, operated by a rack and pinion mechanism, to 0.002 in. A thermometer, provided with Centigrade and Fahrenheit scales, is placed near the top of the instrument. A suspension ring is fixed at the top, and is covered by a ferrule when the instrument is being carried. A screw cap at the bottom likewise serves to enclose the adjusting screw which operates on the cistern. The wooden case which encloses the lower part of the tube is graduated in inches, so that the instrument can serve as a rough measuring rod.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1893-134.

Maker/Donor: Made and lent by E. R. Watts & Son, Ltd.
Object entry information: The advantages of a metal scale for levelling staves have until recently been counterbalanced by the tendency of such scales to expand when heated, and the difficulty of ascertaining their temperature in order to apply the necessary correction. The invention of “invar”—a nickel-steel alloy of negligible temperature coefficient—has now led to its employment in levelling rods used in precise surveys. The example shown is the lower portion of such a rod. The invar rule is painted white and engraved with black bands at intervals of 0.02 ft., every fifth band extending over the complete width (about 2 cm.) of the rule, and the others over half its width. The rule is then screwed into a central recess in the face of the wooden rod, which has an I section for strength and lightness, and is shod with a metal shoe terminating in a flat base plate; the bottom of the invar rule is flush with this plate. The face of the wooden rod is painted white and numbered opposite the marks corresponding to intervals of 0.1 ft. on the invar rule. The numbers are in black, and are inverted so as to be seen erect in the telescope of the level; a V is used instead of 5 and an N instead of 9. At the divisions of the rule corresponding to an integral number of feet from the base plate, large red numbers are painted on the wood, and are twice repeated in smaller sized numbers on the opposite side of the face so that the observer has always one of the red numbers in the telescope field. In estimating the position of the cross wire with respect to the graduated scale of the rod, the nearest 0.02-ft. mark is taken and the remaining interval found either by elevating or depressing the telescope by a fine-motion screw, or by moving an optical device which causes the image of the rod to be raised or lowered in the telescope field. The position of the cross wire is thus readily found to 0.001 ft.
Raw_Response:
Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 124
Object name: GRADUATED RULES FOR LEVELLING RODS.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by E. R. Watts & Son, Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This exhibit illustrates the method of engraving wooden and invar rules for their levelling rods now adopted by Messrs. Watts. The portions to be painted black on the white surface of the rule are first gouged out to a sufficient depth and the black filled in nearly flush with the white surface; the black bands are thus rendered very durable. Two of the rules are portions of those used in the ordinary Sopwith type of staff, one showing the graduations cut and the strips gouged out, the other the finished rule, with the strips filled in and figured. The third rule is made of invar, for use in a precise levelling rod, and the bands of black at 0.02-ft. intervals are not so wide as in the other type of rod, where they are exactly 0.01 ft. wide. In the latter case the lower edges of the bands define the odd hundredths of a foot and the upper edges the even hundredths; in the invar rod, only the upper edges are used, the cross wire of the telescope being made to coincide with this edge in taking a reading. The graduations are not figured on the invar strip, but on the surrounding wood of the rod, as in the adjacent exhibit of a portion of the complete rod.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922-446.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 126
Object name: MOUNTAIN BAROMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by West. Lent by G. J. Symons, F.R.S.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This instrument is a closed cistern mercury barometer of the type common in the late 18th and early 19th centuries; it is specially adapted for portability and thus capable of employment in measuring altitudes. When it is being transported, the mercury can be forced up so as to fill the tube completely by turning an adjusting screw, which depresses the flexible leather base of the cistern. The aperture in the wooden case, used for reading the height of the mercury and the temperature, can also be closed by a rotating brass sheath. The barometer is graduated in inches, and reads by a vernier index, operated by a rack and pinion mechanism, to 0.002 in. A thermometer, provided with Centigrade and Fahrenheit scales, is placed near the top of the instrument. A suspension ring is fixed at the top, and is covered by a ferrule when the instrument is being carried. A screw cap at the bottom likewise serves to enclose the adjusting screw which operates on the cistern. The wooden case which encloses the lower part of the tube is graduated in inches, so that the instrument can serve as a rough measuring rod.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1893-134.

title: Mountain barometer, 1845-1855
description: Mountain barometer, unsigned, 1845-1855
material: brass (copper, zinc alloy); glass; mahogany (wood); cotton thread

Maker/Donor: Made by Dollond. Lent by G. J. Symons, F.R.S.
Object entry information: This resembles the adjacent instrument, made by West, in its general character- istics of compactness and portability, but differs in the arrangement of the cistern. This is of the usual flexible base type, but has a supplementary syphon tube, connected to the cistern by a narrow neck, which can be closed by means of a cock. When the instrument is being used, the cock is opened, and the mercury allowed to attain a fixed height in the syphon tube. This is the zero of the barometer tube scale. For transporting the barometer, the mercury is withdrawn from the syphon tube and the cock closed, after which the flexible base of the cistern is de- pressed by means of the adjusting screw until the mercury completely fills the barometer tube. The barometer tube is graduated in inches, and read to 0·002 in. by a vernier attached to the movable index. A thermometer with Centigrade and Fahrenheit scales is fixed near the top. The window for reading this and the barometer can be closed by means of a rotating brass shutter, and a similar shutter at the bottom of the instrument serves to protect the cistern and syphon tube when required.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 128
Object name: MOUNTAIN BAROMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Troughton & Simms.
Date of creation: constructed probably about 1840
Object entry information: The Gay-Lussac syphon-tube mercury barometer, in which both the long and short tubes are closed completely at the end, but a small aperture in the side of the short tube permits the air to enter whilst preventing the mercury escaping, was essentially a portable instrument, and was, therefore, often used for measuring altitudes prior to the invention of the aneroid. The instrument exhibited is of this type, and was constructed probably about 1840. The barometer tube is enclosed in a brass case, at the ends of which are cork cushions. Scales graduated directly to 0·02 in. and read by movable verniers to 0·001 in. are engraved upon the case opposite the ends of the mercury. Each vernier has an index which can be set level with the top of the mercury column. The difference between the two readings then gives the height of the barometer. A thermometer, with Centigrade and Fahrenheit graduations, is fixed near the centre of the tube. This instrument is attached by brackets to a wooden stand, and can be set accurately vertical by means of three screws threaded in the lower bracket with their ends pressing against the case of the barometer. For mountain barometers a tripod stand was usually provided.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1907-65.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 129
Object name: ANEROID BAROMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by W. F. Stanley.
Date of creation: made about 1890
Object entry information: This instrument was made about 1890, for the use of surveyors in measuring altitudes up to 4,000 ft. The zero mark of the altitude scale corresponds to a height of 32 in. in the mercury barometer. The altitude scale has a diam. of 3·5 in., and is graduated every 10 ft., single feet being estimated. The movable glass cover carries an index mark, which is set to the last height read, and a small lens for facilitating reading. The altitude scale is slightly raised on a step so that its inside graduated edge is flush with an aluminium plate fixed to the tip of the hand and provided with a mark. By this arrangement errors due to parallax are avoided. The instrument is compensated for temperature variations.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1893-119.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 130
Object name: WATKIN ANEROID BAROMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by J. Hicks.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: In aneroid barometers many attempts have been made to provide scales suitable for a very extended range of altitudes. This instrument shows the three concentric circular scale arrangement devised by Major H. S. S. Watkin, by which altitudes from zero to 10,860 ft. can be measured. The zero graduation corresponds to a height of 31 in. in the mercury barometer. Altitudes from zero to 3,440 ft. are marked at 20 ft. intervals on the outermost scale, which has a diameter of 3·6 in. The middle scale, of diam. 2·9 in., records altitudes from 3,440 ft. to 6,860 ft., whilst the innermost scale, of diam. 2·2 in., completes the range to 10,860 ft., every 20 ft. being marked on each scale. The corresponding mercury barometer scales are marked at 0·02 in. intervals from 31 in. to 20 in. To show which scale should be used, an indicator exhibits the number 1, 2 or 3, corresponding to the outer, middle and inner scales respectively. The number indicated is marked upon a plate worked by (E5814) C 2
Object/Inventory number: (E5814)

The middle scale, of diam. 2·9 in., records altitudes from 3,440 ft. to 6,860 ft., whilst the innermost scale, of diam. 2·2 in., completes the range to 10,860 ft., every 20 ft. being marked on each scale. The corresponding mercury barometer scales are marked at 0·02 in. intervals from 31 in. to 20 in. To show which scale should be used, an indicator exhibits the number 1, 2 or 3, corresponding to the outer, middle and inner scales respectively. The number indicated is marked upon a plate worked by the mechanism, and is automatically altered when the barometer hand reaches the end of the scale concerned. The breaks in the circles are indicated by black bars. The revolving glass cover carries an index hand, which can be set to the last reading taken. The instrument is compensated for temperature variations. (See British Patent Specification, No. 14730, of 1886.)
