Catalogue number: 127
Object name: MOUNTAIN BAROMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Dollond. Lent by G. J. Symons, F.R.S.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This resembles the adjacent instrument, made by West, in its general character- istics of compactness and portability, but differs in the arrangement of the cistern. This is of the usual flexible base type, but has a supplementary syphon tube, connected to the cistern by a narrow neck, which can be closed by means of a cock. When the instrument is being used, the cock is opened, and the mercury allowed to attain a fixed height in the syphon tube. This is the zero of the barometer tube scale. For transporting the barometer, the mercury is withdrawn from the syphon tube and the cock closed, after which the flexible base of the cistern is de- pressed by means of the adjusting screw until the mercury completely fills the barometer tube. The barometer tube is graduated in inches, and read to 0·002 in. by a vernier attached to the movable index. A thermometer with Centigrade and Fahrenheit scales is fixed near the top. The window for reading this and the barometer can be closed by means of a rotating brass shutter, and a similar shutter at the bottom of the instrument serves to protect the cistern and syphon tube when required.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1893-133

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 128
Object name: MOUNTAIN BAROMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Troughton & Simms.
Date of creation: constructed probably about 1840
Object entry information: The Gay-Lussac syphon-tube mercury barometer, in which both the long and short tubes are closed completely at the end, but a small aperture in the side of the short tube permits the air to enter whilst preventing the mercury escaping, was essentially a portable instrument, and was, therefore, often used for measuring altitudes prior to the invention of the aneroid. The instrument exhibited is of this type, and was constructed probably about 1840. The barometer tube is enclosed in a brass case, at the ends of which are cork cushions. Scales graduated directly to 0·02 in. and read by movable verniers to 0·001 in. are engraved upon the case opposite the ends of the mercury. Each vernier has an index which can be set level with the top of the mercury column. The difference between the two readings then gives the height of the barometer. A thermometer, with Centigrade and Fahrenheit graduations, is fixed near the centre of the tube. This instrument is attached by brackets to a wooden stand, and can be set accurately vertical by means of three screws threaded in the lower bracket with their ends pressing against the case of the barometer. For mountain barometers a tripod stand was usually provided.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1907-65.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 129
Object name: ANEROID BAROMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by W. F. Stanley.
Date of creation: made about 1890
Object entry information: This instrument was made about 1890, for the use of surveyors in measuring altitudes up to 4,000 ft. The zero mark of the altitude scale corresponds to a height of 32 in. in the mercury barometer. The altitude scale has a diam. of 3·5 in., and is graduated every 10 ft., single feet being estimated. The movable glass cover carries an index mark, which is set to the last height read, and a small lens for facilitating reading. The altitude scale is slightly raised on a step so that its inside graduated edge is flush with an aluminium plate fixed to the tip of the hand and provided with a mark. By this arrangement errors due to parallax are avoided. The instrument is compensated for temperature variations.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1893-119.

title: Watkin aneroid barometer
description: Watkin aneroid barometer, patented 1886, by J. Hicks

Maker/Donor: Made by Francis J. Hyde Wollaston. Presented by the Rev. T. P. W. Worswick.
Object entry information: A new “thermometrical barometer” of the type here exhibited was invented by Wollaston and described by him before the Royal Society in 1817. The one exhibited was made before 1821. It is essentially a very sensitive “boiling-point” thermometer, whereby the temperature at which water boils may be found to within a thousandth of a degree Fahrenheit, and the altitude of the place determined accordingly. The bulb of the thermometer is spherical and has a diameter of about an inch. The tube has a length of 30 in. and a very fine bore, so that one degree Fahrenheit corresponds to a movement of the mercury in the tube of 4 in. This is measured by means of a brass scale fixed on the face of the rod which supports the tube. The scale is graduated to read 0·02° F. directly, and 0·002° F. by means of a movable vernier. The rod carries a double walled tin cylinder surrounding the bulb of the thermometer. The cylinder can be detached and partly filled with water, which is then boiled by means of a spirit lamp so that the steam surrounds the bulb of the thermometer. Along the side of the rod is attached a strip of paper on which is marked a scale of corrections to be applied to the temperature scale, owing probably to inequalities in the diameter of the bore of the tube. (See Phil. Trans., 1817, No. XIII and 1820.)

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 132
Object name: HYPSOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by L. Casella.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: Although not so accurate as a standard barometer, a hypsometer for determining altitudes by means of the boiling point of water is more convenient for rapid surveys in mountainous districts. The example shown is of the “pocket” type much used by Alpine travellers. Its thermometer is graduated from 180° to 215° F. by 0·02°. The apparatus consists of a brass water container and steam jacket, in which the thermometer is suspended and which is fixed above a small spirit lamp for boiling the water. A brass case surrounds the lamp, which is further screened from wind by means of a black japanned tin box, provided with air holes covered by wire gauze. The thermometer is suspended with its bulb inside an inner tube connected to the boiler. An outer telescopic tube surrounds this and serves to support the thermometer in addition to forming a steam jacket enclosing the mercury as much as possible. The steam escapes by a hole in the top of this outer tube. In improved hypsometers it is made to retrace its path downwards and escape at the bottom of the steam jacket. With this apparatus altitudes are determined by means of specially prepared tables provided with the instrument, giving the heights above sea level corresponding to a particular temperature at which water boils, and also corrections to be made for latitude, mean temperature of the air, and decrease of gravity with increase of elevation.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1893-149.
title: "Mountain barometer" (a hypsometer)
description: "Mountain barometer" (a hypsometer), invented and made by F.J.H. Wollaston, c. 1820

Object name: PHOTOGRAPHS OF A CARVING OF A GROMA. Taken by the Municipal Museum, Ivrea, N. Italy.
Object entry information: Upon the tombstone of a Roman "Mensor," L. Aebutius Faustus, who lived about 100 A.D., is carved a crude representation of the "groma," or surveyor's cross, used by Roman surveyors to set out right angles. The photograph exhibited was taken from this tombstone, which is preserved in the Municipal Museum at Ivrea, North Italy. The carving is a somewhat conventionalized perspective sketch, showing the two crossed arms of the "stella," with only two "pondera" (weights) instead of the four usually suspended, one from each end of the "stella." The addition of the "ferramentum," or staff, to support the "stella" is also depicted, passing through the intersection of the two arms of the latter. In using such a groma, it would be set up so that one plummet hung over the station point, and one of the adjacent plummets lay in the direction from which the right angle was to be set off; a sight through the other adjacent plummet would then be taken from the station plummet. (See Schöne, "Das Visirinstrument der römischen Feldmesser," Jahrb. d. Deutsch. Archäolog. Instituts, XVI, 1901, pp. 127–132.)

Catalogue number: 134.
Object name: DRAWING OF A RESTORATION OF A SMALL GROMA.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A (Reconstruction based on find near Eichstätt, Bavaria)
Object entry information: Another example of the Roman groma, found near Eichstätt, Bavaria, has served as basis for Professor Schöne's reconstruction illustrated in this drawing. The groma discovered consisted of an iron "stella" mounted upon a "ferramentum," also of iron. The ends of the arms of the stella are bent and transfixed by iron bolts, which served to attach a square wooden frame—since perished—to the "stella," and to carry the plumb lines. The length of each side of the wooden framework was 35 cm., and the height of the "ferramentum," exclusive of the upper and lower axis pins, is 35·5 cm. This instrument was, therefore, a small type of groma, and was probably mounted upon a wooden tripod, as shown in the drawing, so that the "stella" was at approximately the height of a man from the ground. (See Schöne, "Das Visirinstrument der römischen Feldmesser," Jahrb. d. Deutsch. Archäolog. Instituts, XVI, 1901, pp. 127–132.) (15814) C 4
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923-493.

Object name: REPRODUCTION OF A ROMAN GROMA. Made in the Museum. Plate III, Fig. 1, p. 56.
Maker/Donor: Made in the Museum
Object entry information: During excavations in the Via Abbonanza at Pompeii, in 1912, under the direction of Cav. M. Della Corte, fragments of a Roman groma were discovered. These fragments were sufficiently preserved and complete to enable Dr. Della Corte to reconstruct the original instrument with a certainty not hitherto attained owing to the meagre data available. The instrument exhibited has been constructed in accordance with the measurements and drawings supplied by Dr. Della Corte. As previously reconstructed, the groma consisted of a cross, composed of two equal perpendicular arms intersecting at their centres, mounted upon a supporting staff (ferramentum), upon which the cross could revolve in azimuth: from the ends of the cross were suspended four plummets, through which sights were taken by the surveyor. This reconstruction comprises all the foregoing portions, with the additional modification that the cross is not supported directly upon the staff, but is pivoted upon the outer end of a curved bracket, which is in turn mounted rotatably upon the head of the staff. This arrangement enables the centre of the cross to be set above the mark on a boundary stone, whilst the staff is driven into the ground beside the stone; also, sights could be taken through opposite, not adjacent, plumb lines without interference from the staff. The wooden staff, which is nearly 2 metres long, terminates at its lower end in a fluted iron shoe, and is encircled at its upper extremity by a brass collar, along its upper and lower faces by curved brass strips, and terminating at the staff end in a brass collar and at the cross end in a brass pivot upon which the curved bracket is mounted. The horizontal distance between the cross and bracket pivot centres is 23.4 cm. The cross has a brass centre, and four tapered wooden arms, completely enclosed in thin iron sheeting and reinforced at their intersection by brass angle brackets. The bronze plummets are suspended through holes in the arms at distances of 45 cm. from the centre of the cross. Each plummet resembles its opposite in size and shape but differs from the neighbouring ones. The actual portions discovered included all the metal parts, with a few traces of wood fibres embedded therein. The total height of the instrument is alone considered problematical. (See M. Della Corte's article "Groma," in Monumenti Antichi, Accademia dei Lincei, Vol. XXVIII, 1922.)

Object name: CROSS STAFF.
Maker/Donor: Made by Baldantoni, Ancona.
Date of creation: towards the end of the 17th century
Object entry information: This instrument consists of a hollow brass sphere of 2½ in. diam., with vertical great circle sighting slits cut every 45° in its surface. It is used like the ordinary sight-rule cross staff for setting off angles of any multiple of 45°, and was probably made towards the end of the 17th century. A socket fixed to the sphere serves to connect it to a stand.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1889-22.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 137
Object name: CROSS STAFF.
Maker/Donor: Made by Dollond.
Date of creation: late 18th or early 19th century.
Object entry information: This instrument, which was made in the late 18th or early 19th century, has two 6-in. brass sight rules fixed accurately at right angles to each other and a central screw thread for attaching it to a stand. Backsights and foresights can be taken through either rule, every vertical arm having both a slit backsight and a wire foresight. This type of instrument is mostly used in detail chain and offset surveying, for setting the offset rod at right angles to the chain.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-81.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 138
Object name: OPTICAL SQUARE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by T. H. Court, Esq.
Date of creation: probably near the end of the 18th century.
Object entry information: This instrument, made probably near the end of the 18th century, has two mirrors fixed to the base of a cylindrical brass box, with their planes at an angle of 45° to each other. One mirror is half unsilvered for direct vision, the other half and the whole of the second mirror being silvered, to reflect rays from objects at right angles to the line of vision. A circular aperture and rectangular windows are pierced in the side of the box opposite the mirrors.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1917-22.

Catalogue number: 135
Object name: REPRODUCTION OF A ROMAN GROMA. Made in the Museum. Plate III, Fig. 1, p. 56.
Maker/Donor: Made in the Museum
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: During excavations in the Via Abbonanza at Pompeii, in 1912, under the direction of Cav. M. Della Corte, fragments of a Roman groma were discovered. These fragments were sufficiently preserved and complete to enable Dr. Della Corte to reconstruct the original instrument with a certainty not hitherto attained owing to the meagre data available. The instrument exhibited has been constructed in accordance with the measurements and drawings supplied by Dr. Della Corte. As previously reconstructed, the groma consisted of a cross, composed of two equal perpendicular arms intersecting at their centres, mounted upon a supporting staff (ferramentum), upon which the cross could revolve in azimuth: from the ends of the cross were suspended four plummets, through which sights were taken by the surveyor. This reconstruction comprises all the foregoing portions, with the additional modification that the cross is not supported directly upon the staff, but is pivoted upon the outer end of a curved bracket, which is in turn mounted rotatably upon the head of the staff. This arrangement enables the centre of the cross to be set above the mark on a boundary stone, whilst the staff is driven into the ground beside the stone; also, sights could be taken through opposite, not adjacent, plumb lines without interference from the staff. The wooden staff, which is nearly 2 metres long, terminates at its lower end in a fluted iron shoe, and is encircled at its upper extremity by a brass collar, along its upper and lower faces by curved brass strips, and terminating at the staff end in a brass collar and at the cross end in a brass pivot upon which the curved bracket is mounted. The horizontal distance between the cross and bracket pivot centres is 23.4 cm. The cross has a brass centre, and four tapered wooden arms, completely enclosed in thin iron sheeting and reinforced at their intersection by brass angle brackets. The bronze plummets are suspended through holes in the arms at distances of 45 cm. from the centre of the cross. Each plummet resembles its opposite in size and shape but differs from the neighbouring ones. The actual portions discovered included all the metal parts, with a few traces of wood fibres embedded therein. The total height of the instrument is alone considered problematical. (See M. Della Corte's article "Groma," in Monumenti Antichi, Accademia dei Lincei, Vol. XXVIII, 1922.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923-395. S.M. 1828.

title: Optical square, British, 1851-1917
description: Optical square, unsigned, European, 1851-1917

Maker/Donor: Made by Adie, London. Presented by T. H. Court, Esq.
Object entry information: In this instrument, made in the middle of the 19th century, two right-angled reflecting prisms are mounted one upon the other, with their reflecting faces perpendicular. In using the instrument the observer takes off the cap and screws it beneath the base to serve as a handgrip. Looking at the common face of the two prisms, he views objects on his left hand through the lower prism, and those on his right through the upper. Two objects which appear in the same vertical line will be at opposite ends of a line through the instrument, perpendicular to the direction of sight.

Object entry information: In this instrument, made probably towards the end of the 18th century, three pairs of mirrors are mounted successively in a rectangular brass box, whose sides are provided with the necessary windows. The three pairs of mirrors make angles of 22½°, 90° and 45° respectively with each other, and one mirror of each pair is left partly unsilvered for direct vision. The direct and reflected rays for each pair are thus inclined at 45°, 180° and 90° respectively.

Catalogue number: 141.
Object name: OPTICAL OPPOSITE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by the Admiralty.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: By means of this instrument an observer can place himself in the direct line between two objects. It consists of two mirrors set in small parallel sighting tubes connected by a longer perpendicular tube. The planes of the mirrors are perpendicular and one mirror is partly unsilvered. The observer views the front object directly through the unsilvered portion and the rear object by double reflection at the two silvered surfaces. When the images coincide, he is in the direct line between the two objects. The sighting tubes are closed by glass windows where necessary.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876-1208.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 142.
Object name: TELESCOPIC PLANE TABLE ALIDADE.
Maker/Donor: Made by A. Baldantoni, Ancona.
Date of creation: late 17th century
Object entry information: The application of the telescope and vertical arc to the alidade of a plane table took place about the same time as the corresponding addition to the theodolite. In this exhibit, made in the late 17th century, a vertical pillar fixed perpendicularly to the alidade carries the vertical semicircle and attached telescope, which can rotate about a horizontal axis in the top of the pillar. A vernier fixed to the pillar records the altitude angle of the line of sight. The alidade is 2 ft. 4 in. long by 1½ in. wide and has one edge bevelled. Over this edge, at the two extremities of the rule, are attached two plain sights, a slit backsight and a vertical wire foresight. A few inches in front of the backsight is the vertical pillar carrying the telescope axis. By means of its milled edge and a wormwheel, the socket of this pillar can be slightly rotated in azimuth, and carries the telescope with it. This serves to adjust the line of sight parallel to the bevelled edge of the rule. The semicircle has a diameter of 5 in. and is graduated in degrees up to 50° of elevation or depression. Its edge is milled and gears with a wormwheel attached to the pillar. The telescope rests in semicircular collars fixed to the diameter of the semi-circle, and is kept in place by hinged straps and screws. It has a rack-focussing objective lens of ¾ in. aperture and a fixed eyepiece tube containing a compound field lens and eyepiece with a fixed cross wire diaphragm between the two lenses of the eyepiece. A spirit level is mounted upon the telescope parallel to its axis. The vernier attached to the pillar is slightly adjustable by means of a slide and lever, and reads the vertical arc to 3 minutes.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1889-21.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 143.
Object name: PLANE TABLE AND ALIDADE.
Maker/Donor: Made by W. & S. Jones. Lent by T. H. Court, Esq.
Date of creation: early 19th century
Object entry information: This is an early 19th century outfit comprising plane table, tripod and brass alidade. The table, which is 17 in. by 15 in. can be rotated and levelled independently of the tripod. The alidade is nearly 2 ft. long and has a detachable combined back and foresight at each extremity, the slits and wires being vertically above the bevelled edge of the ruler.

Over this edge, at the two extremities of the rule, are attached two plain sights, a slit backsight and a vertical wire foresight. A few inches in front of the backsight is the vertical pillar carrying the telescope axis. By means of its milled edge and a wormwheel, the socket of this pillar can be slightly rotated in azimuth, and carries the telescope with it. This serves to adjust the line of sight parallel to the bevelled edge of the rule. The semicircle has a diameter of 5 in. and is graduated in degrees up to 50° of elevation or depression. Its edge is milled and gears with a wormwheel attached to the pillar. The telescope rests in semicircular collars fixed to the diameter of the semi-circle, and is kept in place by hinged straps and screws. It has a rack-focussing objective lens of ¾ in. aperture and a fixed eyepiece tube containing a compound field lens and eyepiece with a fixed cross wire diaphragm between the two lenses of the eyepiece. A spirit level is mounted upon the telescope parallel to its axis. The vernier attached to the pillar is slightly adjustable by means of a slide and lever, and reads the vertical arc to 3 minutes.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1889-21.

Catalogue number: 140.
Object name: OPTICAL OPPOSITE AND SQUARE.
Maker/Donor: Made by Beaulieu, Brussels. Presented by T. H. Court, Esq.
Date of creation: probably towards the end of the 18th century
Object entry information: In this instrument, made probably towards the end of the 18th century, three pairs of mirrors are mounted successively in a rectangular brass box, whose sides are provided with the necessary windows. The three pairs of mirrors make angles of 22½°, 90° and 45° respectively with each other, and one mirror of each pair is left partly unsilvered for direct vision. The direct and reflected rays for each pair are thus inclined at 45°, 180° and 90° respectively.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911-154.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 141.
Object name: OPTICAL OPPOSITE.
Maker/Donor: Presented by the Admiralty.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: By means of this instrument an observer can place himself in the direct line between two objects. It consists of two mirrors set in small parallel sighting tubes connected by a longer perpendicular tube. The planes of the mirrors are perpendicular and one mirror is partly unsilvered. The observer views the front object directly through the unsilvered portion and the rear object by double reflection at the two silvered surfaces. When the images coincide, he is in the direct line between the two objects. The sighting tubes are closed by glass windows where necessary.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876-1208.

title: Telescopic alidade, Italian, 1690-1710
description: Telescopic plane table alidade with bubble tube by A. Baldantoni, Ancona, Italy, 1690-1710.

Maker/Donor: Made by W. & S. Jones. Lent by T. H. Court, Esq.
Object entry information: This is an early 19th century outfit comprising plane table, tripod and brass alidade. The table, which is 17 in. by 15 in. can be rotated and levelled independently of the tripod. The alidade is nearly 2 ft. long and has a detachable combined back and foresight at each extremity, the slits and wires being vertically above the bevelled edge of the ruler. Various useful scales of length are engraved upon the alidade, and the rectangular boxwood frame forming the edge of the table is graduated on both faces in half degrees and tenth-inches. This frame is detachable and serves to clamp the paper to the table. Three centres corresponding to the half-degree graduations are marked on the table proper, by which means it can be used also as a theodolite. There is a dovetailed recess beneath the table for supporting a compass box (missing in the instrument exhibited) to orient the instrument, and a small spirit level is used to level the table. The brass piece connecting the table to the tripod has a conical axis and socket, and a spherical ball and socket joint for orienting and levelling the table independently of the tripod. The latter has a brass tripod head and circular tapering legs, 4 ft. long, jointed in the middle, and fitted with brass shoes at the extremities.

Maker/Donor: Made by T. Cooke & Sons.
Object entry information: This is a small outfit of modern construction suitable for rough reconnaissance and engineering surveys. The table is 17 in. by 14 in. and has its under edges removable for inserting and clamping the drawing paper. The boxwood ruler is 12 in. long and has folding metal sights at each extremity. The back of the table has a brass plate, recessed to receive the knob of the bolt clamping it to the tripod. A small circular spirit level is used to level the table, the slope of the tripod legs being changed to effect this. A small trough compass with a 3-in. needle is provided for orienting the table. The bevelled edges of the alidade are divided in scales of 6 and 8 inches to the mile, to read 10 yd. on each scale. The sights consist of a slit backsight and strip foresight, each vertically above the centre line of the alidade.

Catalogue number: 145.
Object name: JOHNSON PLANE TABLE OUTFIT.
Maker/Donor: Made by W. & L. E. Gurley.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: A type of modern plane table outfit with telescopic alidade, suitable for topographical surveys of a comparatively high degree of precision, is here exhibited. Similar outfits have been extensively employed by the topographers of the U.S. Geological Survey. The table is 30 in. by 24 in., and is carefully made in sections to preserve its shape. Brass screw pins fitting into sockets at the corners and middle of the sides are used for fastening the drawing paper to the table, which is slightly recessed at these points to allow the heads of the pins to be flush with the upper surface of the board and thus permit the alidade to slide freely over the pins. The board is connected to the tripod by means of a Johnson quick-levelling socket, which permits it to be easily levelled and rotated in azimuth independently of the tripod. Two butterfly nuts control these movements of levelling and rotation, and, when tightened, clamp the table rigidly to the tripod. This latter has three split legs, 4 ft. long, attached by bolts to the metal tripod head and terminating in metal shoes. Any point on the sketch can be set vertically above the corresponding station point, after the instrument is levelled, by means of the wooden plumbing arm which consists of two pieces so jointed and marked at the joint that, when the upper piece is set flat on the table, with its point over the point on the sketch, and the joint clamped with its two marks coincident, the metal hook at the end of the second arm lies vertically beneath the point. The plumb-bob is suspended from this hook and the table moved until it lies over the station point. A flat 4-in. square metal plate, upon which are mounted two mutually perpendicular spirit levels and a central compass box with a 3-in. needle and ring divided in degrees, is used for levelling and orienting the table. The alidade consists of a flat brass ruler 20 in. long by 4 in. wide, having one edge bevelled and a central pillar projecting vertically from its upper face and supporting the telescope and attached vertical circle, and the fixed vernier for reading this latter. The vertical circle has a diameter of 4.5 in., and is divided on silver to half degrees, read by the vernier to single minutes. It is fixed with the telescope to the horizontal axis, which can rotate within a socket fixed to the vertical pillar. A tangent clamp and slow motion screw is fitted to this axis and connected to the vernier. The telescope is of the pattern usually fixed to 5-in. transit theodolites. It has a rack-focussing objective lens of 1.2 in. aperture and 8 in. focal length, and a rack-focussing eyepiece magnifying 20 diameters. The fixed diaphragm has two horizontal stadia wires as well as the usual cross wires.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914-742.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 146.
Object name: JÄHNS'S POLYMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Schmidt & Hansch, Berlin.
Date of creation: 1873
Object entry information: The “Vielmesser” or Polymeter, invented by R. Jähns in 1873, is an early example of a plane table alidade adapted to measure the distance, altitude, and azimuth of a point simultaneously. It is mounted upon a horizontal plane table, and used in conjunction with a tacheometric staff of constant interval, set vertically at the distant station.
The alidade consists of a T-shaped base piece, mounted on three levelling screws and provided with two spirit levels. A vertical arm projecting from the base piece carries two metal rulers, which can be rotated independently about a common horizontal axis in the vertical arm by means of quick and slow motion screws. The axis is perpendicular to the longer arm of the base piece, and there is a marking pin attached to the latter vertically beneath the base, so that the alidade can be centred above the observing station point on the plan and rotated as a whole about this point. After this has been done, the inner edges of the two rulers are directed upon the upper and lower reference marks on the distant staff by means of a telescope fixed to the upper ruler. A vertical slide, which carries a distance piece and corresponding wooden scales, is then moved along the alidade until the distance piece—which can move up and down on the slide—fits accurately between the two rulers. There is a lever multiplying device to enable this adjustment to be made with extreme precision, and the final motion of the slide is performed with a slow motion screw. The marking pin attached to the slide vertically beneath the distance piece is now depressed, and the point so defined will correspond to the horizontal projection of the distant staff, both as regards azimuth and distance. The position of the distance piece on the wooden scale on the vertical slide gives the altitude of the staff. The scale of representation in each case is the ratio of the width of the distance piece to the staff interval. Five separate distance pieces are provided, with the corresponding wooden scales, so that a suitable scale of representation can be chosen.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1200.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 147.
Object name: PRISMATIC ALIDADE.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by C. F. Casella & Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: In this alidade devised by the Rev. A. J. Potter for use with a plane table, the usual folding sights are replaced by a single right-angled prism which is mounted at one end of the ruler, with its reflecting base vertical and parallel to the edge of the latter. Any distant object can be viewed directly above the prism, whilst an image of the object can be seen through the prism after refraction on each face and reflection on the base. When the two images thus seen are made to coincide, the edge of the ruler must point at the distant object, and the direction line of the latter can be plotted.
The reflected image is inverted left for right compared with the direct image and is displaced laterally if the ruler is not sighted correctly so that coincidence is readily effected by adjusting the ruler.
The advantage of this type of alidade lies in the rigidity of the sights, absence of illumination, and the increased accuracy of alignment rendered possible by the fact that, for a given angular displacement of the ruler, the displacement of the reflected image is double that of the ruler.
The ruler is 15 in. long, and has its bevelled edge graduated in inches and tenths. A circular bubble level is mounted upon it near the prism.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924–466.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 148.
Object name: EARLY COMPASS.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: 17th century
Object entry information: This consists of a square brass plate with an engraved circle graduated in degrees over which moves an index arm carrying a small compass box. It dates from the 17th century and was probably used for plotting the bearings of objects taken with a circumferentor.
The side of the square plate is 3 in. long, as is also the diameter of the graduated circle. The compass box has a diameter of nearly 1 in. The N.-S. and E.-W. lines are engraved upon the base of the compass. When the needle is set over the N.-S. line, and the index arm which is always parallel to this line is set upon the graduation corresponding to the bearings, two sides of the square plate will be in the proper direction for plotting this bearing. The circle is divided into four quadrants and each quadrant is graduated from 0° to 90°, all the graduations beginning on the same line parallel to two sides of the plate.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1880–198.

Catalogue number: 146.
Object name: JÄHNS'S POLYMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Schmidt & Hansch, Berlin.
Date of creation: 1873
Object entry information: The “Vielmesser” or Polymeter, invented by R. Jähns in 1873, is an early example of a plane table alidade adapted to measure the distance, altitude, and azimuth of a point simultaneously. It is mounted upon a horizontal plane table, and used in conjunction with a tacheometric staff of constant interval, set vertically at the distant station.
The alidade consists of a T-shaped base piece, mounted on three levelling screws and provided with two spirit levels. A vertical arm projecting from the base piece carries two metal rulers, which can be rotated independently about a common horizontal axis in the vertical arm by means of quick and slow motion screws. The axis is perpendicular to the longer arm of the base piece, and there is a marking pin attached to the latter vertically beneath the base, so that the alidade can be centred above the observing station point on the plan and rotated as a whole about this point. After this has been done, the inner edges of the two rulers are directed upon the upper and lower reference marks on the distant staff by means of a telescope fixed to the upper ruler. A vertical slide, which carries a distance piece and corresponding wooden scales, is then moved along the alidade until the distance piece—which can move up and down on the slide—fits accurately between the two rulers. There is a lever multiplying device to enable this adjustment to be made with extreme precision, and the final motion of the slide is performed with a slow motion screw. The marking pin attached to the slide vertically beneath the distance piece is now depressed, and the point so defined will correspond to the horizontal projection of the distant staff, both as regards azimuth and distance. The position of the distance piece on the wooden scale on the vertical slide gives the altitude of the staff. The scale of representation in each case is the ratio of the width of the distance piece to the staff interval. Five separate distance pieces are provided, with the corresponding wooden scales, so that a suitable scale of representation can be chosen.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1200.

title: Magnetic compass, Italian, 1601-1700
description: Compass and pointer set in square plate, Italian, 1601-1700

Maker/Donor: Made by Dollond. Presented by T. H. Court, Esq.
Object entry information: This instrument, made by Dollond about 1770, is typical of the surveyor's compass previous to the invention of Kater's mirror compass or Schmalkalder's prismatic compass. Here the position of the needle upon the graduated compass ring, which is fixed, cannot be read at the same time as the object is viewed through the sights. Consequently it is necessary to use a stand to support the compass, and a socket is attached to the base of the wooden case for this purpose. The fixed compass ring is graduated in degrees continuously from 0° to 360° in a counter-clockwise direction. The slit backsight and wire foresight are fixed to the compass box at the 0° and 180° respectively. When the object is sighted, the reading of the S. end of the needle upon the graduated ring gives the correct magnetic bearing. The compass ring is 4¼ in. diameter, and the sights are 6¼ in. apart. These latter can be folded down upon the face of the compass for transport, and a recess is provided in the lid of the wooden case for their reception. This lid, on being closed, depresses a pin which lifts the needle from its pivot and clamps it against the glass cover.

Object name: AZIMUTH COMPASS
Maker/Donor: Made by Dollond. Presented by T. H. Court, Esq.
Date of creation: about 1770

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 150
Object name: AZIMUTH COMPASS
Maker/Donor: Made by Adams.
Date of creation: about the end of the 18th century
Object entry information: This compass, probably made about the end of the 18th century, differs only in minor details from the adjacent one made by Dollond. It has a 3½ in. compass ring graduated in degrees, mounted in a brass case to which sights can be fitted, and which has a threaded socket for attaching the instrument to a stand when taking bearings. The graduations are numbered every 10° in quadrants, with the 0° at the N. and S. points. Opposite these points are sliding sockets in the outer case. The two sights, each having a slit and a wire for use as backsight and foresight respectively, are mounted in these sockets when in use, or fitted within the lid of the compass case for transport. The sights are 3 in. long. The compass needle is provided with a lifting lever actuated by a pin which is depressed when the lid is fitted on the case, but has no clamping arrangement.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1909–140.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 151
Object name: MIRROR AZIMUTH COMPASS
Maker/Donor: Made by Thos. Jones. Lent by W. Shackleton, Esq., F.R.A.S.
Date of creation: beginning of the 19th century
Object entry information: The mirror attachment to the eye lens here shown was invented by Capt. Kater at the beginning of the 19th century, and enables the observer to view the graduations of the horizontal compass ring at the same time as he takes a sight. The compass ring is fixed to the rotating needle and is so graduated in half-degrees consecutively from 0° to 360° that correct bearings are read off immediately. The diameter of the compass card is 4½ in. The usual slit backsight and wire foresight are fixed to the compass box at a distance apart of 5 in. A small pin fixed in the case vertically beneath the backsight serves as fiducial mark, and its position on the graduated scale is seen through the mirror very clearly when the instrument is held about one foot away from the eye. The foresight can be folded down upon the top of the case, and the compass card and needle are thereby automatically lifted from the pivot and clamped.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1916–6. S.M. 962. L.S.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 152
Object name: PRISMATIC COMPASS
Maker/Donor: Made by Schmalkalder.
Date of creation: early part of the 19th century
Object entry information: The reflecting mirror used by Captain Kater for viewing the graduated compass ring was superseded in 1812 by the application of Schmalkalder's prismatic eyepiece to the compass. By this means the observer can read the bearing and sight the object simultaneously, and can thus dispense with a stand for the instrument. For this reason the prismatic compass has come into general use for rapid reconnaissance surveys. The example exhibited was constructed by Schmalkalder in the early part of the 19th century. The compass card is 2½ in. in diameter, and is fixed to the magnetic needle. It is graduated in consecutive half-degrees from 0° to 360° in a clockwise direction, the N. end of the needle being under the 180° mark. The diagonal prism is attached to the plate which has a slit serving as backsight, and is ground convex on one perpendicular face so as to magnify the image of the graduated card seen by reflection at its inclined face, which is silvered. This backsight plate is jointed
Object/Inventory number: N/A

This backsight plate is jointed to the compass box, and can be folded down when the instrument is not in use. The foresight consists of a vertical wire fixed in a frame diametrically opposite the back-sight, and similarly jointed to the base so as to fold down when not in use. Mirrors and coloured glasses are attached to the sights for taking bearing upon the sun and other celestial objects. A lever is provided for lifting the needle from its pivot and locking the compass card when desired, and there is a steadying pin underneath the foresight for damping the oscillations of the card.

Catalogue number: 149
Object name: AZIMUTH COMPASS
Maker/Donor: Made by Dollond. Presented by T. H. Court, Esq.
Date of creation: about 1770
Object entry information: This instrument, made by Dollond about 1770, is typical of the surveyor's compass previous to the invention of Kater's mirror compass or Schmalkalder's prismatic compass. Here the position of the needle upon the graduated compass ring, which is fixed, cannot be read at the same time as the object is viewed through the sights. Consequently it is necessary to use a stand to support the compass, and a socket is attached to the base of the wooden case for this purpose. The fixed compass ring is graduated in degrees continuously from 0° to 360° in a counter-clockwise direction. The slit backsight and wire foresight are fixed to the compass box at the 0° and 180° respectively. When the object is sighted, the reading of the S. end of the needle upon the graduated ring gives the correct magnetic bearing. The compass ring is 4¼ in. diameter, and the sights are 6¼ in. apart. These latter can be folded down upon the face of the compass for transport, and a recess is provided in the lid of the wooden case for their reception. This lid, on being closed, depresses a pin which lifts the needle from its pivot and clamps it against the glass cover.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1912–243.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 150
Object name: AZIMUTH COMPASS
Maker/Donor: Made by Adams.
Date of creation: about the end of the 18th century
Object entry information: This compass, probably made about the end of the 18th century, differs only in minor details from the adjacent one made by Dollond. It has a 3½ in. compass ring graduated in degrees, mounted in a brass case to which sights can be fitted, and which has a threaded socket for attaching the instrument to a stand when taking bearings. The graduations are numbered every 10° in quadrants, with the 0° at the N. and S. points. Opposite these points are sliding sockets in the outer case. The two sights, each having a slit and a wire for use as backsight and foresight respectively, are mounted in these sockets when in use, or fitted within the lid of the compass case for transport. The sights are 3 in. long. The compass needle is provided with a lifting lever actuated by a pin which is depressed when the lid is fitted on the case, but has no clamping arrangement.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1909–140.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 151
Object name: MIRROR AZIMUTH COMPASS
Maker/Donor: Made by Thos. Jones. Lent by W. Shackleton, Esq., F.R.A.S.
Date of creation: beginning of the 19th century
Object entry information: The mirror attachment to the eye lens here shown was invented by Capt. Kater at the beginning of the 19th century, and enables the observer to view the graduations of the horizontal compass ring at the same time as he takes a sight. The compass ring is fixed to the rotating needle and is so graduated in half-degrees consecutively from 0° to 360° that correct bearings are read off immediately. The diameter of the compass card is 4½ in. The usual slit backsight and wire foresight are fixed to the compass box at a distance apart of 5 in. A small pin fixed in the case vertically beneath the backsight serves as fiducial mark, and its position on the graduated scale is seen through the mirror very clearly when the instrument is held about one foot away from the eye. The foresight can be folded down upon the top of the case, and the compass card and needle are thereby automatically lifted from the pivot and clamped.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1916–6. S.M. 962. L.S.

Catalogue number: 152
Object name: PRISMATIC COMPASS
Maker/Donor: Made by Schmalkalder.
Date of creation: early part of the 19th century
Object entry information: The reflecting mirror used by Captain Kater for viewing the graduated compass ring was superseded in 1812 by the application of Schmalkalder's prismatic eyepiece to the compass. By this means the observer can read the bearing and sight the object simultaneously, and can thus dispense with a stand for the instrument. For this reason the prismatic compass has come into general use for rapid reconnaissance surveys. The example exhibited was constructed by Schmalkalder in the early part of the 19th century. The compass card is 2½ in. in diameter, and is fixed to the magnetic needle. It is graduated in consecutive half-degrees from 0° to 360° in a clockwise direction, the N. end of the needle being under the 180° mark. The diagonal prism is attached to the plate which has a slit serving as backsight, and is ground convex on one perpendicular face so as to magnify the image of the graduated card seen by reflection at its inclined face, which is silvered. This backsight plate is jointed

title: Two prismatic magnetic compass, British, 1810-1826
description: Two prismatic magnetic compass, one with leather case, by Charles  Auguste Schmalcalder, Strand, London, England, 1810-1826

Maker/Donor: Made by Schmalcalder.
Object entry information: This instrument, constructed in the early part of the 19th century, is essentially a combined theodolite and prismatic compass. The telescopic alidade, which carries the prismatic eyepiece and a vernier underneath this, can be rotated about the vertical axis independently of the compass box, the instrument thus acting as a theodolite—or can be rotated together with the compass ring, in which case it fulfills the functions of a prismatic compass. The compass ring is graduated directly to 20' in a clockwise direction and is read by vernier to single minutes. The instrument is attached to a stand by means of a ball and socket arrangement, and can be levelled independently of the stand by four screws which engage in threads in the socket and press against the vertical axis. There is also a tangent clamp and slow motion screw for rotating the whole instrument in azimuth, whilst a circular rack and pinion inside the compass box serves to rotate the alidade independently. This is actuated by the screw projecting beneath the compass. The telescope carries a small spirit level, and is screwed at the eyepiece end to a brass plate hinged to a sliding piece, whilst it rests at the objective end in a Y-piece fixed to another sliding piece. These two sliding pieces terminate at their lower ends in screws, which work in threaded plates screwed to the compass box. Thus the telescope can be elevated at either end with respect to the compass box and can be adjusted so as to be horizontal. It is focussed by sliding the objective lens.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 154.
Object name: PRISMATIC COMPASS AND CLINOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Cary.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The quadrant attached to this instrument, which is in other respects similar to the Schmalcalder prismatic compass, enables it to be used for measuring altitudes as well as taking magnetic bearings. The quadrant has separate sights and a small spirit level fixed to a movable radial arm. A mark engraved on the outer end of this arm registers the altitude upon the graduated arc of the quadrant when the arm is horizontal and the sights are directed upon the distant object. The compass ring is 2½ in. in diam. and is fixed to the rotating magnetic needle. It is graduated continuously in half-degrees from 0° to 360°. As the N. point of the needle is attached at the 180° mark of the ring, the correct bearing of the object sighted is read off directly through the prismatic eyepiece attached to the slit back-sight. A small spirit level is fixed to the bottom of the case inside and serves to set the compass horizontal. The altitude quadrant has a radius of 2 in. and is attached to the wire foresight of the compass. It is graduated in degrees from 0° to 90°, the radius corresponding to the former being parallel to the compass plane, and carrying the supplementary sights, a pin-hole back-sight and a cross-wire foresight, for determining altitudes. Mirrors and coloured glasses are attached to the two compass sights for taking bearings on high objects such as the sun.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1917-78.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 155.
Object name: PRISMATIC COMPASS.
Maker/Donor: Made by Chamberlain.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: In this instrument, constructed about the middle of the 19th century, the method of lifting and locking the compass card is similar to that employed by Schmalcalder. The card is graduated in degrees, in two sets numbered consecutively in the clockwise sense from 0° to 180°. There are no mirrors or coloured glasses for celestial observations. The diameter of the compass ring is 2½ in. and it can be read by estimation to the nearest 10'.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1872-79.

The compass card is not graduated continuously from 0° to 360°, but in two sets of 180°, both in the clockwise sense. It reads directly to half-degrees, and by estimation to 10'. The compass card is lifted and clamped by folding down the foresight.

Maker/Donor: Made by Cary, Porter, Ltd. Presented by the Admiralty.
Object entry information: Except for the arrangement to lift and lock the compass card, this instrument differs very little from those made by Schmalcalder nearly a century previously. The compass card, prismatic eyepiece, steadying pin, etc., remain the same, but the eyepiece is here arranged so that the eye must be nearer the slit for focussing than in Schmalcalder's instruments, whilst the folding down of the foresight upon the compass automatically lifts and clamps the card. The compass card is 5 in. in diameter, and a duplicate card is provided. The card is graduated in half-degrees in the usual clockwise sense. Both the sights can be folded down, and the prismatic eyepiece can be adjusted for focussing the gradua-tions. There are the usual mirrors and coloured glasses for taking bearings of celestial objects. A socket is rigidly fixed to the base of the compass box for attaching it to a stand. When the compass is so mounted, bearings can be taken to within 15', and estimated to the nearest 5'.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 158
Object name: PRISMATIC COMPASS (Mark VIII).
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a modern type of compass specially designed for rough surveying and for night marching upon a given bearing, previously set off on the edge of the compass. It has a hair foresight upon the hinged lid, and a slit backsight upon the hinged mounting carrying the prismatic reader. Various marks in luminous paint upon the lid, cover plate and dial of the compass are used in night marching. The compass has a spring damping pin for checking the oscillations of the dial as well as a lifting pin for locking it when not in use. The luminous marks on the lid are at the extremities of the hair foresight. The glass cover plate of the compass box also has a luminous mark and can be independently rotated so as to set this mark at any angle to the sight line. The angle so set is measured by means of an index mark on the cover in conjunction with the graduated edge of the compass box. This is set to the bearing upon which it is desired to march, and the cover plate locked by means of a spring catch which engages in the milled edge of the plate. The dial of the compass, which is fixed to the magnetic needle and pivoted so as to rotate freely, has a luminous arrow marked above the north pole of the magnet. When the compass is turned until the luminous mark on the cover plate lies above the luminous arrow on the dial, the luminous marks at the extremity of the hair line on the lid point in the direction it is desired to march. For surveying purposes the compass dial is graduated in degrees round its edge, the numbers being inverted so as to appear upright when seen through the prism, and so arranged that the correct bearing of the line of sight is read directly through the prism. There is a supplementary set of numbered graduations every 5° for direct reading without using the prism. A ring is hinged to the box to steady it when taking bearings, and a lever on the lid automatically actuates the lifting pin when the lid is closed. The compass has a diameter of 2 in.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922-41

Catalogue number: 159
Object name: LIQUID PRISMATIC COMPASS.
Maker/Donor: Made by Kelvin, Bottomley & Baird, Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This instrument combines the advantages of prismatic reading with the rapid and accurate setting afforded by nearly floating the compass card in a liquid, which reduces the friction of the pivot and rapidly damps the motion of the card. The dial can be illuminated for night reading by means of an electric bulb fixed beneath the transparent base of the compass box. A socket attached to the base enables the compass to be mounted upon the tripod exhibited with it. The compass card has a diameter of 2·5 in. and is graduated in degrees, read by an internal index point mounted beneath the centre of the prismatic reader. The card carries two cylindrical magnetic needles fixed below it with their axes parallel, and has a central buoyant chamber resting upon the pivot. The card, needles and pivot are enclosed in a watertight chamber filled with a mixture of water and alcohol, which has a low freezing point. The card just rests upon the pivot, without pressing much on it, so that there is little frictional resistance to its rotation, and its motion is nearly "critically damped" by the liquid so that it takes up its new setting after rotation within a few seconds. Maker/Donor: Made by Kelvin, Bottomley & Baird, Ltd.
Object entry information: This instrument combines the advantages of prismatic reading with the rapid and accurate setting afforded by nearly floating the compass card in a liquid, which reduces the friction of the pivot and rapidly damps the motion of the card. The dial can be illuminated for night reading by means of an electric bulb fixed beneath the transparent base of the compass box. A socket attached to the base enables the compass to be mounted upon the tripod exhibited with it. The compass card has a diameter of 2·5 in. and is graduated in degrees, read by an internal index point mounted beneath the centre of the prismatic reader. The card carries two cylindrical magnetic needles fixed below it with their axes parallel, and has a central buoyant chamber resting upon the pivot. The card, needles and pivot are enclosed in a watertight chamber filled with a mixture of water and alcohol, which has a low freezing point. The card just rests upon the pivot, without pressing much on it, so that there is little frictional resistance to its rotation, and its motion is nearly "critically damped" by the liquid so that it takes up its new setting after rotation within a few seconds. The prismatic reader has a V-shaped backsight used with the long foresight bracket upon which is a travelling foresight. Owing to the freedom of the needle from vibration, the reading can be taken to the nearest fifth degree. The electric bulb serving to illuminate the dial for night reading is operated by a plug switch and a battery of two small cells, carried in the leather case used for transporting the compass.

Maker/Donor: Made by Bulbreck, Paris. Lent by T. H. Court, Esq.
Object entry information: In this type of military compass, invented by Capt. Burnier about 1850, the graduated edge of the compass ring, which is fixed to the needle and rotates with it, is perpendicular to the plane of the needle. The bearing of the sighting thread can therefore be viewed at the same time as a sight is taken. A weighted disc is mounted parallel to the compass ring, and has a similar graduated edge. On clamping the compass ring and bringing the planes of both rings vertical, the disc is unclamped and serves as a clinometer. Either ring is viewed through a cylindrical eye lens, which closes the brass case and is about 2 cm. distant from the graduated edges. A double-jointed socket attached to the base of the case permits the instrument to be rotated in a vertical or a horizontal plane upon a stick stand, and serves as a support for holding the instrument when no stand is used. The compass ring is graduated in degrees continuously from 0° to 360°, and the magnetic bearing of the object sighted is read off directly. The clinometer ring is likewise graduated in degrees, and is weighted at the 90° portion. Each ring is 4 cm. diameter and has an edge 2 mm. deep. The usual folding slit and wire sights are attached to the top of the case, and are easily viewed simultaneously with the graduated rings when the instrument is held about a foot from the eye. A wire mounted within the case near the graduated edges in the plane of these two sights serves as fiducial mark. The whole instrument is compact and serviceable, and is in general use on the Continent for military and reconnaissance surveys. (See Laussedat's "Recherches sur les Instruments Topographiques," Vol. I, p. 306.)

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 161.
Object name: EXPERIMENTAL "POCKET ALTAZIMUTHS."
Maker/Donor: Presented by C. F. Casella & Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: These two examples of Casella's " Pocket Altazimuth," or combined compass and clinometer, illustrate the experimental stages of development of the instrument, which is represented in its modern form by an adjacent exhibit. Each instrument consists of two graduated aluminium rings separately mounted upon pivots along the axis of a single cylindrical metal box, which is closed by glass faces. A magnetic needle is fixed to one ring, which acts as a compass to determine azimuths, whilst the other ring is loaded at one point and serves as a plummet clinometer for measuring altitude angles. When not in use, each ring can be lifted from its pivots and clamped by means of a lever actuated by a sliding knob. In one instrument the graduated edges of the rings are read by means of two small telescopes, one for each ring, mounted on the metal box; a thin wire is stretched across the box between the telescopes and the rings and defines the index line, or line of sight. In the other instrument, a single telescope can be fitted so as to read either ring alternately, and also to sight upon a distant object. This telescope has a single objective lens and a dual eyepiece, comprising a lens for sighting on the distant object and a prism for reading the graduations upon the upper face of the compass or clinometer ring. In both instruments the rings are graduated in degrees, and a flat footing is attached to the box so that it can be placed upon any surface of which the inclination is to be measured.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923-414.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE

Object name: POCKET ALTAZIMUTH.
Maker/Donor: Made by Casella.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a compact form of combined telescopic compass and clinometer of a design embodying improvements due to Sir Francis Galton, F.R.S. Either magnetic bearings or altitude angles can be measured independently, but not simultaneously, with it. It is particularly suitable for very approximate reconnaissance surveying.

Maker/Donor: Made by Casella.
Object entry information: This is a compact form of combined telescopic compass and clinometer of a design embodying improvements due to Sir Francis Galton, F.R.S. Either magnetic bearings or altitude angles can be measured independently, but not simultaneously, with it. It is particularly suitable for very approximate reconnaissance surveying. It consists of two graduated rings, separately pivoted within a cylindrical case, having glass-covered ends parallel to the planes of the two rings. One of the rings is graduated at the 32 points of the compass, and has a diametrical magnetic needle whose centre rests on the pivot. The other ring is loaded at one part of its circumference and is pivoted to the case on each side. It is graduated in degrees, numbered in quadrants, with the zero point opposite the centre of gravity of the load. Both rings have a diameter of $1\frac{1}{4}$ in., the external diameter of the cylindrical case being $2\frac{1}{2}$ in. The compass ring only moves when its plane is horizontal, the clinometer ring when its plane is vertical. Each ring is clamped when its plane is in use, and is read by the position of an index mark on the cylindrical case. The latter carries a telescope, whose axis is parallel to the ends of the cylinder and passes through the line of pivots of the ring. The telescope has its objective tube and eyepiece tube separately fixed to the case, the latter being partly without and partly within the case, and having a slide-focussing eyepiece. A hair line is stretched across the case just behind the objective lens. A base piece for supporting the instrument is attached to the case, with its plane base parallel to the axis of the telescope. There is also a central threaded hole in the base for fixing it to a tripod. A damping spring is provided for use with the compass ring. The complete instrument weighs only 8 oz.

Object entry information: reader has a V-shaped backsight used with the long foresight bracket upon which is a travelling foresight. Owing to the freedom of the needle from vibration, the reading can be taken to the nearest fifth degree. The electric bulb serving to illuminate the dial for night reading is operated by a plug switch and a battery of two small cells, carried in the leather case used for transporting the compass.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922-44.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 160.
Object name: BURNIER'S COMBINED COMPASS AND CLINOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Bulbreck, Paris. Lent by T. H. Court, Esq.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: In this type of military compass, invented by Capt. Burnier about 1850, the graduated edge of the compass ring, which is fixed to the needle and rotates with it, is perpendicular to the plane of the needle. The bearing of the sighting thread can therefore be viewed at the same time as a sight is taken. A weighted disc is mounted parallel to the compass ring, and has a similar graduated edge. On clamping the compass ring and bringing the planes of both rings vertical, the disc is unclamped and serves as a clinometer. Either ring is viewed through a cylindrical eye lens, which closes the brass case and is about 2 cm. distant from the graduated edges. A double-jointed socket attached to the base of the case permits the instrument to be rotated in a vertical or a horizontal plane upon a stick stand, and serves as a support for holding the instrument when no stand is used. The compass ring is graduated in degrees continuously from 0° to 360°, and the magnetic bearing of the object sighted is read off directly. The clinometer ring is likewise graduated in degrees, and is weighted at the 90° portion. Each ring is 4 cm. diameter and has an edge 2 mm. deep. The usual folding slit and wire sights are attached to the top of the case, and are easily viewed simultaneously with the graduated rings when the instrument is held about a foot from the eye. A wire mounted within the case near the graduated edges in the plane of these two sights serves as fiducial mark. The whole instrument is compact and serviceable, and is in general use on the Continent for military and reconnaissance surveys. (See Laussedat's "Recherches sur les Instruments Topographiques," Vol. I, p. 306.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1916-64.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 161.
Object name: EXPERIMENTAL "POCKET ALTAZIMUTHS."
Maker/Donor: Presented by C. F. Casella & Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: These two examples of Casella's " Pocket Altazimuth," or combined compass and clinometer, illustrate the experimental stages of development of the instrument, which is represented in its modern form by an adjacent exhibit. Each instrument consists of two graduated aluminium rings separately mounted upon pivots along the axis of a single cylindrical metal box, which is closed by glass faces. A magnetic needle is fixed to one ring, which acts as a compass to determine azimuths, whilst the other ring is loaded at one point and serves as a plummet clinometer for measuring altitude angles. When not in use, each ring can be lifted from its pivots and clamped by means of a lever actuated by a sliding knob. In one instrument the graduated edges of the rings are read by means of two small telescopes, one for each ring, mounted on the metal box; a thin wire is stretched across the box between the telescopes and the rings and defines the index line, or line of sight. In the other instrument, a single telescope can be fitted so as to read either ring alternately, and also to sight upon a distant object. This telescope has a single objective lens and a dual eyepiece, comprising a lens for sighting on the distant object and a prism for reading the graduations upon the upper face of the compass or clinometer ring. In both instruments the rings are graduated in degrees, and a flat footing is attached to the box so that it can be placed upon any surface of which the inclination is to be measured.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1923-414.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 163.
Object name: TELESCOPIC COMPASS.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This is a modern example of a French type of surveying compass, with an eccentrically mounted telescope, used on the Continent on minor work. The compass is fixed in a flat, rectangular wooden box, to one side of which is attached the telescope, rotating about an axis fixed perpendicularly to this side. The whole instrument can rotate in the plane of the compass ring, which can itself be varied by means of a ball-and-socket joint.
The instrument is attached to a "peg" stand by means of a brass socket connected to the compass by a ball-and-socket joint. By this means the compass can be set horizontal without adjusting the stand. The compass ring has a diameter of 5 in., and is graduated in half-degrees, numbered every $10^{\circ}$ in the clockwise sense. The plane of rotation of the telescope is parallel to the $0^{\circ}$ to $180^{\circ}$ line of the ring. The telescope has a single fixed objective lens of 6 in. The cross wires are also fixed, the single eye lens being slide focussing. A set-screw serves to clamp the socket to the tripod peg, and a clamping screw to prevent the horizontal rotation of the compass upon its platform. The ball-and-socket joint is fixed by means of a nut and bolt.
A small tube spirit level is mounted on one side of the compass box, and the compass needle can be elevated from its pivot by a locking lever.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1919–416.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 164.
Object name: EARLY CIRCUMFERENTOR.
Maker/Donor: Lent by T. H. Court, Esq.
Date of creation: 1590
Object entry information: The date of this instrument is indicated by the allowance for magnetic declination on the compass ring, on which the meridian is engraved at the point $10^{\circ}$ E. of N. This corresponds to the year 1590, in England.
It consists of a brass circle, $4\frac{1}{2}$ in. diam., having a small suspension ring, and a pair of fixed sights which define a horizontal line when the instrument is suspended from the ring. This circle acts as the base plate for a compass box, $3\frac{1}{2}$ in. diam., which has a separate graduated circle of 3 in. diam. The circular side of the compass box is movable about its centre, and carries a pair of sights, with pointers attached, the latter moving over the graduated circle on the base plate.
The instrument can be screwed on to a stick stand, for taking magnetic bearings in a horizontal plane, or suspended by the ring for taking altitude angles. In each case the movable sights are set along the line whose direction is required.
A lid is provided for protecting the instrument when it is not in use.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1918–124.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 165.
Object name: EARLY THEODOLITE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by T. H. Court, Esq.
Date of creation: early 17th century
Object entry information: This instrument probably dates from the early 17th century. It consists of a brass circle, 8 in. diam., graduated in degrees, having two pairs of fixed sights along perpendicular diameters, and a movable alidade fitted with pointers at each end. It can be set upon a stand for measuring angles in any plane, or suspended from a ring attached to the circumference for taking altitudes.
On the face of the circle is engraved a dial indicating the points of the compass, and a geometrical square with “Umbra Recta” and “Umbra Versa” scales.
The circle is graduated continuously from $0^{\circ}$ to $360^{\circ}$.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1918–123.

Object entry information: Plate III, Fig. 2, p. 56. In this instrument, which was probably made in the early 17th century, only one pair of fixed sights is provided, defining a horizontal line when the instrument is suspended from the ring attached to its circumference. The diameter of the graduated circle is 10 in., and the movable alidade carries the usual slit sights and terminates in pointers. There is a circular ring on one arm of the instrument which probably supported a magnetic compass. The circle is graduated in degrees in four sets from 0° to 90°. On the back of the instrument is attached a socket with a fixing screw for receiving the head of a stand. The suspension ring is specially jointed to permit the plane of the circle to hang freely vertical.

Catalogue number: 167.
Object name: COMBINED GRAPHOMETER, SECTOR AND COMPASSES.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: Late 16th or early 17th century
Object entry information: This instrument of Italian make was probably constructed in the late 16th or early 17th century, and consists of a graphometer whose alidades are fitted with points to serve as compasses, and have various scales engraved on them corresponding to those usually found on sectors, and used in measuring lines, setting off angles, taking weights of spherical shot, etc. A small magnetic compass is attached to the junction of the two alidades. There is no evidence that this instrument was fitted to a stand, and it was presumably employed in conjunction with a plane table, on which it rested when angles were observed. The semicircle is graduated in degrees, and is 6.5 in. in diam. The sights on the alidades are 8 in. apart.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1880–202.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 168.
Object name: IPODIMETER.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: 17th-century
Object entry information: This is a 17th-century theodolite of Continental design, the alidade being mounted near the edge of the circle and connected to a centrally mounted parallel index arm used to read the circle. The circle has a diameter of 6 1/4 in., and a 2 1/4-in. compass box is centrally fixed above the movable index arm. The circle is divided on its outer edge into 360 degrees, but has a concentric circle, of 5 in. diam., divided into 320 parts, also read by the diametral index arm. Each circle is divided into octants and the divisions of each octant numbered in the clockwise sense from 0 to 45 on the outer circle and from 0 to 40 on the inner. The outer octants are successively designated by the letters T, G, L, S, O, A, P, M, which are the initial letters of the old Italian names for the compass points. The inner octants each commence at the central points of the outer ones, and are named Septentrio, Aquilo, Solanus, Eurus, Auster, Africus, Favonius, and Chaurus respectively, which are the old Latin titles for the winds corresponding to the cardinal points. The central index arm has bevelled edges at each extremity for reading the divisions. The alidade is about 9 in. long and has folding combined back and foresights at each end. It rotates with the index arm about the axis of the circle. The compass box, fixed to the circle above the index arm, has its base divided into octants, but no subdivisions.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1908–122.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 169.
Object name: GRAPHOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Christoff Kohler, Dresden
Date of creation: 1663.
Object entry information: This instrument is a combined graphometer, or surveying semicircle, and clinometer. The graduated semicircle can be detached from the frame and used as a protractor for plotting the angles in the field. A compass is attached to the frame for orienting the instrument, and the whole is attached to a stand by means of a double-knuckled joint, permitting it to be set in any plane. It can also rotate as a whole in that plane. The semicircle has one fixed and one movable alidade, and is 5 in. in diam. It is graduated in degrees, and has a diagonal scale enabling it to read to 5′. This is particularly interesting as showing that the much simpler vernier system was not yet in general use, although invented over 30 years previously. The compass ring has a diameter of 1 1/4 in. and is graduated in degrees. On the back of the plate carrying it is a simple quadrant pendulum clinometer, also graduated in degrees, and provided with “Umbra Versa” and “Umbra Recta” scales for measuring heights. The clinometer is attached to an alidade, which is connected to the semicircle by a spring clip and can be disconnected for taking altitudes.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1894–106.

In this instrument, which was probably made in the early 17th century, only one pair of fixed sights is provided, defining a horizontal line when the instrument is suspended from the ring attached to its circumference. The diameter of the graduated circle is 10 in., and the movable alidade carries the usual slit sights and terminates in pointers. There is a circular ring on one arm of the instrument which probably supported a magnetic compass. The circle is graduated in degrees in four sets from 0° to 90°. On the back of the instrument is attached a socket with a fixing screw for receiving the head of a stand. The suspension ring is specially jointed to permit the plane of the circle to hang freely vertical.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1918–126, S.M. 1856.

Catalogue number: 167.
Object name: COMBINED GRAPHOMETER, SECTOR AND COMPASSES.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: Late 16th or early 17th century
Object entry information: This instrument of Italian make was probably constructed in the late 16th or early 17th century, and consists of a graphometer whose alidades are fitted with points to serve as compasses, and have various scales engraved on them corresponding to those usually found on sectors, and used in measuring lines, setting off angles, taking weights of spherical shot, etc. A small magnetic compass is attached to the junction of the two alidades. There is no evidence that this instrument was fitted to a stand, and it was presumably employed in conjunction with a plane table, on which it rested when angles were observed. The semicircle is graduated in degrees, and is 6.5 in. in diam. The sights on the alidades are 8 in. apart.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1880–202.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 168.
Object name: IPODIMETER.
Maker/Donor: N/A
Date of creation: 17th-century
Object entry information: This is a 17th-century theodolite of Continental design, the alidade being mounted near the edge of the circle and connected to a centrally mounted parallel index arm used to read the circle. The circle has a diameter of 6 1/4 in., and a 2 1/4-in. compass box is centrally fixed above the movable index arm. The circle is divided on its outer edge into 360 degrees, but has a concentric circle, of 5 in. diam., divided into 320 parts, also read by the diametral index arm. Each circle is divided into octants and the divisions of each octant numbered in the clockwise sense from 0 to 45 on the outer circle and from 0 to 40 on the inner. The outer octants are successively designated by the letters T, G, L, S, O, A, P, M, which are the initial letters of the old Italian names for the compass points. The inner octants each commence at the central points of the outer ones, and are named Septentrio, Aquilo, Solanus, Eurus, Auster, Africus, Favonius, and Chaurus respectively, which are the old Latin titles for the winds corresponding to the cardinal points. The central index arm has bevelled edges at each extremity for reading the divisions. The alidade is about 9 in. long and has folding combined back and foresights at each end. It rotates with the index arm about the axis of the circle. The compass box, fixed to the circle above the index arm, has its base divided into octants, but no subdivisions.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1908–122.

Maker/Donor: Made by Lusuérg, Rome.
Object entry information: This instrument has a radius of 6 in. and is graduated in half-degrees. By means of a vernier arc covering 31' and divided into 60 parts, angles can be measured to the nearest half-minute. The index arm carrying this vernier is pivoted at the centre of the quadrant and carries three folding sights, one at its centre and the other two at the ends of its arc. Two similar sights are fixed at the ends of the quadrant arc. The quadrant is attached to a socket for fixing it upon a stand by a ball and socket joint permitting it to be set in any plane, including the vertical.
