Catalogue number: 170
Object name: EARLY SURVEYING QUADRANT.
Maker/Donor: Made by Lusuérg, Rome.
Date of creation: 1674.
Object entry information: This instrument has a radius of 6 in. and is graduated in half-degrees. By means of a vernier arc covering 31' and divided into 60 parts, angles can be measured to the nearest half-minute. The index arm carrying this vernier is pivoted at the centre of the quadrant and carries three folding sights, one at its centre and the other two at the ends of its arc. Two similar sights are fixed at the ends of the quadrant arc. The quadrant is attached to a socket for fixing it upon a stand by a ball and socket joint permitting it to be set in any plane, including the vertical.
On the upper surface of the quadrant are engraved a tangent scale (" Scala altimetra "), concentric with the divided arc, and also linear scales and a rect angular network for use in plotting. On the lower surface is engraved a clino meter scale for artillery purposes and the arms and coronet of the Duke of Modena. The inscription " Jacobus Lusuérg Mutinensis Faciebat Romae A° 1674", engraved on the upper surface, gives the date and maker of the instrument.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1880-200.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 171
Object name: EARLY THEODOLITE.
Maker/Donor: Made by Joannes Macarius, Mirandola (Modena).
Date of creation: 1676.
Object entry information: The date of construction, 1676, and maker's name are inscribed on this very fine example of an early theodolite, which has a circle of 12 in. diam., graduated every 10' and read by a vernier on the alidade to 1'. A 2-in. compass is fixed at the centre of the circle and has its ring divided in degrees.
The circle carries four fixed combined sights at the ends of mutually perpen dicular diameters. Each sight has a vertical slit, a small aperture, and a pair of thin cross-pieces intersecting at the aperture and forming cross-wire foresights. The alidade, pivoted to rotate about the centre of the circle, has a similar pair of sights at the extremities of its index arm, and these have bevelled edges for reading the circle directly. The double vernier plate is screwed to the alidade at right angles to its direction of sight. Each vernier extends over 61° of the circle, and is divided into 60 parts. There are two vernier plates provided, the one fixed to the alidade having engraved upon it the various numbers of foreign feet equal to 1,000 Roman feet. The other vernier plate can be sub stituted for this one if required. The circle graduations have three sets of numbers, one consecutively from 0° to 360° in the clockwise sense, the other two by quadrants having the zero points beneath each of the fixed sights. Scales of sines, tangents and sides of inscribed polygons are also engraved on the circle, as well as various scales of length on its cross-bars. On the back of the circle are engraved other scales used in artillery and fortification work with the Latin inscription " Bonifacius March" Rangonus Faciebat jussit Mutinae Anno Domini, 1676".
A suspension shackle is fixed to the top of the circle for setting it in a vertical plane, and a socket is provided for mounting it horizontally upon a stand.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1880-195.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 172
Object name: GRAPHOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Deens.
Date of creation: 1682.
Object entry information: This instrument consists of one fixed and one movable alidade, each provided with sights, intersecting each other at the centre of a semicircle graduated to read half-degrees. The whole is mounted upon a ball and socket joint, and can be used to measure angles in any plane.
In this instrument, no compass is attached for orientation, and the alidades are not provided with verniers. The graduated semicircle has a diameter of 11 cm., with two sets of supplementary figures.
An inscription on the movable alidade reads " Iodocus Deens Louaniensis Belga Austriorum Viennes fecit, 1682".
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1892-9.

The circle graduations have three sets of numbers, one consecutively from 0° to 360° in the clockwise sense, the other two by quadrants having the zero points beneath each of the fixed sights. Scales of sines, tangents and sides of inscribed polygons are also engraved on the circle, as well as various scales of length on its cross-bars. On the back of the circle are engraved other scales used in artillery and fortification work with the Latin inscription " Bonifacius March" Rangonus Faciebat jussit Mutinae Anno Domini, 1676".
A suspension shackle is fixed to the top of the circle for setting it in a vertical plane, and a socket is provided for mounting it horizontally upon a stand.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1880-195.

title: Graphometer, Flemish, 1682
description: Graphometer by Joducus Deens of Belgium, 1682

Maker/Donor: Made by Lusuérg, Rome.
Object entry information: This example was constructed in 1686, and exhibits many characteristics of that period. The alidade plate is square, and can be detached from its support and employed as a protractor. On it are engraved three concentric graduated circles, of diameters 8 in., 7 in. and 3 in. The outer circle is divided in degrees, with two sets of numberings. The central circle is a " Scala altimetra," or tangent scale, for measuring heights, and the inner circle is divided into 32 parts corresponding to the points of the compass. The movable alidade carries a 2 1/4-in. compass box, and is pivoted at the centre of the plate. At one end is a vernier arc which moves over the outer graduated circle, and reads this to single minutes, the 60 divisions of the vernier extending over 61°. The fixed and movable sights have circular apertures, with vertical slits above their centres, and are carved and ornamentally engraved. Two edges of the square plate are parallel to the two fixed sights, which can be folded down upon the plate when not in use. The conical socket for attaching the instrument to its stand has a ball and socket joint permitting the alidade plate to be set in any plane, including the vertical. It is kept in position by the friction of the joint, there being no clamping screw. The compass plate is graduated in degrees, numbered left and right from the N. and S. points from 0° to 90°. A compass rose indicating the 32 main points is engraved inside the circle. On the back of the alidade plate are engraved a clinometer scale for use of artillery, and the inscription "Jacobus Lussorg Mutinensis Faciebat Romae A° 1686", with the arms and coronet of the Duke of Modena.

Catalogue number: 170
Object name: EARLY SURVEYING QUADRANT.
Maker/Donor: Made by Lusuérg, Rome.
Date of creation: 1674.
Object entry information: This instrument has a radius of 6 in. and is graduated in half-degrees. By means of a vernier arc covering 31' and divided into 60 parts, angles can be measured to the nearest half-minute. The index arm carrying this vernier is pivoted at the centre of the quadrant and carries three folding sights, one at its centre and the other two at the ends of its arc. Two similar sights are fixed at the ends of the quadrant arc. The quadrant is attached to a socket for fixing it upon a stand by a ball and socket joint permitting it to be set in any plane, including the vertical.
On the upper surface of the quadrant are engraved a tangent scale (" Scala altimetra "), concentric with the divided arc, and also linear scales and a rect angular network for use in plotting. On the lower surface is engraved a clino meter scale for artillery purposes and the arms and coronet of the Duke of Modena. The inscription " Jacobus Lusuérg Mutinensis Faciebat Romae A° 1674", engraved on the upper surface, gives the date and maker of the instrument.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1880-200.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 171
Object name: EARLY THEODOLITE.
Maker/Donor: Made by Joannes Macarius, Mirandola (Modena).
Date of creation: 1676.
Object entry information: The date of construction, 1676, and maker's name are inscribed on this very fine example of an early theodolite, which has a circle of 12 in. diam., graduated every 10' and read by a vernier on the alidade to 1'. A 2-in. compass is fixed at the centre of the circle and has its ring divided in degrees.
The circle carries four fixed combined sights at the ends of mutually perpen dicular diameters. Each sight has a vertical slit, a small aperture, and a pair of thin cross-pieces intersecting at the aperture and forming cross-wire foresights. The alidade, pivoted to rotate about the centre of the circle, has a similar pair of sights at the extremities of its index arm, and these have bevelled edges for reading the circle directly. The double vernier plate is screwed to the alidade at right angles to its direction of sight. Each vernier extends over 61° of the circle, and is divided into 60 parts. There are two vernier plates provided, the one fixed to the alidade having engraved upon it the various numbers of foreign feet equal to 1,000 Roman feet. The other vernier plate can be sub stituted for this one if required. The circle graduations have three sets of numbers, one consecutively from 0° to 360° in the clockwise sense, the other two by quadrants having the zero points beneath each of the fixed sights. Scales of sines, tangents and sides of inscribed polygons are also engraved on the circle, as well as various scales of length on its cross-bars. On the back of the circle are engraved other scales used in artillery and fortification work with the Latin inscription " Bonifacius March" Rangonus Faciebat jussit Mutinae Anno Domini, 1676".
A suspension shackle is fixed to the top of the circle for setting it in a vertical plane, and a socket is provided for mounting it horizontally upon a stand.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1880-195.

title: Circumferentor, Italian, 1686
description: Circumferentor in brass, by J. Lusuerg, made in Rome, Italy, 1686

Maker/Donor: Made by Thos. Wright.
Object entry information: Fig. 1, p. 67. This early 18th-century example is typical of the circumferentor of that period. It is a combined theodolite—having a graduated limb of 11 in. diam., reading by vernier to 5'—and compass, with a 6-in. needle reading to half-degrees. The theodolite limb is graduated in single degrees in the clockwise sense from 0° to 360°, and carries a pair of fixed sights, each with a slit and window for sighting both ways, at its 0° and 180° marks. The movable alidade, carrying a similar pair of sights, has a vernier at one end reading to 5' and a central fiducial mark at the other end. The compass box is fixed to this alidade with its N. point above the zero of the vernier. The compass ring is graduated consecutively in half-degrees from 0° to 360° in a counter-clockwise sense, so that the position of the N. end of the needle gives the magnetic bearing of the alidade sights. Both pairs of sights are employed when the instrument is used as a theodolite, but only the alidade sights when taking magnetic bearings. The instrument is mounted upon a tripod when in use.

Catalogue number: 175.
Object name: CIRCUMFERENTOR.
Maker/Donor: Made by J. Howard, London.
Date of creation: Early 18th-century
Object entry information: This early 18th-century instrument has a 10 1/4-in. graduated circle, reading by vernier to 5'. The vernier is attached at one end of the movable alidade, to which is also fixed the compass ring, which has a 6-in. diam. and is graduated in degrees. The sights on the movable alidade, and those fixed on the large circle are each fitted with both slits and vertical wires, and can be used either as back or fore sights. They are sufficiently high to permit the measurement of angles in the horizontal plane, and the whole instrument is designed for such measurements, and not for determining angles in any plane. The outer circle is graduated in degrees, and reads from 0° to 360° in a clockwise sense. The fixed sights are attached at the 0° and 180° points. The compass ring has two sets of graduations, one set reading degrees from 0° to 360° in a counter-clockwise sense, the other set giving every 10° only from 0° to 90° in each quadrant, the N. and S. points being the zero points. The eight main points of the compass are likewise indicated. The whole instrument fits upon a stand by means of a socket fixed on the back of the large circle.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1913-257.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 176.
Object name: GRAPHOMETER.
Maker/Donor: Made by Macquart, Paris.
Date of creation: Early 18th-century
Object entry information: This is an early 18th-century example of the graphometer, or surveying semicircle, much used in France in preference to the English theodolite. It has a diameter of 11 in. and is graduated in degrees, read by vernier on the rotating alidade to 5'. A 3-in. compass, with its ring divided in degrees, is mounted eccentrically on the semicircle. Combined slit and wire sights are fixed at opposite ends of the diameter of the semicircle, and their orientation determined by means of the compass. A similar pair of sights is attached to the alidade, which rotates about the centre of the semicircle, and has bevelled verniers at each end. The axis of the semicircle terminates below in a spherical ball and socket arrangement for mounting the instrument on a tripod and setting its semicircle in any plane.

Date of creation: towards the end of the 18th century
Object entry information: In this instrument, which was constructed towards the end of the 18th century, the compass has a diameter of $1\frac{1}{2}$ in. and is graduated only at the eight cardinal points. It is arranged for a magnetic variation of 16° W. The main circle has a diameter of 6 in. and is graduated in degrees, numbered both ways from 0° to 180° from the diameter underneath the pair of fixed sights. The alidade carrying the movable sights is fixed to the compass box and rotates with it about the vertical axis. The compass needle is pivoted upon a plate fixed to the horizontal circle. There are no verniers, but only bevelled reading edges, on the alidade, and the sights are not suited for sighting both ways, but consist of a simple slit backsight on one end of the alidade and a wire foresight at the other end. The graduated circle can be set in any desired plane by means of a ball and socket joint connecting it to the stand.

Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1908–119.

Catalogue number: 178.
Object name: CIRCUMFERENTOR.
Maker/Donor: Made by W. & S. Jones. Presented by Evan Roberts, Esq.
Date of creation: about the end of the 18th century
Object entry information: This instrument, made about the end of the 18th century, is a good example of the circumferentor of that period. It has two small spirit levels fixed in the base of the compass box for setting the instrument horizontal. The 6-in. circle is graduated in degrees in the clockwise sense from 0° to 360°, and read by the vernier at one end of the alidade to 3'. The compass ring, with a 4-in. needle, is graduated in degrees in the counter-clockwise sense from 0° to 360°. Both fixed and movable sights are provided with slits and windows for sighting in either direction. The small spirit levels upon the base of the compass box were not considered necessary by the makers, but were provided owing to the wishes of many surveyors. The socket attached to the base does not appear to have the customary screw for clamping the instrument to its tripod. (See Adams’s “Geometrical and Graphical Essays,” p. 213, and Plate XIV, Fig. 5.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1912–308.

Catalogue number: 179.
Object name: EARLY ALTAZIMUTH THEODOLITE.
Maker/Donor: Made by Thomas Wright. Presented by P. A. Newton, Esq.
Date of creation: early part of the 18th century
Object entry information: This instrument, dating from the early part of the 18th century, illustrates a fundamental stage in the development of the theodolite. Upon the alidade of a “common theodolite” of the type very generally used in the 17th century, is mounted a fixed graduated vertical arc. A telescope upon which is fixed a longitudinal spirit level, carries a vernier arm which traverses the graduated arc as the telescope rotates, and thus measures the altitude of the object sighted at the same time as the alidade measures its azimuth. The horizontal circle in this instrument has a diameter of 10 in. and is graduated in degrees, numbered from 0° to 260° in the clockwise sense. The alidade has a vernier at one extremity reading the horizontal circle to 5'. A 5-in. compass box is mounted centrally upon this alidade and gives magnetic bearings in single degrees. The vertical arc is graduated in degrees, with the zero at the point vertically beneath the telescope axis, and reads by vernier to 10'. Altitude angles up to 40° of elevation or depression can be measured. The telescope has a focal length of 8 in., an aperture of 1 in., and an erecting eyepiece with a simple cross-wire diaphragm. The spirit level is rigidly attached to the telescope tube. The instrument is attached to its tripod by means of a socket fixed beneath the centre of the horizontal circle.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1918–240. S.M. 1098. L.S.

Maker/Donor: Made by J. Sisson. Lent by T. H. Court, Esq.
Object entry information: Among the early 18th-century makers of surveying instruments, Sisson is generally regarded as the most expert, and his design of altazimuth theodolite, of which the instrument exhibited is typical, remained the standard until Ramsden’s time. This example has a $4\frac{1}{2}$-in. horizontal circle, graduated in degrees and read by three symmetrically placed verniers to 6'. The vertical arc, reading angles up to 70° of elevation or depression, has a radius of 2 in. and is similarly graduated and read by a single vernier centrally placed on the horizontal vernier plate. Both circles have toothed edges, in which engage pinion wheels, the motion of rotation being effected by turning these pinions. The telescope is attached above the vertical arc by screw bearings which permit it to be adjusted to sight horizontally when the vertical arc reads zero. A small spirit level fixed above the telescope, and a smaller one rigidly joined to the vertical arc enable this adjustment to be effected. The horizontal axis of rotation of the vertical arc and telescope rests on standards projecting from the central plate carrying the three horizontal vernier arms. To one of these is attached a clamp and screw which regulates the friction between the movable vernier plate and the fixed horizontal circle. In another vernier arm is fixed the axis of rotation of the pinion wheel which engages in the teeth of the horizontal circle. Beneath the horizontal circle is screwed a compass box of 4 in. diameter. The compass ring is not graduated, but has index marks beneath the o° and the 180° graduations of the horizontal circle. This enables the instrument to be oriented. The conical socket for attaching the theodolite to a staff, or to a levelling device consisting of two parallel plates and four levelling screws, is fixed beneath the compass box. The telescope has a fixed objective of $\frac{3}{4}$-in. aperture, and a sliding Huygens ocular, with a simple fixed cross-wire diaphragm.

Catalogue number: 182
Object name: ALTAZIMUTH THEODOLITE.
Maker/Donor: Made by G. Adams. Lent by T. H. Court, Esq.
Date of creation: probably about 1770
Object entry information: In this theodolite, made probably about 1770, the alidade is replaced by a circular plate carrying two widely separated standards upon which is mounted the horizontal axis of rotation. The vertical semicircle is fixed to this axis, whilst the vernier is fixed on the circular plate. The telescope rests in jointed rings attached above the semicircle. The 7-in. horizontal circle is graduated in degrees, and read by a vernier scale on the alidade plate to 5'. The vertical semicircle is of the same diam. and is graduated in degrees on one side, with scales of feet and links on the other. It is also read by vernier to 5', and can measure angles up to 60° on either side of the vertical. The compass fixed on the alidade plate has a diam. of 3 in. and is graduated in degrees. The telescope, of 7-in. focal length and 0.5-in. aperture, has a single-lens, draw-focussing eyepiece. A spirit level is fixed by adjustable screws beneath the telescope tube, parallel to its axis. The horizontal circle is attached by a clamping screw to the upper of two parallel plates, which are connected to each other by four levelling screws and a spherical joint.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1917-104. S.M. 950. L.S.

Object entry information: read by three symmetrically placed verniers to 6'. The vertical arc, reading angles up to 70° of elevation or depression, has a radius of 2 in. and is similarly graduated and read by a single vernier centrally placed on the horizontal vernier plate. Both circles have toothed edges, in which engage pinion wheels, the motion of rotation being effected by turning these pinions. The telescope is attached above the vertical arc by screw bearings which permit it to be adjusted to sight horizontally when the vertical arc reads zero. A small spirit level fixed above the telescope, and a smaller one rigidly joined to the vertical arc enable this adjustment to be effected. The horizontal axis of rotation of the vertical arc and telescope rests on standards projecting from the central plate carrying the three horizontal vernier arms. To one of these is attached a clamp and screw which regulates the friction between the movable vernier plate and the fixed horizontal circle. In another vernier arm is fixed the axis of rotation of the pinion wheel which engages in the teeth of the horizontal circle. Beneath the horizontal circle is screwed a compass box of 4 in. diameter. The compass ring is not graduated, but has index marks beneath the o° and the 180° graduations of the horizontal circle. This enables the instrument to be oriented. The conical socket for attaching the theodolite to a staff, or to a levelling device consisting of two parallel plates and four levelling screws, is fixed beneath the compass box. The telescope has a fixed objective of $\frac{3}{4}$-in. aperture, and a sliding Huygens ocular, with a simple fixed cross-wire diaphragm.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-588. S.M. 1858.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 181
Object name: EARLY ALTAZIMUTH THEODOLITE.
Maker/Donor: Made by Cole.
Date of creation: probably constructed about 1760
Object entry information: This instrument was probably constructed about 1760 and resembles the adjacent theodolite made by Wright. The vertical arc is fixed to the alidade, and the vernier to the telescope. The 8-in. horizontal circle is graduated in degrees and read to 5' by means of a vernier scale on the alidade. The vertical arc has a radius of 3 in. and is graduated in degrees up to 50° on each side of the zero. It also is read to 5' by its vernier. The 4-in. compass mounted on the alidade is graduated in degrees in the counter clockwise sense. The telescope of 10-in. focal length and 0.5-in. aperture, has a single lens, draw-focussing eyepiece and a simple cross-wire diaphragm. Spirit levels are fixed on the telescope tube and the base of the compass box. The two parallel plates for fixing the instrument to its tripod are connected by four levelling screws and a spherical joint.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1910-125.

Catalogue number: 182
Object name: ALTAZIMUTH THEODOLITE.
Maker/Donor: Made by G. Adams. Lent by T. H. Court, Esq.
Date of creation: probably about 1770
Object entry information: In this theodolite, made probably about 1770, the alidade is replaced by a circular plate carrying two widely separated standards upon which is mounted the horizontal axis of rotation. The vertical semicircle is fixed to this axis, whilst the vernier is fixed on the circular plate. The telescope rests in jointed rings attached above the semicircle. The 7-in. horizontal circle is graduated in degrees, and read by a vernier scale on the alidade plate to 5'. The vertical semicircle is of the same diam. and is graduated in degrees on one side, with scales of feet and links on the other. It is also read by vernier to 5', and can measure angles up to 60° on either side of the vertical. The compass fixed on the alidade plate has a diam. of 3 in. and is graduated in degrees. The telescope, of 7-in. focal length and 0.5-in. aperture, has a single-lens, draw-focussing eyepiece. A spirit level is fixed by adjustable screws beneath the telescope tube, parallel to its axis. The horizontal circle is attached by a clamping screw to the upper of two parallel plates, which are connected to each other by four levelling screws and a spherical joint.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1917-104. S.M. 950. L.S.

title: Seven-inch altazimuth theodolite by George Adams
description: Seven-inch altazimuth theodolite by George Adams, London, England, UK, about 1770.

Maker/Donor: Made by G. Adams. Lent by the Royal Society.
Object entry information: In its essential features this theodolite is a smaller example of the adjacent type by the same maker. A supplementary telescope is fixed to the horizontal circle for keeping the back station in view, whilst both the vertical arc and horizontal circle have milled edges and are rotated by small pinions gearing with the edges. The base of the horizontal circle forms the upper parallel plate for levelling. The 5-in. horizontal circle and 3·5-in. vertical arc are graduated in degrees, and read by verniers to 5′. Angles up to 65° on either side of the vertical can be taken. The telescope has a 4·5-in. objective, with an aperture of 0·3 in. and a simple cross-wire diaphragm. It has a small magnification—about 2 diam.—and no focussing arrangement. The supplementary telescope is of similar construction and dimensions. A small spirit level is fixed in adjustable bearings beneath the main telescope parallel to its optical axis. The telescope rests in Y-s, fixed to the ends of the vertical semicircle, and is kept in position by retaining straps. The bracket supporting the axis of rotation of the vertical arc carries the vernier and is supported on the alidade above the compass box. This latter has a 3-in. diam., graduated in degrees. The needle is missing. The lower parallel plate is attached to the base of the horizontal circle by a ball and socket joint, and carries a conical socket with a clamping spring and screw for mounting the instrument on the peg of a tripod. On the back of the vertical circle are graduated scales of feet and links, the former being a tangent series and the latter one of hypotenusal increments.

Object/Inventory number: N/A

Maker/Donor: Made by Ramsden. Lent by T. H. Court, Esq.
Date of creation: towards the end of the 18th century
Object entry information: This instrument, made towards the end of the 18th century, illustrates the many improvements in design due to Ramsden. The alidade and horizontal plates have their graduated edges bevelled to facilitate reading, and are supported by accurately made conical axes. A tangent clamp and slow-motion screw control the horizontal motion, and the ball and socket joint connecting the two parallel plates of the levelling attachment is very solidly and accurately constructed. The telescope has an achromatic, rack-focussing objective lens of 8·5-in. focal length and 1-in. aperture, and an erecting eyepiece. It rests in Y-s attached to the ends of the vertical semicircle, which has a radius of 3 in. and is graduated on one face in half-degrees. This arc is read by a fixed vernier to 1′, and used to measure angles of elevation or depression up to 60°. The 7-in. horizontal circle is divided in half-degrees and read by two opposing verniers to 1′. The compass box, has a 3-in. ring graduated in degrees and a sensitive needle which can be lifted from its pivot by means of a lever when required. The box is mounted between the telescope standards upon an adjustable stage, which is connected to the horizontal vernier plate by capstan-headed screws. Spirit levels are mounted on the telescope and the vernier plate.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 185
Object name: ALTAZIMUTH THEODOLITE
Maker/Donor: Made by Troughton.
Date of creation: early part of the 19th century
Object entry information: This instrument was made in the early part of the 19th century, and in details resembles the adjacent example made by Ramsden. There is, however, a supplementary telescope used for keeping the back-set station in view. The horizontal circle and vertical semicircle have diameters of 7 in., are graduated in half-degrees, and read by vernier to single minutes. Both are rotated by rack and pinion movements. There is a tangent clamp and slow-motion screw to the horizontal circle. The telescope rests in Y-s attached to the vertical arc, and moves with this. The standards supporting the horizontal axis of rotation are fixed upon an adjustable stage, attached to the alidade plate by three capstan-headed screws. This stage carries the compass box, which has a 3-in. ring, graduated in degrees. The two telescopes are of precisely similar optical construction. Each has a 7-in. achromatic objective, with a 1·2-in. aperture, and a rack and pinion-focussing mechanism. Their eyepieces are erecting and consist of four lenses, with a draw-focussing mechanism. The supplementary telescope has a full azimuthal motion round the vertical axis of the instrument, and a small altitude movement. The construction of the parallel plate mounting is of the usual Ramsden type, with four levelling screws. There is a longitudinal spirit level fixed in adjustable bearings beneath the telescope, and two levels with their axes at right angles on the alidade plate.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1909–138.

Object entry information: This instrument, although made in the middle of the 19th century, retains most of the features characterising the Ramsden type of theodolite. Tangent clamps and slow-motion screws replace the Ramsden rack and pinion movements

title: 7 inch altazimuth theodolite by Troughton
description: 7 inch altazimuth theodolite by Troughton, early 19th century

Maker/Donor: Made by W. Harris.
Object entry information: This instrument, although made in the middle of the 19th century, retains most of the features characterising the Ramsden type of theodolite. Tangent clamps and slow-motion screws replace the Ramsden rack and pinion movements for both horizontal and vertical circles, and small reading microscopes are provided near the verniers. The supporting standards for the horizontal axis of rotation are not mounted upon an adjustable stage, as in Ramsden’s instruments, but are fixed directly to the alidade plate. The horizontal circle has a diameter of 6 in. and the vertical semicircle one of 5 in. Both are graduated in half-degrees and read by vernier to 1'. The telescope is mounted in Ys attached to the vertical arc. It has a 9-in. achromatic objective, with a 1-in. aperture and a rack-focussing arrangement. The eyepiece is erecting, with four lenses, and a draw-focussing mechanism. The diaphragm has one vertical and one horizontal wire. A sensitive longitudinal spirit level is fixed in adjustable bearings beneath the telescope. On the alidade there are two smaller levels at right angles to each other, and a 3-in. compass graduated in degrees. The parallel plates are of the usual Ramsden type, with four levelling screws.

title: Altazimuth theodolite, British, 1813-1839, with accessories
description: Altazimuth theodolite, 6 inch,  by W. Harris and Co., London, England, 1813-1839

Maker/Donor: Made by W. & T. Gilbert, London. Lent by T. H. Court, Esq.
Object entry information: This instrument, probably constructed about 1840, differs in many respects from the more usual Y-theodolite of the period. Its telescope is rigidly attached to the horizontal axis of rotation, which carries the vertical arc and rests in bearings upon two standards fixed to the rim of a case whose bottom forms the alidade. This case is closed at the top by a glass cover, so that the horizontal circle and compass are enclosed. Reading microscopes with prism reflectors are attached to the case for reading the verniers of the horizontal circle. Tangent clamps and slow-motion screws are fitted to both circles. The upper part of the instrument is suspended in a gimbal mounting within a hollow cylinder screwed upon the tripod plate, and can be levelled independently of the tripod by two screws threaded into the cylinder, with diametrically opposite springs. These screws press against a square nut fixed to the lower end of the axial cone which carries the horizontal circle. The 6-in. horizontal circle is graduated to 20' and read by vernier to 30''. The 5-in. vertical arc is similarly graduated and read by vernier, and has a range of 50° on either side of the zero mark. The telescope is achromatic, with a 1-in. aperture and 8-in. focal length. The objective is focussed by a rack and pinion mechanism. The eyepiece is a simple Ramsden inverting draw-focussing one, and the diaphragm has one vertical and one horizontal wire. A diagonal reflecting mirror can be attached in front of the objective for taking steep sights. There is one longitudinal adjustable spirit level attached beneath the telescope, and a parallel one fixed to the standards but no transverse level. The alidade carries a 3-in. compass, graduated in degrees.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 188.
Object name: ALTAZIMUTH THEODOLITE (Everest Type).
Maker/Donor: Made by T. Cooke & Sons. Presented by the Ordnance Survey.
Date of creation: late 19th-century
Object entry information: The Everest pattern theodolite, although not possessing the advantage of a transit instrument, has been much used by the British and Indian Survey departments since its inception, due to Sir George (then Captain) Everest, about the year 1835. The one exhibited is a late 19th-century 5-in. model, the horizontal circle and vertical arcs being graduated to 20' and read by two opposing verniers to 30''. In the Everest type of theodolite two opposing vertical arcs are used instead of a complete vertical circle, and the horizontal axis to which the telescope and arcs are fixed, is mounted upon two short standards projecting from a central pillar, supported on the horizontal vernier plate. The vernier bracket and attached spirit level are mounted on the axis, and are clamped to one standard by opposing screws. Two perpendicular spirit levels are likewise mounted on the horizontal vernier plate. The horizontal circle has a bevelled graduated edge and a separate mounting on the vertical axis cone. Thus the vernier plate and circle have independent motions, controlled by clamps and tangent screws, for repeating azimuth angles. All verniers are provided with reading microscopes. The instrument has a tribrach mounting, the feet of the three levelling screws resting in grooves in a trivet plate and being locked therein by a spring-controlled locking plate—also a feature of the original Everest design. The telescope has a rack-focussing objective of 1·2-in. aperture and 9-in. focal length, and a slide-focussing Ramsden eyepiece. Owing to the low standards, angles of elevation beyond 30° and of depression beyond 45° cannot be measured, as the telescope then fouls the horizontal plates. The vertical arcs consequently only extend about 50° on each side of the horizontal zeros.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1895–49.

title: Everest pattern altazimuth theodolite, with case,1885-1895
description: Everest pattern altazimuth theodolite, 5-inch, with case by T. Cooke & Sons, York, England, 1885-1895.

Maker/Donor: Made by Troughton & Simms.
Object entry information: The introduction of the transit principle into medium and small-sized theodolites in England took place in the early part of the 19th century. This exhibit is an early example of such a theodolite. Below the horizontal circle it resembles Ramsden's Y-theodolite, but the upper part has standards sufficiently high to permit the telescope to transit at either end. Both horizontal and vertical circles are 6 in. diam., divided on silver to 10′ and read by opposing verniers to 10″. The vernier plate and horizontal circle have independent axes of rotation for repeating angles, and are bevelled at the graduations to facilitate reading. Reading microscopes are provided for both circles, and also tangent clamps and slow-motion screws, as well as a similar clamp and screw connecting the vernier plate to the horizontal circle. The axis of this circle rests in a conical socket attached to the upper of two parallel levelling plates, connected by four screws and a ball and socket joint. The vernier plate carries a single spirit level, parallel to the transit axis, and a central circular compass box, with a 3½-in. stepped ring graduated in degrees. The needle, of rectangular section with its longer side vertical, is provided with a lifting lever for clamping it. The vertical circle is attached to the telescope and transit axis, and is read by horizontal verniers on a standard. This bracket carries the clamp and tangent screw. The other standard carries a spirit level perpendicular to the transit axis. The telescope, fixed in the centre of the transit axis, has a rack-focussing objective of 1⋅5-in. aperture and 10-in. focal length, a fixed diaphragm having one vertical and three equidistant horizontal wires, and a slide-focussing Ramsden eyepiece. A sensitive spirit level is mounted parallel to the axis of the telescope.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 190
Object name: TRANSIT THEODOLITE
Maker/Donor: Made by Thos. Jones. Presented by the Admiralty.
Date of creation: Early part of the 19th century
Object entry information: In this instrument, made in the early part of the 19th century, the 8½-in. horizontal and the 7¼-in. vertical circles are graduated every 10′ and read by vernier to 10″. The vertical circle and telescope are rigidly joined to the transit axis and rotate with it, the verniers being fixed to one standard. The horizontal circle and vernier plate can rotate independently about the vertical axis, for repeating azimuth angles. The three footscrews for levelling the instrument are fixed to the base circle of a framed stand having a central conical socket, into which fits the hollow conical axis attached beneath the horizontal circle. The axis of the vernier plate fits within this and is kept in position by a screw and washer fitted in its lower end and abutting against the socket in the stand. The vernier plate carries three symmetrically placed vernier arms, with reading microscopes suspended above their verniers, and is provided with a sensitive spirit level, with its axis perpendicular to the transit axis. The standards supporting the transit axis project from the vernier plate, and have Y-s at their upper ends, one of which is adjustable. The axis is kept in position in these Y-s by metal straps; it is hollow, and permits the telescope to be illuminated by means of a lamp supported by a bracket fixed to one standard. The vernier bracket for reading the vertical circle carries a spirit level parallel to its two vernier arms, for setting their zeros. It has a projecting piece which fits between screws fixed to the standard, and keeps the verniers stationary when the telescope and circle rotate. The telescope has a fixed objective of 11-in. focal length and 1⋅8-in. clear aperture, and a central mirror for illuminating the axis at night. The eyepiece tube can be focussed by a rack and pinion mechanism, and carries the diaphragm, having five vertical and one horizontal threads, and the inverting, draw-focussing eye-piece, which fits in a slide permitting a slight lateral motion of the eyepiece. Clamps and tangent screws for fine motion are fitted to both circles and the horizontal vernier plate.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1206.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 191
Object name: TRANSIT THEODOLITE
Maker/Donor: Made by Cary. Presented by the Admiralty.
Date of creation: Early 19th-century
Object entry information: This is an early 19th-century example of a medium-sized transit theodolite. The 10-in. vertical and horizontal circles are graduated on silver every 10′ and read by two opposing verniers to 10″ of arc. The telescope transits at the eyepiece end, and its axis can be illuminated for night reading through the hollow horizontal axis of rotation. The instrument is mounted upon a tribrach having three footscrews for levelling; these rest upon a plate screwed to the tripod head and are kept in position by a locking plate of the Everest pattern.

Maker/Donor: Made by Cary. Presented by the Admiralty.
Object entry information: This is an early 19th-century example of a medium-sized transit theodolite. The 10-in. vertical and horizontal circles are graduated on silver every 10′ and read by two opposing verniers to 10″ of arc. The telescope transits at the eyepiece end, and its axis can be illuminated for night reading through the hollow horizontal axis of rotation. The instrument is mounted upon a tribrach having three footscrews for levelling; these rest upon a plate screwed to the tripod head and are kept in position by a locking plate of the Everest pattern. The horizontal circle can rotate freely about the vertical axis, or can be clamped to it and rotated slowly by means of a tangent screw. The vernier plate can be similarly clamped to the horizontal circle, or rotated freely. Reading microscopes are fixed on brackets above each vernier. An adjustable spirit level is fixed to the vernier plate, perpendicular to the line joining the two standards which support the vertical circle and telescope. The vertical circle is mounted upon the axis of rotation of the telescope, and is read by verniers at the ends of a bracket fixed to one standard. Reading microscopes are attached to this bracket for use with each vernier, and a spirit level is mounted in adjustable bearings on the bracket with its axis parallel to the line joining the vernier zeros. A tangent clamp and slow-motion screw connects the vertical circle to one standard. Upon the top of the telescope, parallel to its axis, is set a 5-in. trough compass. The lamp for illuminating the telescope axis rests upon a bracket fixed to one standard, with its lens opposite the end of the horizontal axis of rotation. A mirror in the centre of the telescope reflects the light down its axis.

The axis of the vernier plate fits within this and is kept in position by a screw and washer fitted in its lower end and abutting against the socket in the stand. The vernier plate carries three symmetrically placed vernier arms, with reading microscopes suspended above their verniers, and is provided with a sensitive spirit level, with its axis perpendicular to the transit axis. The standards supporting the transit axis project from the vernier plate, and have Y-s at their upper ends, one of which is adjustable. The axis is kept in position in these Y-s by metal straps; it is hollow, and permits the telescope to be illuminated by means of a lamp supported by a bracket fixed to one standard. The vernier bracket for reading the vertical circle carries a spirit level parallel to its two vernier arms, for setting their zeros. It has a projecting piece which fits between screws fixed to the standard, and keeps the verniers stationary when the telescope and circle rotate. The telescope has a fixed objective of 11-in. focal length and 1⋅8-in. clear aperture, and a central mirror for illuminating the axis at night. The eyepiece tube can be focussed by a rack and pinion mechanism, and carries the diaphragm, having five vertical and one horizontal threads, and the inverting, draw-focussing eye-piece, which fits in a slide permitting a slight lateral motion of the eyepiece. Clamps and tangent screws for fine motion are fitted to both circles and the horizontal vernier plate.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876–1206.

The diaphragm is fixed in the eyepiece tube, which is focussed by a rack and pinion mechanism. There are three vertical and one horizontal wires. A diagonal erecting eyepiece is provided in addition to the normal inverting one. The telescope transits at the eyepiece end.

The telescope has a rack-focussing objective of aperture 1.1 in. and focal length 9.5 in. The diaphragm is fixed in the telescope tube and has two wires forming an acute angled cross instead of the usual vertical wire, together with a single horizontal wire. Maker/Donor: Made by Robinson, London. Lent by T. H. Court, Esq.
Date of creation: probably constructed in the middle of the 19th century
Object entry information: This is a highly compact transit theodolite, with vertical and horizontal circles of diameter 3.5 in., graduated in half-degrees and read by vernier to single minutes. It rests on three levelling screws, which can be fitted within three V-shaped notches in the top of the case. The instrument was probably constructed in the middle of the 19th century. The horizontal circle is fixed to the tribrach, which carries a supplementary telescope, tangential to the circle, for keeping the back station in view. A single central standard projects vertically from the horizontal circle, and serves as an axis for the hollow cylinder which carries the vernier bracket for the horizontal axis at its lower extremity, and a bracket to which is fixed the vertical circle at its upper end. The telescope is fixed to an arm carrying opposing verniers for the vertical circle, and can rotate with this arm about a horizontal axis through the top of the standard. A spirit level is attached to the back of the vertical circle, at right angles to the standard. Tangent clamps and slow-motion screws are fixed to the vernier brackets of both circles, and there are magnifying lenses for facilitating the reading of the vernier. There are three verniers to the horizontal circle, symmetrically disposed round its circumference. The vertical circle has two verniers at opposite ends of a diameter. The main and supplementary telescopes are of equal size and power. Their objectives have a focal length of 3.5 in., and a clear aperture of 0.6 in. They slide in the telescope tubes for focussing. The eyepieces are of the Ramsden type. Diaphragms fitted with cross wires are fixed inside the telescope tubes. The one on the main telescope has two vertical wires and one horizontal wire. A diagonal eyepiece is provided for taking steep sights. As the telescope is slightly eccentric to the vertical standard, a counterpoise to balance its weight is fitted on the standard.

Maker/Donor: Made by A. & R. Hahn, Cassel.
Object entry information: This is a repeating theodolite, made about 1875, and resembles the adjacent one by Fennel in general construction. It differs, however, in having an ordinary one-sided spirit level attached to the telescope, which has also a Huygens, not a Ramsden, eyepiece. The horizontal circle has a diameter of 14 cm., is graduated every 20' and read by two opposing verniers and reading microscopes to 30". The vertical circle, of 10.5 cm. diam., is divided to 30' and read by opposing verniers to single minutes. The telescope has a fixed objective, of 2.5 cm. clear aperture and with the field lens of the eyepiece, a focal length of 23 cm. The eyepiece is focussed by a rack and pinion arrangement, the cross-wire diaphragm being fixed between the two lenses. The telescope, rigidly attached to the horizontal axis and the vertical circle, transits at the eyepiece end, and has a sensitive longitudinal spirit level mounted on it in adjustable bearings. The vertical vernier bracket is screwed to one standard, whilst the other carries the tangent screw and clamping spring for the transit axis. The horizontal vernier plate carries a metal cover which protects the horizontal circle and supports a central circular spirit level, and the reading microscopes. There are windows in this plate above the verniers, and reflectors are attached to the microscopes for illuminating the field. The horizontal circle has a separate axis, with clamp and tangent screw for repetition. This fits in the socket fixed to the tribrach, which has three levelling screws furnished at their feet with small metal plates, to which they are connected by ball and socket joints. The instrument is connected to its tripod by the usual German central screw, with a flange and opposing spring which fix the instrument tightly, but on loosening the screw permit the theodolite to be displaced laterally for accurate centring over the station point.

On loosening this the theodolite can be moved laterally for centring above the station point.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876-1193.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 196
Object name: TRANSIT THEODOLITE
Maker/Donor: Made by A. & R. Hahn, Cassel.
Date of creation: about 1875
Object entry information: This is a repeating theodolite, made about 1875, and resembles the adjacent one by Fennel in general construction. It differs, however, in having an ordinary one-sided spirit level attached to the telescope, which has also a Huygens, not a Ramsden, eyepiece. The horizontal circle has a diameter of 14 cm., is graduated every 20' and read by two opposing verniers and reading microscopes to 30". The vertical circle, of 10.5 cm. diam., is divided to 30' and read by opposing verniers to single minutes. The telescope has a fixed objective, of 2.5 cm. clear aperture and with the field lens of the eyepiece, a focal length of 23 cm. The eyepiece is focussed by a rack and pinion arrangement, the cross-wire diaphragm being fixed between the two lenses. The telescope, rigidly attached to the horizontal axis and the vertical circle, transits at the eyepiece end, and has a sensitive longitudinal spirit level mounted on it in adjustable bearings. The vertical vernier bracket is screwed to one standard, whilst the other carries the tangent screw and clamping spring for the transit axis. The horizontal vernier plate carries a metal cover which protects the horizontal circle and supports a central circular spirit level, and the reading microscopes. There are windows in this plate above the verniers, and reflectors are attached to the microscopes for illuminating the field. The horizontal circle has a separate axis, with clamp and tangent screw for repetition. This fits in the socket fixed to the tribrach, which has three levelling screws furnished at their feet with small metal plates, to which they are connected by ball and socket joints. The instrument is connected to its tripod by the usual German central screw, with a flange and opposing spring which fix the instrument tightly, but on loosening the screw permit the theodolite to be displaced laterally for accurate centring over the station point.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876-1192.

Catalogue number: 197
Object name: TRANSIT THEODOLITE
Maker/Donor: Made by Dennert & Pape, Altona.
Date of creation: constructed about 1875
Object entry information: The horizontal circle and vernier plate in this instrument, which was constructed about 1875, have independent motions about the vertical axis, for repeating azimuth angles. Clamps and tangent screws are provided for both circles, and for the vertical circle. The horizontal and vertical circles have diameters 21 and 13 cm. respectively, are both covered, divided to 10' and read by opposing verniers and reading microscopes to 10". The telescope is mounted centrally on the horizontal axis, and can transit at either end. It has a fixed objective of aperture 3.5 cm. and focal length 25 cm., and a rack-focussing eyepiece tube, carrying a fixed cross-wire diaphragm and a screw-focussing inverting eyepiece. A sensitive spirit level is mounted in adjustable bearings longitudinally above the telescope, and another is fixed at right angles to this on the vernier plate, between the standards. The vertical circle is fixed to the telescope and transit axis, the vernier plate being fixed to one standard, and an axis clamp and tangent screw to the other. The trunnions on both standards are adjustable vertically. The instrument has a tribrach mounting, with three footscrews for levelling. The attachment for fixing the theodolite to the tripod is the central screw and spring usual in German instruments, which permits a lateral adjustment of the theodolite over the station point without moving the tripod.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876-1194.

title: Surveyor's transit theodolite.
description: Transit theodolite, 23-cm, by Dennert and Pape, Altona, Hamburg, Germany, 1876
material: brass (copper, zinc alloy); glass; metal (unknown); alcohol; steel (metal)

Maker/Donor: Made by J. Wanschaff, Berlin.
Object entry information: This instrument, constructed about 1875, has the telescope and vertical circle fixed at opposite extremities of the horizontal axis, outside the bearings. This arrangement reduces the height of the instrument and permits the telescope to transit completely, but has the disadvantage that the telescope is not centred above the station point. The horizontal circle has a diameter of 16 cm., is divided to 10' and read by opposing verniers and reading microscopes to 10". It is covered by a metal plate attached above the vernier plate, and fits fairly tightly on the vertical axis, but can be rotated independently for taking readings of an azimuth angle at various parts of the limb. The vernier plate has an axis clamp and tangent screw, and carries a central socket in which the vertical axis rotates. A horizontal bracket fixed across the top of this socket carries the bearings for the transit axis. Both bearings can be adjusted on the bracket, and tested for horizontality by a sensitive striding level. The transit axis has a clamp and slow-motion screw to fix it to the vertical socket. The vertical circle has a diameter of 10·5 cm., is divided to 20' and reads by opposing verniers fixed to the axis bracket and magnifying lenses to 1'. The telescope has a fixed objective of 2·5-cm. aperture and 22-cm. focal length, and a rack-focussing eyepiece tube carrying a fixed cross-wire diaphragm and a slide-focussing inverting eyepiece. The instrument is mounted on a tribrach, with three footscrews.

title: Theodolite with circles of 6 and 4 inches
description: Theodolite with circles of 6 and 4 inches, with spring fastening for plummet. Spirit level for the above

Maker/Donor: Made by Elliott Bros. Presented by the Admiralty.
Object entry information: This instrument was made at the end of the 19th century and used in the British Antarctic Expedition, 1901. It has 7-in. vertical and horizontal circles, graduated every 10' and reading by two opposing verniers and reading microscopes to 10". All adjustable screws and parts are covered with wash leather to protect the operator's fingers from frost. The horizontal and alidade circles are enclosed in a metal case, the verniers being covered by hinged plates. Clamps and tangent screws are fitted to both circles, and to the vertical circle, which is not covered, and is fixed to the transit axis. The vertical vernier bracket is clamped to a lug on one standard by opposing screws, and carries a sensitive spirit level perpendicular to the transit axis. The transit axis rests in Y-bearings on the standards, one trunnion being adjustable vertically, and is kept in position by metal retaining straps; it is hollow and has a lens at one end for illuminating the telescope axis. The telescope is rigidly fixed to this axis and transits at the eyepiece end only. It has an objective of 11-in. focal length and 1·5-in. aperture, focussed by a rack and pinion mechanism controlled from the eyepiece end. The diaphragm has one vertical and one horizontal thread, both adjustable laterally. Three slide focussing eyepieces are provided, one inverting, one diagonal, and one erecting. There is a central reflector in the telescope for illuminating its axis by light coming through the transit axis from a lamp fixed to one standard. A striding level is provided for testing the transit axis. The vernier cover plate carries a spirit level, with its axis parallel to the transit axis, whilst a perpendicular level is fixed to one standard. A central compass with a 4-in. ring graduated in degrees is attached to the vernier plate. The instrument has a tribrach mounting with three levelling footscrews, whose points rest in a trivet plate; this is provided with a locking plate of the Everest type attached to the tripod head.

Object name: TRAVELLER'S TRANSIT THEODOLITE.
Maker/Donor: Made by L. Casella.

Object entry information: This is a compact theodolite specially designed for Alpine and military surveying. It has 3-in. vertical and horizontal circles, divided to half-degrees and read by verniers to single minutes. A diagonal eyepiece is provided for astronomical observations of stars near the zenith. The construction of the instrument is similar to that of a modern vernier theodolite of twice the size. The transit axis rests on standards projecting from the vernier plate, and carries a central telescope and the vertical circle fixed to it. The vernier arm projects from one standard, and a tangent clamp and slow-motion screw is fitted to the other, which also carries a spirit level perpendicular to the transit axis. A similar level parallel to the transit axis is fixed on the vernier plate, which also carries a central compass box, having a 1-in. ring divided in degrees. The compass needle is provided with a lifting lever for clamping it when desired. The vernier plate rotates independently about the vertical axis and has a clamp and tangent screw for connecting it to the horizontal circle, which has a similar clamp and tangent screw connecting it to the tribrach. This latter has three footscrews, with their feet clamped in a trivet plate by a locking plate of the Everest type. The trivet plate can be screwed to the tripod head. Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 201.
Object name: ENGINEER'S TRANSIT THEODOLITE.
Maker/Donor: Made by W. & L. E. Gurley, Troy, New York.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This instrument illustrates many of the characteristics of modern American transit theodolites of the type used in reconnaissance and engineering surveying. The solar attachment to the telescope for determining meridians and latitudes by observations on the sun is a special feature, whilst the levelling base, with its "shifting centre" and four footscrews, is typical of American construction.
The horizontal circle has a diameter of 6·25 in. and is graduated on silver to 30', reading by two opposite verniers to 1'. It is covered by a metal plate attached to the vernier plate and having windows above the verniers. The graduations on the limb are in two sets, one completely round the circle from 0° to 360°, the other in four quadrants from 0° to 90°. The figures are slightly inclined in the direction of increasing numbers. The vernier cover plate carries two spirit levels with their axes respectively parallel and at right angles to the transit axis. A large compass box, with a 5-in. ring graduated in half-degrees, is so mounted on the centre of the plate that its ring can be rotated in its own plane by a rack and pinion arrangement. The pivot of the needle is attached to a large plate, which can be lifted as a whole for clamping the needle. The standards for the transit axis terminate in Y-bearings, one of which is adjustable. The transit axis carries at one end a small spirit level, which can rotate about it, and be clamped in any position to rotate with the axis. At the opposite end is similarly mounted the vertical arc, its vernier being adjustably fixed to the corresponding standard. The arc is graduated every 20' and reads by vernier to 30'; angles of elevation or depression up to 80° can be read. The telescope rigidly fixed to the axis transits at either end. It has an 11 in. objective, of 13/16ths in. aperture, with a rack and pinion focussing movement, and an erecting eyepiece of magnification 26 diam., also rack focussing. Three parallel horizontal and one vertical platinum wires are mounted in the diaphragm, the two outer horizontal ones being for stadia work. A sensitive level, 7½-in. long, with a metal scale for reading the bubble is mounted beneath the telescope and can be adjusted by capstan screws at both ends.
The solar attachment is of the type invented by Burt, and is fixed to the top of the telescope, with its polar axis perpendicular to that of the telescope and the transit axis. This axis, and the hour circle attached to it, can be adjusted on the telescope to ensure perpendicularity. The hour circle is graduated every 5', and has a diameter of 1·5 in. The declination arc, movable about the polar axis, has a radius of 5 in., with a silver limb graduated every 15' from 0° to 33°, and read by a vernier on the sighting arm to 30". This sighting arm is mounted on the centre of the arc, and can be rotated with respect to it by a fine threaded screw. At each end of the arm is fixed a lens with a pin-hole stop and a silver reflecting plate on which are engraved parallel lines in two perpendicular directions, at a distance apart equal to the diameter of the sun's image. In using this attachment to find the true meridian, the co-latitude of the place is set off on the vertical arc, the declination of the sun and time on the arc, and the hour on its circle, and the telescope is then rotated in azimuth until the sun's image, caused by refraction through the lens of the sighting arm, falls exactly between the lines on the mirror. The telescope and polar axis are then in the meridian.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914-741.

Maker/Donor: Made and lent by C. F. Casella & Co., Ltd.
Object entry information: This is a 5-in. vernier theodolite of modern construction, the telescope having a fixed objective and internal focussing lens. A gradienter scale is fitted to the clamp of the vertical circle and is used for measuring distances. of 4 in. is divided to 20' and read by opposing verniers and microscopes to 30". A sensitive spirit level is fixed to the vernier bracket, perpendicular to the transit axis. The telescope has a fixed objective of 1.25 in. aperture, and an internal lens, movable for focussing by means of a central screw operating the rack and pinion. This screw is conveniently placed at one end of the transit axis. The eyepiece is inverting, screw focussing and magnifies 20 diam. It can readily be removed to permit access to the diaphragm, which is fixed in the main telescope tube and is of the star pattern, with one horizontal and two equally inclined wires intersecting on the former. The gradienter scale is fixed to the clamping bracket of the vertical circle, the head of the tangent screw having a graduated drum reading hundredths of the scale divisions, each of which is one-hundredth of the distance between the transit axis and the axis of the tangent screw. In using the scale for measuring distances, the altitude introduces a factor depending on the square of its cosine. The instrument has a tribrach mounting with three levelling screws, the feet of which rest in grooves in a trivet stage and are kept fixed by a locking plate. A knurled clamping screw serves to fix this stage to the tripod head, permitting a small centring movement without disturbing the tripod.

Object/Inventory number: N/A

Maker/Donor: Made and lent by E. R. Watts & Son, Ltd.
Object entry information: The 4.6-in. horizontal and 4-in. vertical circles in this instrument are divided on silver to 20' and read by two opposing verniers and reading microscopes to 20". The telescope has an internal focussing lens and transits at both ends. The horizontal circle is enclosed in a dustproof and waterproof box, fixed to the vernier plate. The theodolite is clamped to the levelling tribrach by a centring device which permits the vertical axis to be set over the station point without moving the tribrach and tripod. The telescope has a fixed objective of 1.7 in. aperture and a fixed glass diaphragm on which are engraved the usual cross lines and stadia lines. Owing to the anallatic properties of the internal focussing lens, no "constant" is necessary when using the theodolite as a tacheometer. The eyepiece is inverting and screw focussing. The transit axis, on which are fixed the telescope and vertical circle, is permanently fixed on the standards, but the bearing at one end can be adjusted by means of a capstan screw. The horizontal circle is mounted on a repeating stage and has a separate axis clamp and tangent screw, carefully distinguished in shape from those operating the plate motion. The vertical vernier bracket is fixed adjustably to the standard in the ordinary manner, and carries the usual spirit level with its axis parallel to the vernier zeros. A similar bubble tube is mounted on the horizontal plate, parallel to the transit axis, and a very small bubble is fixed across one standard, perpendicular to the transit axis. A trough compass with the usual edge-bar needle and lifting arrangement is screwed across the other standard, and can be detached if required. The feet of the three levelling foot-screws are tightly clamped in a trivet stage which screws on the tripod head, but has also pointed feet for setting it on a platform when the tripod is not necessary. The heads of the footscrews have dustproof caps, threaded in the tribrach; these also serve to take up any wear on the footscrews. The graduation of the circles and the numbering of the divisions at every 5° are very distinct.

Catalogue number: 204.
Object name: MICROMETER MICROSCOPE TRANSIT THEODOLITE.
Maker/Donor: Made by A. Lingke & Co., Freiberg. Lent by the Admiralty.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The precision of small theodolites has been greatly enhanced in recent years by the provision of micrometer microscopes for reading the circles to within a few seconds. The instrument exhibited, salved from a German warship sunk at Scapa, illustrates a type of theodolite of Continental design, with micrometer reading to both circles, the telescope and vertical circle being mounted eccentrically at one end of the transit axis. The horizontal and vertical circles, of diameters 14 cm. and 13 cm. respectively, are graduated on silver to 10' and read by two opposing micrometer microscopes to 2", the micrometer drums being graduated every 20", and the tenths estimated. The eccentric arrangement of the telescope has obvious disadvantages, but permits the telescope to transit independently of the height of the standards above the horizontal circle, and also enables longer microscopes to be employed with the vertical circle than is possible when the telescope is above the vertical axis.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Maker/Donor: Made by A. Lingke & Co., Freiberg. Lent by the Admiralty.
Object entry information: The precision of small theodolites has been greatly enhanced in recent years by the provision of micrometer microscopes for reading the circles to within a few seconds. The instrument exhibited, salved from a German warship sunk at Scapa, illustrates a type of theodolite of Continental design, with micrometer reading to both circles, the telescope and vertical circle being mounted eccentrically at one end of the transit axis. The horizontal and vertical circles, of diameters 14 cm. and 13 cm. respectively, are graduated on silver to 10' and read by two opposing micrometer microscopes to 2", the micrometer drums being graduated every 20", and the tenths estimated. The eccentric arrangement of the telescope has obvious disadvantages, but permits the telescope to transit independently of the height of the standards above the horizontal circle, and also enables longer microscopes to be employed with the vertical circle than is possible when the telescope is above the vertical axis. These microscopes are mounted in a stage which is set on the transit axis and is permitted a slight rotation about this by means of a tangent screw attached to one standard. The stage carries a spirit level mounted in adjustable bearings, whereby the microscope can be set accurately horizontal. A second adjacent bracket on the transit axis, to which it can be clamped, preventing fouling the microscope by stops, which abut against the vertical axial cone, but allow a small motion of the level. A separate axis clamp is connected with the tangent screw fitted to the second standard, and when tightened, permits a slow motion only of the transit axis. The telescope is screwed upon one end of this axis, the vertical circle being attached to it by a friction clutch permitting independent setting of the circle, but ensuring that the telescope and circle move together with the axis. An auxiliary vertical circle, 10-cm. diam., graduated in degrees and read by index, is mounted on the other end of the transit axis, and serves both to balance the instrument and to check the larger units of the vertical reading. The standards are fixed to a central hollow conical socket, and also carry the brackets supporting the two horizontal reading micrometer microscopes. This conical socket revolves about a central cone carried by the horizontal circle, which is fixed to the tribrach, and is provided with an axis clamp and tangent screw for slow motion. The telescope has a sliding eyepiece, actuated by a rack and pinion arrangement and a fixed objective, of 22-cm. focal length and 2-5-cm. aperture. The eyepiece tube carries the diaphragm and a screw-focussing inverting eyepiece.

Object name: MICROMETER TRANSIT THEODOLITE. Made and lent
Maker/Donor: by T. Cooke & Sons, Ltd.
Object entry information: This design of a small transit theodolite exhibits many special features which render it capable of very accurate work. The horizontal circle, of 5-in. diam. and graduated directly to 10ʹ, is completely enclosed in a metal sheath and is read by two micrometer microscopes to 10ʹ, or even less by estimation. The vertical circle is likewise graduated and read, but is not enclosed. The telescope is focussed by means of an internal lens, the position of which can be varied by rotating a milled screw at one end of the transit axis. In other respects the theodolite resembles an ordinary modern vernier reading type, with the usual tribrach mounting, the feet of the three levelling screws being clamped in a trivet plate which screws on to the tripod head. Tangent clamps and slow-motion screws are fitted to the independently rotating horizontal plate and limb, as also to the vertical circle, which is fixed to the transit axis. The microscopes for the horizontal circle are held rigidly by brackets projecting from the cover plate, and are “broken” near their eyepiece ends, so that they can be read more comfortably. At the other end their tubes are attached to the cover plate by translucent glass tubes which exclude dust but permit illumination of the limb. The microscopes for reading the vertical circle are rigidly fixed to a bracket to which is attached a long spirit level, perpendicular to the transit axis, and which by means of a projecting tongue. A perpendicular spirit level is also mounted on the cover plate. Both levels can be adjusted. The telescope is mounted centrally on the transit axis and transits at either end. It has a 1·5 in. aperture objective lens, internal focussing lens and a screw-focussing inverting eyepiece of magnification 25 diam. The diaphragm is of glass, and has horizontal stadia lines of 1 : 100 ratio on each side of the main line, and is so fixed that, by a special key, it can be withdrawn and cleaned without upsetting the collimation setting. A special type of trough compass, with a flat-nosed needle, read from one end, can be screwed to one of the standards. The needle is clamped or released by turning the milled screw at the non-reading end.

The microscopes for the horizontal circle are held rigidly by brackets projecting from the cover plate, and are “broken” near their eyepiece ends, so that they can be read more comfortably. At the other end their tubes are attached to the cover plate by translucent glass tubes which exclude dust but permit illumination of the limb. The microscopes for reading the vertical circle are rigidly fixed to a bracket to which is attached a long spirit level, perpendicular to the transit axis, and which by means of a projecting tongue. A perpendicular spirit level is also mounted on the cover plate. Both levels can be adjusted. The telescope is mounted centrally on the transit axis and transits at either end. It has a 1·5 in. aperture objective lens, internal focussing lens and a screw-focussing inverting eyepiece of magnification 25 diam. The diaphragm is of glass, and has horizontal stadia lines of 1 : 100 ratio on each side of the main line, and is so fixed that, by a special key, it can be withdrawn and cleaned without upsetting the collimation setting. A special type of trough compass, with a flat-nosed needle, read from one end, can be screwed to one of the standards. The needle is clamped or released by turning the milled screw at the non-reading end.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922-205.

Object name: MICROMETER TRANSIT THEODOLITE. Made and lent
Maker/Donor: by E. R. Watts and Son, Ltd.
Object entry information: In this example of a modern theodolite of small size, both the vertical and horizontal circles are read by two opposing micrometer microscopes, rigidly fixed to the standards; the objective tubes of these microscopes are vertical, but prismatic reflectors are fitted to deflect the light into the horizontal eyepieces and also, in the case of the vertical circle microscopes, into the objectives. Both circles have a diameter of 5 in. and are divided on silver to 10ʹ, every degree being numbered. The micrometer drums are graduated into sixty parts, each division thus corresponding to 10″ on the circle; it is, however, quite easy to set the micrometer wire to within a single second of arc, and to read the drum to this amount. The circles are both enclosed completely in dustproof metal boxes, fixed to the standards. The telescope is centrally mounted on the transit axis, and has a fixed objective of 1.5-in. aperture and 8-in. focal length; its tube is dustproof, being terminated at the other end by a fixed glass diaphragm upon which the image is focussed by means of a movable internal concave lens, operated by a milled screw outside the tube. Slide-focussing eyepieces of different powers are provided. The vertical circle is fixed to one side of the telescope and revolves with it on the transit axis. The horizontal circle can revolve independently of the upper plate for repeating azimuth angles, and has a separate axis clamp and tangent screw for slow motion. The instrument has a tribrach mounting, with three levelling footscrews. A self-centring arrangement is fitted whereby the vertical axis can be displaced laterally through a range of $\frac{1}{4}$ in. in any direction without disturbing the tribrach or the tripod to which it is screwed. Two small bubble tubes are fixed to the horizontal cover plate with their axes respectively perpendicular and parallel to the transit axis; a more sensitive level is mounted on the vertical microscope brackets, and a specially sensitive striding level is provided for testing the horizontality of the transit axis.

Object entry information: These microscopes are mounted in a stage which is set on the transit axis and is permitted a slight rotation about this by means of a tangent screw attached to one standard. The stage carries a spirit level mounted in adjustable bearings, whereby the microscope can be set accurately horizontal. A second adjacent bracket on the transit axis, to which it can be clamped, preventing fouling the microscope by stops, which abut against the vertical axial cone, but allow a small motion of the level. A separate axis clamp is connected with the tangent screw fitted to the second standard, and when tightened, permits a slow motion only of the transit axis. The telescope is screwed upon one end of this axis, the vertical circle being attached to it by a friction clutch permitting independent setting of the circle, but ensuring that the telescope and circle move together with the axis. An auxiliary vertical circle, 10-cm. diam., graduated in degrees and read by index, is mounted on the other end of the transit axis, and serves both to balance the instrument and to check the larger units of the vertical reading. The standards are fixed to a central hollow conical socket, and also carry the brackets supporting the two horizontal reading micrometer microscopes. This conical socket revolves about a central cone carried by the horizontal circle, which is fixed to the tribrach, and is provided with an axis clamp and tangent screw for slow motion. The telescope has a sliding eyepiece, actuated by a rack and pinion arrangement and a fixed objective, of 22-cm. focal length and 2-5-cm. aperture. The eyepiece tube carries the diaphragm and a screw-focussing inverting eyepiece.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-88.

Object entry information: This is a 17th-century instrument for measuring angles in either a vertical or a horizontal plane. It consists of a wooden rectangular frame to which can be screwed a brass socket in either of two positions for setting the plane of the rectangle horizontal or vertical. Two adjacent sides of the rectangle have folding brass sights at their corners for setting off right angles. A movable brass index arm, provided with folding sights, is centred on one of the sighted sides of the rectangle and rotates over a brass scale mounted on the other side. This scale is graduated to read tangents, to the nearest tenth. A clamp and screw fixed to the index arm serve to clamp it in any desired position to a brass arc fixed to the rectangle. The outer sight on the arm carries a plumb-line when the rectangle is horizontal. When vertical angles are being measured, the plumb-line is detached and fixed to a screw so that it hangs parallel to the brass scale in the plane of the rectangle.
