Catalogue number: 208.
Object name: TROUGHTON DIP SECTOR.
Maker/Donor: Made by Thos. Jones. Presented by the Admiralty.
Date of creation: early part of the 19th century
Object entry information: The Dip-Sector was first designed and made by Troughton for measuring the "dip of the horizon" from an elevated observing point. The example shown was made in the early part of the 19th century. The graduated sector, index arm, index mirror and horizon mirror are the same as in the sextant, but the telescope has its eyepiece at right angles to its objective, a reflecting mirror being interposed between the two. This enables the observer to measure the zenith angle between the apparent horizon lines to his left and right. By rotating the handle through a half turn, he can measure the corresponding nadir angle. The quarter of the difference between these two readings is the required dip angle between his apparent and true horizons. The index error is eliminated in this method. The sector has a radius of 7 in. and is divided on silver from 5° to 40° every 10' and read by vernier to 10". The actual angles are only half the graduation angle, as in the sextant, but the angle read is the correct one between the two sight lines. The horizon mirror, fixed to the sector, is partly silvered and partly unsilvered. The index glass, which rotates with the index arm, is wholly silvered, and has a central index. The arm carries the vernier, and can be clamped to the sector at any point, further rotation being effected by a tangent screw. The telescope can be adjusted to vary its lateral distance from the sector by a screw, and the handle can be rotated and clamped in any position parallel to the face of the sector.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1876-1207.

title: Brass dip sector.
description: Dip sector made by Thomas Jones, London, about 1845. Lacquered brass frame and index arm, polished limb, a hinged wooden handle. Signed on the limb: Thomas Jones 62 Charing Cross London. Marked on the limb: I 1. Inlaid silver scale from -5° to 40° every 10' (from left to right). Silver vernier by 10", zero at the left. The double-ended tangent screw and the clamping screw are on the back of the index arm. No shades. Index-glass adjustment by screw; adjustment of the horizon glass by capstan screws. A detached magnifier. Threaded telescope bracket in two parts, fitted for correcting collimation error by capstan screws; perpendicular adjustment by rising-piece and a milled knob. Telescope in two parts at a right angle, containing a prism; a shaded eyepiece (grey). No box. The observer looks through the telescope and sees reflections of the horizon on either side of him, at an angle of 180°. The horizons are brought into one line by moving the index arm, and the dip or rise of the horizon is read from the scale. I 1 was the Hydrographic Office serial numbering adopted in February 1828, where I was the letter presumably given to dip sectors.
place: Charing Cross, City of Westminster, London, England, United Kingdom

Maker/Donor: Made and lent by Newton & Co.
Object entry information: This example is typical of the box sextant invented by William Jones at the beginning of the 19th century. In principle, it measures angles like the sextant, but its fixed and movable mirrors are enclosed in a circular brass box, which has an aperture sighting hole and opposing window cut in its circular side. The index mirror is rotated from without the box by means of a milled head and pinion gears, and the external vernier arm is fixed on the same pivot axis as this mirror and measures its rotation on a graduated arc engraved on a silver strip embedded in the upper external surface of the box.

Object entry information: an aperture sighting hole and opposing window cut in its circular side. The index mirror is rotated from without the box by means of a milled head and pinion gears, and the external vernier arm is fixed on the same pivot axis as this mirror and measures its rotation on a graduated arc engraved on a silver strip embedded in the upper external surface of the box.
The arc is divided to quarter-degrees, numbered as if they were half-degrees, since the angle sighted is double the angle through which the index mirror and arm rotate, and is read by vernier on the index arm to single minutes; a pivoted magnifying lens is fitted for assisting the reading of the vernier. The brass cover which protects the external parts when the instrument is not in use, can be screwed to the under part of the box when sights are taken, and serves as a hand grip. The radius of the divided arc is only 2 in., so that the instrument is less accurate than an ordinary sextant, but it is preferred for rough reconnaissance surveying on account of its portability and the protection of its parts afforded by the box.
The horizon mirror can be adjusted from outside the box by means of a key, and coloured glasses are provided for taking sights on the sun.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1865-5.

Object name: PAGET ANGLE SEXTANT.
Maker/Donor: Made by Hughes & Son. Presented by the Admiralty.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This instrument is very similar to the ordinary box sextant with open sides and is used for measuring angles in any plane. One object is viewed directly through a lateral aperture and the unsilvered half of a fixed mirror, whilst the other is viewed after double reflection at the surface of a rotating mirror and the silvered half of the fixed one.
An index geared to the rotating mirror measures the angle between the two objects on the graduated limb of the top surface of the instrument. A hand grip is screwed to the bottom surface. The index arm is so geared to the revolving mirror that it rotates through four times the angle through which this mirror turns; this is twice the angle through which the doubly reflected ray rotates. Hence the limb is graduated in degrees, numbered as if they were half-degrees. Both mirrors have their faces perpendicular to the plane of the angle measured. A metal index in front of the axis of the rotating mirror marks the central line of sight.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911-220.

Object entry information: This instrument is a crude form of altazimuth theodolite, designed for approximately locating the position of aerial objects. The altitude and azimuth angles of such an object can be measured at any moment to the nearest tenth of a degree.
It consists of a massive, horizontal, graduated circle of 16 in. diam., divided in degrees and read by estimation to the nearest tenth-degree by means of the pointed end of a rotating alidade, pivoted at the centre of the circle. Three footscrews and a pair of perpendicular spirit levels are fixed to the circle for levelling it. The feet of the footscrews rest on three footplates, of which the upper surfaces have a plane, a straight groove and a conical hole respectively. The footplates are fixed to a stand and serve to keep the circle fixed without straining it. The alidade has a vertical bracket fixed at the end opposite to its pointer for supporting the vertical arc and sighting tube, which are pivoted about a horizontal axis at its upper extremity. The vertical arc is a quadrant of 8 in. radius, graduated in degrees and read by an index fixed to the bracket. The sighting tube is fixed parallel to one radius of the quadrant and moves with it. It carries a blade foresight and aperture backsight, the latter having a rubber protecting eyepiece. There are no clamps to the motions, the friction at the pivots being great enough to prevent the instrument moving after it has been set. Two small electric bulbs set in conical reflectors on the alidade can illuminate the circles for night reading, a battery and operating switch for this purpose being provided and exhibited with the instrument.

Object entry information: an aperture sighting hole and opposing window cut in its circular side. The index mirror is rotated from without the box by means of a milled head and pinion gears, and the external vernier arm is fixed on the same pivot axis as this mirror and measures its rotation on a graduated arc engraved on a silver strip embedded in the upper external surface of the box.
The arc is divided to quarter-degrees, numbered as if they were half-degrees, since the angle sighted is double the angle through which the index mirror and arm rotate, and is read by vernier on the index arm to single minutes; a pivoted magnifying lens is fitted for assisting the reading of the vernier. The brass cover which protects the external parts when the instrument is not in use, can be screwed to the under part of the box when sights are taken, and serves as a hand grip. The radius of the divided arc is only 2 in., so that the instrument is less accurate than an ordinary sextant, but it is preferred for rough reconnaissance surveying on account of its portability and the protection of its parts afforded by the box.
The horizon mirror can be adjusted from outside the box by means of a key, and coloured glasses are provided for taking sights on the sun.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1865-5.

Object name: PAGET ANGLE SEXTANT.
Maker/Donor: Made by Hughes & Son. Presented by the Admiralty.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This instrument is very similar to the ordinary box sextant with open sides and is used for measuring angles in any plane. One object is viewed directly through a lateral aperture and the unsilvered half of a fixed mirror, whilst the other is viewed after double reflection at the surface of a rotating mirror and the silvered half of the fixed one.
An index geared to the rotating mirror measures the angle between the two objects on the graduated limb of the top surface of the instrument. A hand grip is screwed to the bottom surface. The index arm is so geared to the revolving mirror that it rotates through four times the angle through which this mirror turns; this is twice the angle through which the doubly reflected ray rotates. Hence the limb is graduated in degrees, numbered as if they were half-degrees. Both mirrors have their faces perpendicular to the plane of the angle measured. A metal index in front of the axis of the rotating mirror marks the central line of sight.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911-220.

Object entry information: This instrument, probably of fairly modern French construction, has a hollow brass cylinder of 13 cm. diam., divided into two parts independently movable about the common vertical axis, instead of the horizontal and vernier plates of an ordinary theodolite. bearings between these standards and is used for setting the axis of the cylinder vertical. The curved face of this half is pierced by two pairs of vertical sighting slits at opposite ends of perpendicular diameters, and the lower circular edge, which is in contact with the lower half cylinder, has two opposing vernier scales engraved on it. The corresponding edge of the lower half is graduated in degrees, and read by the verniers to 2'. This half, which has a single pair of vertical sighting slits pierced in its surfaces, is mounted upon a tribrach provided with the usual three footscrews, and is fitted with a clamp and tangent screw for slow motion. The upper half cylinder can be rotated with respect to the lower half by a toothed wheel and pinion mechanism, actuated by a milled screw beneath the cylinder. The telescope is mounted so as to be always in the same vertical plane as the vernier zeros of the upper half cylinder. It has a fixed objective of 1-in. aperture and 7-in. focal length, and a rack-focussing eyepiece tube with a slide-focussing inverting eyepiece. The head of the tripod used with this instrument is also exhibited and illustrates the type usual in French construction. It is of wood, with brass slots for the feet of the tribrach, and is connected to the theodolite by a central plunger screw with opposing spring, which permits the small displacement of the instrument necessary for setting it horizontal.

title: Cross-staff head with telescope
description: Adjustable cross-staff head with telescope on tripod stand, European, 1880-1899

Maker/Donor: Made by Troughton & Simms. Lent by the War Office.
Object entry information: This instrument was designed during the war, 1914-18, for surveying from the front line trenches. The periscope attachment to the objective end of the telescope enables the observer to take azimuth angles without exposing himself or the theodolite. The latter is similar to an ordinary 3-in. vernier theodolite, except that the telescope is "broken" by a diagonal mirror in the transit axis, one half of which is hollow and forms the eyepiece tube, perpendicular to the objective tube. When in use the objective tube is vertical, pointing to the zenith, and a counterpoise fixed to its lower end below the transit axis balances the weight of the periscope. The axis of rotation of the periscope mirror is perpendicular to the transit axis, and the mirror is adjusted about this axis by means of a long brass chain. This adjustment varies the vertical angle of the line of sight, but does not change its azimuth. The 3-in. horizontal circle is graduated in half-degrees and read by opposing verniers and readers to 1'. A similar vertical circle is attached to the transit axis and read by opposing verniers fixed to the standards, but is not used with the periscope attachment. The horizontal vernier plate covers the divided circle except at the verniers and carries a spirit-level parallel to the transit axis. A perpendicular spirit-level is attached to the vertical vernier bracket. A trough compass is fitted beneath the horizontal circle and rotates with it about the vertical axis. Clamps and tangent screws are fitted to the vertical and horizontal circles, and the horizontal vernier plate. The theodolite has a tribrach mounting, with three levelling screws, which rest in a trivet stage and are locked in position by a locking plate of the Everest type. A shifting centre arrangement serves to attach the trivet stage to the tripod head, but permits a relative horizontal displacement of the two when the clamping screw is loosened.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 214.
Object name: THREE READING MICROSCOPES.
Maker/Donor: Made by O. Fennel Söhne, Cassel.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: These represent three types of microscope for reading the circles of small theodolites. In each case, the circles are completely enclosed in metal, dust-proof cases, and the microscopes are consequently provided with mirror reflecting tubes for illuminating the graduations. The first microscope is a "Schätz" or "Estimation" Microscope, and has a single fixed line marked in its focal plane, parallel to the graduations of the circle. It is used in theodolites having 10-cm. circles, graduated every 10'. The position of the fixed microscope line between these graduations is estimated to a single minute. (See "Zeitschrift für Vermessungswesen," 1902, p. 214-216.) The second microscope, known as a "Nonien-Mikroskop," has a fixed vernier scale marked in its focal plane, and is used for theodolites having 13-cm. circles graduated to 5'. Ten divisions of the vernier scale correspond to nine of the circle, whence the position of the zero vernier line can be read to 30", or even to 15" by estimation. Alternate graduations of the vernier scale are numbered consecutively from 0 to 5, and represent minutes. (See "Zeitschrift für Instrumentenkunde," 1912, Part V.)
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Maker/Donor: Made by O. Fennel Söhne, Cassel.; Hensoldt
Object entry information: These represent three types of microscope for reading the circles of small theodolites. In each case, the circles are completely enclosed in metal, dust-proof cases, and the microscopes are consequently provided with mirror reflecting tubes for illuminating the graduations. The first microscope is a "Schätz" or "Estimation" Microscope, and has a single fixed line marked in its focal plane, parallel to the graduations of the circle. It is used in theodolites having 10-cm. circles, graduated every 10'. The position of the fixed microscope line between these graduations is estimated to a single minute. (See "Zeitschrift für Vermessungswesen," 1902, p. 214-216.) The second microscope, known as a "Nonien-Mikroskop," has a fixed vernier scale marked in its focal plane, and is used for theodolites having 13-cm. circles graduated to 5'. Ten divisions of the vernier scale correspond to nine of the circle, whence the position of the zero vernier line can be read to 30", or even to 15" by estimation. Alternate graduations of the vernier scale are numbered consecutively from 0 to 5, and represent minutes. (See "Zeitschrift für Instrumentenkunde," 1912, Part V.) The third microscope, designated a "Skalen-Mikroskop," is of the type devised by Hensoldt in 1870, and is used on theodolites having 13·5-cm. circles, graduated in 20'. A fixed scale in the focal plane of the microscope has ten divisions, numbered right to left, exactly covering the interval between consecutive graduations of the circle. The position of one circle graduation on this scale can be read to one-tenth of a scale division, i.e., to 12". In this and the second microscope, the reading edges of the two scales slightly overlap each other, which ensures a sharper reading. (See "Zeitschrift für Vermessungswesen," 1879, pp. 497–507.)

Maker/Donor: Made and lent by T. Cooke & Sons, Ltd., York.
Object entry information: For setting up a surveying instrument on uneven ground, the tripod head is often provided with an arrangement permitting the instrument to be quickly levelled, without moving the legs of the tripod or the foot-screws, which last are only used in the final accurate levelling. Such a device is here exhibited. The trivet stage of the instrument is screwed to a central spherical section of a hollow ball, which fits sufficiently closely into a spherical socket fixed to the tripod legs to prevent any motion other than a rotation of the ball in the socket, permitting the top of the ball to be levelled irrespective of the top of the tripod socket. A circumferential clamp, provided with three thumb pieces, is threaded upon the outside of the socket, and serves to clamp the ball tightly within this when the instrument is approximately level, as shown by a small circular spirit level fixed in the top of the ball. A shank attached beneath the top plate of the ball marks its centre, and has a loop of cord attached for centring the instrument over the station point.

Catalogue number: 216.
Object name: SHIFTING CENTRE TRIPOD HEAD.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by T. Cooke & Sons, Ltd., York.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This tripod head is fitted with a "shifting centre" arrangement, permitting the centre of the attached theodolite to be displaced any distance up to about 1 in. in any direction without removing the theodolite from the tripod or altering the position of this latter. This property is very useful in setting the theodolite accurately over the station point. The tripod head consists of five metal parts, namely a threaded plate to which the theodolite is screwed, a shoulder plate to which the tripod legs are attached, and three other parts which together form a collar, between the flanges of which the other two plates can be clamped. The outer diameter of the collar is 1½ in., whilst the theodolite base plate and tripod shoulder plate have central apertures 2 in. and 2⅛ in. diam. respectively, so that either of them can be moved between the flanges independently, and clamped in the required relative position. A small circular spirit level is embedded in the top of the tripod plate and is used to set this approximately level.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-539.

Object entry information: The third microscope, designated a "Skalen-Mikroskop," is of the type devised by Hensoldt in 1870, and is used on theodolites having 13·5-cm. circles, graduated in 20'. A fixed scale in the focal plane of the microscope has ten divisions, numbered right to left, exactly covering the interval between consecutive graduations of the circle. The position of one circle graduation on this scale can be read to one-tenth of a scale division, i.e., to 12". In this and the second microscope, the reading edges of the two scales slightly overlap each other, which ensures a sharper reading. (See "Zeitschrift für Vermessungswesen," 1879, pp. 497–507.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914-553. 554. 555.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 215.
Object name: QUICK-LEVELLING TRIPOD HEAD.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by T. Cooke & Sons, Ltd., York.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: For setting up a surveying instrument on uneven ground, the tripod head is often provided with an arrangement permitting the instrument to be quickly levelled, without moving the legs of the tripod or the foot-screws, which last are only used in the final accurate levelling. Such a device is here exhibited. The trivet stage of the instrument is screwed to a central spherical section of a hollow ball, which fits sufficiently closely into a spherical socket fixed to the tripod legs to prevent any motion other than a rotation of the ball in the socket, permitting the top of the ball to be levelled irrespective of the top of the tripod socket. A circumferential clamp, provided with three thumb pieces, is threaded upon the outside of the socket, and serves to clamp the ball tightly within this when the instrument is approximately level, as shown by a small circular spirit level fixed in the top of the ball. A shank attached beneath the top plate of the ball marks its centre, and has a loop of cord attached for centring the instrument over the station point.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-561.

Maker/Donor: Presented by the Ordnance Survey.
Object entry information: The main angles of the Prinicipal Triangulation of Great Britain and Ireland were mostly measured with this altazimuth theodolite, or with a very similar one now in the possession of the Royal Society. The latter was made by Ramsden in 1787 and the one here exhibited about 1790; both were in constant use between 1792 and 1862, and several sights were taken with them during the Principal Triangulation at distances exceeding 100 miles. The theodolite here exhibited has a 3-ft. horizontal circle, divided to 10' and read to 1" by three micrometer microscopes. The circle is mounted upon ten conical radii, which project from the outer conical vertical axis; this revolves upon an inner fixed axis to which the reading microscopes and levelling foot screws are fixed. A flat horizontal bar rigidly mounted across the top of the outer axis supports the telescope axis. Two 10·5-in. vertical circles, divided to 30', and read to 3" by single microscopes mounted on the telescope axis and supporting bar are made accurately horizontal by means of two spirit levels, one 24 in. and the other 21 in. long. (18814) The telescope objective has a clear aperture of 2·5 in. and a focal length of 36 in. The erecting eyepiece generally employed magnifies 54 diam., but other eyepieces were used in special cases. The telescope diaphragm has fixed cross wires and a horizontal travelling wire controlled by a micrometer screw, and could be illuminated through the horizontal axis of rotation for night readings. Clamps and tangent screws for fine adjustment are fitted to the horizontal and vertical circles. The probable error of a single observation with this instrument was about 2″ for distances up to 70 miles. The mechanism of the microscope is illustrated in the accompanying diagram. (See No. 218.) (See " Phil. Trans. Roy. Soc.," Vol. LXXX, 1790, p. 111. "Account of the Principal Triangulation," "Ordnance Survey, 1858.")

Maker/Donor: Constructed in the Museum.
Object entry information: The method of reading a graduated scale by means of a micrometer microscope having at its focal plane a movable cross wire, was first applied to theodolites by Ramsden in the construction of his 3-ft. instruments. The diagram shows the details of his later microscopes, which were added to the original two of his theodolites, and which differ very slightly from those. The microscope has a single objective lens fixed in a tube, which is mounted in the supporting bracket and can be slightly adjusted towards or from the graduated circle of the theodolite. The base of the micrometer box is screwed to the top of this tube and has a smaller one screwed into its top; the latter carries a slide-focussing eyepiece of the usual Ramsden type. The micrometer box contains two adjustable stages having their inner surfaces contiguous and their outer surfaces touching the walls of the box. The lower edge of the aperture of the upper stage has divisions notched in it at intervals of a hundredth of an inch, every fifth notch larger than the rest. The interval between the larger scale divisions is the same as that between adjacent divisions on the graduated circle when the latter interval is magnified by the microscope objective. Thus the interval between consecutive notches is 1′ of arc on the circle. The lower stage has a cross hair attached to its inner face, and can be moved as a whole across the notched scale by rotating the micrometer head; this head is threaded on to a screwed pin fixed to one end of the stage, and is pressed against the micrometer box by a counter helical spring inside the box. The pin has 100 threads per inch, so that the cross hair moves over one division of the notched scale at each revolution of the micrometer head. The periphery of the drum on this head is divided into 60 parts, and its rotation read by the position of a knife edge fixed to the box. Thus a rotation of the drum through one division of its periphery causes the cross hair to travel through 1″ of arc on the circle. The stage carrying the notched scale can be adjusted in the box by means of a screw and counter V-spring acting on its ends until the cross hair lies over a notch when the micrometer drum reads zero.

Catalogue number: 219.
Object name: 2-ft. TRANSIT THEODOLITE.
Maker/Donor: Made by Troughton and Simms. Presented by the Ordnance Survey.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: Plate V, Fig. 2, p. 83. This instrument was made at the commencement of the Irish survey and was first used in 1828 for checking the measurement of the Lough Foyle base by triangulation. It was further employed between 1829 and 1862 in measuring the main angles of the Principal Triangulation of Great Britain and Ireland. This theodolite differs from the adjacent 3-ft. one made by Ramsden in that its telescope can transit completely between the supporting pillars, and the horizontal circle is mounted upon a repeating stage so that both circle and microscopes can be independently rotated. The horizontal circle is 2 ft. in diam., and is divided on silver to 5′ and read by five microscopes to 1″. Two vertical circles of 12-in. diam. are fixed to the telescope; they are divided to 5′ and read by single microscopes to 2″. The telescope has a fixed objective of 27-in. focal length and 2·1-in. aperture, and a rack-focussing eyepiece tube carrying the diaphragm and erecting eyepiece. The diaphragm has one fixed horizontal wires, with five equidistant vertical wires moved laterally by a micrometer screw.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Maker/Donor: Made by Troughton and Simms. Presented by the Ordnance Survey.
Object entry information:
Plate V, Fig. 2, p. 83. This instrument was made at the commencement of the Irish survey and was first used in 1828 for checking the measurement of the Lough Foyle base by triangulation. It was further employed between 1829 and 1862 in measuring the main angles of the Principal Triangulation of Great Britain and Ireland. This theodolite differs from the adjacent 3-ft. one made by Ramsden in that its telescope can transit completely between the supporting pillars, and the horizontal circle is mounted upon a repeating stage so that both circle and microscopes can be independently rotated. The horizontal circle is 2 ft. in diam., and is divided on silver to 5′ and read by five microscopes to 1″. Two vertical circles of 12-in. diam. are fixed to the telescope; they are divided to 5′ and read by single microscopes to 2″. The telescope has a fixed objective of 27-in. focal length and 2·1-in. aperture, and a rack-focussing eyepiece tube carrying the diaphragm and erecting eyepiece. The diaphragm has one fixed horizontal wires, with five equidistant vertical wires moved laterally by a micrometer screw. The repeating stage rests by means of three footscrews upon an iron triangle fixed upon the head of the wooden tripod stand. It has an upper rotating tribrach supporting the horizontal circle and upper axis of the theodolite. The five microscopes reading this circle rotate with the telescope and upper part about this axis. Clamps and tangent screws are fitted to both circles and the repeating stage, and four spirit levels are provided for adjusting the telescope and horizontal axis of rotation.
(See "Account of the Measurement of the Lough Foyle Base," Ordnance Survey, 1847, p. 108.)

Catalogue number: 220.
Object name: 40-cm. TRANSIT THEODOLITE.
Maker/Donor: Made by Brunner Frères, Paris. Lent by the Physical Department, Ministry of Public Works, Egypt.
Date of creation: Ordered in 1858
Object entry information: This instrument was ordered in 1858 for use in a projected general survey of Egypt. It has horizontal and vertical circles, each 40-cm. diam., graduated direct on silver to 5', and each read by four micrometer microscopes direct to 2", by estimation to 0".
The vertical circle, together with a circle of equal dimensions as a counterpoise, is fixed directly to the horizontal axis of rotation of the telescope. This axis rests in bearings upon two standards which carry, opposite the two ends of the axis, fixed brackets for supporting the circle carrying the microscopes at one end and a counterpoise at the other. The axis of the telescope is pierced by a cylindrical hole for illuminating the interior, and a lamp can be attached to one of the brackets for this purpose. The standards project from a horizontal stage fixed to the alidade platform by adjustable screws, operated by a wormwheel and pinion mechanism. These serve to level the stage more precisely after the alidade has been approximately levelled by the three footscrews attached to the horizontal circle. A striding level fitted parallel to the axis of rotation of the telescope, together with a perpendicular level fixed to the microscope circle, is used for levelling. The alidade platform carries the four microscopes for reading the graduated horizontal scale, and can be rotated in azimuth, carrying the whole upper portion with it. The horizontal circle itself is fixed to the three footscrews, but its graduated circle can be independently rotated for "repeating" angles. In addition to the microscopes, there is an index arm with a reading lens for checking the major readings of each circle. Tangent clamps and slow-motion screws are fitted to both the vertical circle and the alidade.
The telescope has an objective of 2-2-in. aperture and 30-in. focal length, and an inverting draw-focussing Ramsden eyepiece, to which is fitted a micrometer stage having one horizontal and five vertical fixed threads, and one vertical thread movable by means of the micrometer screw.
The reading microscopes are fitted with metallic mirrors, and the vertical circle ones have prism reflectors in addition, for illuminating the field.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-479.

Object name: 12-in. EVEREST THEODOLITE.
Maker/Donor: Made by T. Cooke & Sons, Ltd. Lent by the Ordnance Survey.
Date of creation: The example shown was made in 1884.
Object entry information: Theodolites of this type were used by the Ordnance Survey in the Secondary Triangulation of the United Kingdom during the latter half of the 19th century. The example shown was made in 1884, and the probable error of a single observation made with it was about one second of arc.
The telescope is mounted on very low standards, so that it cannot be transited, whilst the vertical arcs only extend for some 40° on each side of the horizontal. The horizontal circle is mounted on a separate vertical axis for repeating azimuth angles. When this axis is clamped the verniers revolve with the standards; when unclamped, the circle, verniers and standards rotate together. The circle is of 12-in. diam., divided on silver to 5' and read by four symmetrical verniers to 5"; four small microscopes are mounted on a separate rotating bracket for reading these verniers. The circle is mounted in a tribrach stiffened by a circular ring, used for lifting the theodolite. The three levelling screws threaded in the tribrach arms rest in radial V-shaped grooves in a base plate. The latter rests in turn on a trivet stage having a massive curb and three footscrews; three horizontal radial screws threaded in this curb press on the central boss of the base plate and serve to adjust the theodolite axis over the station point.
The four horizontal verniers are rigidly fixed to the standards which are about 6 in. high and support the central telescope, vertical arcs, vertical verniers and counterpoise. The two vertical arcs are portions of a circle of 12-in. diam.,

Catalogue number: 220.
Object name: 40-cm. TRANSIT THEODOLITE.
Maker/Donor: Made by Brunner Frères, Paris. Lent by the Physical Department, Ministry of Public Works, Egypt.
Date of creation: Ordered in 1858
Object entry information: This instrument was ordered in 1858 for use in a projected general survey of Egypt. It has horizontal and vertical circles, each 40-cm. diam., graduated direct on silver to 5', and each read by four micrometer microscopes direct to 2", by estimation to 0".
The vertical circle, together with a circle of equal dimensions as a counterpoise, is fixed directly to the horizontal axis of rotation of the telescope. This axis rests in bearings upon two standards which carry, opposite the two ends of the axis, fixed brackets for supporting the circle carrying the microscopes at one end and a counterpoise at the other. The axis of the telescope is pierced by a cylindrical hole for illuminating the interior, and a lamp can be attached to one of the brackets for this purpose. The standards project from a horizontal stage fixed to the alidade platform by adjustable screws, operated by a wormwheel and pinion mechanism. These serve to level the stage more precisely after the alidade has been approximately levelled by the three footscrews attached to the horizontal circle. A striding level fitted parallel to the axis of rotation of the telescope, together with a perpendicular level fixed to the microscope circle, is used for levelling. The alidade platform carries the four microscopes for reading the graduated horizontal scale, and can be rotated in azimuth, carrying the whole upper portion with it. The horizontal circle itself is fixed to the three footscrews, but its graduated circle can be independently rotated for "repeating" angles. In addition to the microscopes, there is an index arm with a reading lens for checking the major readings of each circle. Tangent clamps and slow-motion screws are fitted to both the vertical circle and the alidade.
The telescope has an objective of 2-2-in. aperture and 30-in. focal length, and an inverting draw-focussing Ramsden eyepiece, to which is fitted a micrometer stage having one horizontal and five vertical fixed threads, and one vertical thread movable by means of the micrometer screw.
The reading microscopes are fitted with metallic mirrors, and the vertical circle ones have prism reflectors in addition, for illuminating the field.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-479.

Catalogue number: 222.
Object name: 12-in. TRANSIT THEODOLITE.
Maker/Donor: Made by E. R. Watts & Son. Lent by the Ordnance Survey.
Date of creation: 1910
Object entry information: This theodolite was constructed in 1910 for use on the Primary (First Order) Triangulation of the United Kingdom and has already been used to observe the angles of a piece of test triangulation in North-East Scotland in 1911-12, when 29 angles were observed with a mean error of 0.517" per angle.
It is a transit theodolite with a repeating horizontal circle of 12-in. diam., read by three micrometer microscopes to 1" and by estimation to 0.1". A separate pointer microscope serves to check the integral degrees of the reading. The circle is protected from dust by a cover plate provided with apertures for the tubular microscope reflectors which form dustproof connections to the microscopes. The outer vertical axis is rigidly connected to a strong tribrach with its arms with levelling footscrews and strengthened by a strong metal ring, covered with leather, which serves to lift the instrument. The footscrews rest in radial V-shaped notches on a lower tribrach plate which rests upon a strong circular baseplate having a massive curb. The lower tribrach has a central boss projecting through an aperture in the base plate; three radial screws threaded in the curb impinge on this boss and serve to move the whole instrument accurately over the station point. The vertical axis has a central socket in which can be inserted a nadir telescope for this centring operation.
The massive U-shaped standards for supporting the telescope axis of rotation are cast in one piece and attached to the cover plate of the horizontal circle, which also carries two mutually perpendicular spirit levels for setting the plate horizontal. The telescope axis is hollow and thus permits the diaphragm to be illuminated by an electric lamp supported on one standard, the light being reflected down the axis of sight by a central diagonal reflector inside the telescope. The latter has a fixed objective of 3-in. aperture and 24-in. focal length and a rack-focussing micrometer eyepiece tube in which various inverting eyepieces of powers 72, 50 and 30 diam. can be fitted. A 6-in. vertical circle, reading by two fixed verniers to 1' is attached to the telescope and rotates with it; the vernier bracket, which carries a sensitive spirit level parallel to the telescope axis, is clamped to one standard. A very sensitive striding level is mounted on the telescope axis pivots; its bubble moves about 0.1 in. per 1" difference of elevation.
For testing the cylindricity of the telescope axis, an arrangement designed by Sir David Gill is provided (see “Report of Geodetic Survey of South Africa,” 1896, p. 123). Its micrometer drum reads to 0.00001 in. All the circles are fitted with clamps and tangent screws for slow motion.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914-103. S.M. 1366, 1367 and 1368.

Object name: AIRY'S ZENITH SECTOR. Presented by the Ordnance Survey.
Maker/Donor: Sir George Airy (Designer); Ordnance Survey (Donor)
Object entry information: On the destruction by fire at the Tower of London of Ramsden's zenith sector, which had previously been used to determine latitudes in the Principal Triangulation of Great Britain and Ireland, this sector was designed by Sir George Airy and constructed under his direction. It was used between 1842 and 1850 for determining the latitudes of twenty-seven stations of the Principal Triangulation. The telescope is pivoted horizontally to a revolving gunmetal frame which is itself pivoted vertically in a fixed cast-iron framework. The latter is supported upon a rectangular plate which in turn rests upon a cast-iron trough; this trough was usually screwed upon heavy wooden pickets driven into the ground. Four micrometer microscopes attached to the telescope serve to read its inclination to the zenith upon two graduated arcs, mounted upon the revolving frame. Each arc extends over 45° of a circle of radius 20.5 in., and is divided to 5' and read by the microscopes to one-quarter of a second. The telescope has an objective of aperture 3.7 in. and 46 in. focal length, a micrometer diaphragm with five fixed and one movable wires, and an inverting eyepiece of magnification 70. Three sensitive spirit levels are fixed in adjustable bearings across the back of the revolving frame. In taking observations of a star's transit, the frame is quickly rotated to permit face east and face west readings of the telescope. The probable error of a single observation of latitude with this instrument was about 1". (See "Astronomical Observations made with Airy's Zenith Sector," Ordnance Survey, 1852.)

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 224
Object name: ZENITH SECTOR.
Maker/Donor: Troughton
Date of creation: Beginning of the 19th century
Object entry information: This portable sector was made at the beginning of the 19th century for use in America and was afterwards transferred to Copenhagen. The main telescope for observing stars near the zenith is pivoted horizontally near its objective end to the top of a vertical hollow brass cylinder, which carries at its lower end the fixed graduated sector over which the eyepiece of the telescope rotates. Two micrometer microscopes fixed to the telescope serve to read its inclination to the vertical upon separate scales engraved on the sector. The scales, each of which covers about 15° and is divided to 3', start at opposite ends of the sector and overlap about 5° in the centre. A third scale, continuous across the whole sector, is read by an index and serves as a check. The telescope has an objective of 2.5-in. aperture and 45-in. focal length. Its motion over the sector is controlled by a clamp and tangent screw. The base of the vertical cylinder is connected to a horizontal circle by six vertical pillars and can rotate with this circle about a vertical axis coincident with the cylinder axis. A long plummet suspended within the cylinder along its axis rests in a water vessel, inside the pillars, and serves to set the axis vertical. Its position is observed by two perpendicular microscopes fixed in the cylinder below the graduated sector. A small telescope pivoted to the cylinder is used to observe circumpolar stars for setting the sector in the meridian. The horizontal circle has a diameter of 9 in. and is divided to 10". The vertical axis revolves inside a conical socket fixed to the tribrach, which carries three verniers for reading the circle to 10". The three levelling foot screws of the tribrach rest on the top plate of a strong mahogany tripod. A small spirit level is mounted on the cylinder for rough levelling, and an adjustable counterpoise balances the telescope. (See Pearson's Astronomy, 1829, Vol. II, p. 546.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1891-24. S.M. 1943.

By means of this and a somewhat improved instrument of similar design and make, many latitudes were determined in India during the period 1884-1900; from 1890, however, a more convenient zenith telescope has been mostly employed in India for determining latitudes by Talcott's method.

description: Zenith sector telescope by Edward Troughton, London, 1800-1822.  Used in  America and later in Denmark

Maker/Donor: Lent by Prof. J. Norman Lockyer, C.B., F.R.S.
Date of creation: Designed by Lt.-Col. A. Strange and constructed by Troughton and Simms in 1869.
Object entry information: The zenith sector represented in these two photographs was designed by Lt.-Col. A. Strange and constructed by Troughton and Simms in 1869 for use in the Great Trigonometrical Survey of India. By means of this and a somewhat improved instrument of similar design and make, many latitudes were determined in India during the period 1884-1900; from 1890, however, a more convenient zenith telescope has been mostly employed in India for determining latitudes by Talcott's method. The instrument illustrated consists of a telescope of 4-in. aperture and 48-in. focal length, mounted rigidly upon a double sector which forms part of a graduated vertical circle of 3 ft. diam. The telescope can rotate upon a horizontal axis supported by a vertical metal pillar, and the vertical rotation is measured by means of four microscopes fixed to the frame carrying the axis. The instrument can be accurately adjusted upon its base frame so that the vertical sector revolves in the meridian plane, and its zero line is adjusted to be horizontal by means of a sensitive spirit level; the zero line is perpendicular to the telescope axis of sight, which therefore points to the zenith when the former is horizontal. The sector is graduated on silver every 5'; each limb extends over 55° and is read by two microscopes, separated 20" from each other, to single seconds; a separate smaller microscope serves to read degrees and minutes on the sector graduations. The telescope has a micrometer eyepiece fitted with a diagonal reflecting prism. A setting circle, of diameter 8 in., divided to 10' and read by vernier to 10", is mounted on the telescope near its eyepiece, and is provided with a small level and also a very sensitive one, which latter permits the instrument to be used as a zenith telescope for observations by Talcott's method. The probable error of latitude determination with this instrument was about 0·05". (See "Great Trigonometrical Survey of India," Vol. XI, 1890.)

Maker/Donor: Lent by T. Cooke & Sons, Ltd.
Date of creation: The original instrument was supplied to the Survey of India in 1909.
Object entry information: This photograph illustrates a 3-in. portable zenith telescope for determining latitudes by the Talcott method. The original instrument was supplied to the Survey of India in 1909, and is a typical example of the modern zenith instrument for geodetic work. The telescope, of 3-in. aperture and about 42-in. focal length, is mounted at one end of the horizontal axis by means of a centrepiece, which also carries the Talcott level frame. The latter has two chambered levels, running 0·1 in. to 2" of arc, enclosed in special sealed cases lined with thermal insulating material, and is provided with a long sensitive clamp and slow motion screw permitting an accurate adjustment in altitude. The horizontal axis has a weight relieving spring and ball race at the telescope end and a counterpoise at the other end; it is hollow to permit illumination of the telescope field by means of an oil or electric lamp. The telescope has a steel micrometer eyepiece, giving a value of about 30" to one revolution of the micrometer screw. A 7-in. setting circle, divided on silver to 30' and reading by vernier to 1', is mounted on the telescope near the eyepiece end. A 10 in. diam. horizontal circle, divided on silver to 30' and read by vernier to 1', is mounted on the tribrach base, which is provided with three levelling foot-screws. A clamp and slow motion screw controls the vertical axis motion, and two adjustable stops are provided to enable the telescope to be rapidly rotated in azimuth through 180°. A striding level is mounted above the horizontal axis of the instrument.

Catalogue number: 227.
Object name: PORTABLE TRANSIT.
Maker/Donor: Made by Brauer, Pulkowa Observatory. Lent by the Royal Observatory, Greenwich. Plate VI, Fig. 2, p. 86.
Date of creation: Used about 1850
Object entry information: A transit of this type was used about 1850 by F. G. Struve in his measurement of an arc of the 52nd parallel from Haverfordwest to Eastern Russia. The telescope has a 2·7 in. objective and is "broken" where it meets the hollow transit axis, a diagonal prism being here interposed to deflect the light into the eyepiece tube at one end of this axis. The diaphragm of the Ramsden eyepiece, which has a pair of movable wires actuated by a micrometer screw in addition to an adjustable reticule, is illuminated by a lamp mounted at the other end of the transit axis. A vertical circle of 11 in. diam., divided on silver to 10', is fixed to the transit axis near the eyepiece, and is read by an index on the adjacent standard. The steel pivots of the transit axis rest on high standards projecting from the levelling platform, which is supported on the wooden tripod stand by three levelling screws, having a point, line and plane contact respectively with the bearing plates. Two small bubble-levels are used to set the base horizontal by means of the foot-screws, and the transit axis is finally adjusted horizontal by a sensitive hanging level.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

title: Portable transit instrument by Brauer of Pulkowa Observatory
description: Portable transit instrument by Brauer of Pulkowa Observatory, c.1850.   With tripod.

Maker/Donor: Lent by T. Cooke & Sons, Ltd.
Object entry information: Transit instruments of the type here illustrated are sufficiently portable to be used for time and longitude observations in geodetic surveys. Transits very similar to the original of this photograph have been supplied to the Colonies in recent years. The telescope, of 3-in. aperture and about 30-in. focal length, has two setting circles of 6 in. diam., reading by verniers to 20", mounted near its eyepiece end, and is mounted upon a rigid horizontal axis fitted with a long clamp and slow-motion screw. The axis rests in bearings upon a massive U-shaped frame which permits the telescope to transit, and also carries a mechanism for lifting the telescope axis from its pivots and reversing it through 180° in azimuth. The supporting frame is adjustably mounted upon a base plate which can be fixed on a masonry pier. The diaphragm of the telescope is of glass and has seven lines; it is illuminated through the transit axis by means of an electric lamp at one end of the latter. A sensitive striding level is mounted above the axis. Levels, tangent and slow motion screws are fitted to both setting circles.

Catalogue number: 229.
Object name: EQUAL ALTITUDE INSTRUMENT.
Maker/Donor: Made by A. Jobin, Paris. Plate VII, Fig. 1, p. 90.
Date of creation: about the year 1900
Object entry information: This instrument, also known as a "Prismatic Astrolabe," was designed by MM. Claude and Driencourt about the year 1900, and is used for the astronomical determination of latitude, local time and azimuth. It acts on the principle of determining the exact moment at which a known star crosses a horizontal circle of constant angle, namely 60°. The instrument exhibited is the "geodetic" model of the firm, and has a telescope of aperture 40 mm. and magnification 75 diam. Latitudes can be determined with it to 0.4" and time to 0.04/sin $\lambda$ sec., where $\lambda$ is the co-latitude of the observing station. The telescope can rotate in azimuth upon one end of a horizontal plate, which carries a mercury artificial horizon at its other end and can itself rotate above the graduated horizontal circle of the instrument. This circle is divided in degrees, serving any particular star. An equilateral glass prism of sides and height 45 mm. is mounted in front of the objective lens of the telescope, with its base vertical and apex edge horizontal. When the star is nearly at an altitude of 60°, two images are seen of it in the telescope, one by light refracted through the prism and telescope, and the other by light reflected from the mercury horizon before refraction in the prism. At the precise moment that the star crosses the 60° horizontal circle, the two images meet on the same horizontal line of the telescope graticule. By a series of similar observations of the times of crossing of known stars, both latitude and local time can be ascertained from tables. (See "Handbook of the Prismatic Astrolabe," by J. Ball and H. Knox-Shaw, 1919.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1920-131. S.M. 1939 & 1940.

title: Prismatic astrolabe, French, 1895-1905
description: Prismatic astrolabe, including sighting telescope, base, main stand and accessories, including prisms, designed by Claude and Driencourt, made by Jobin, c. 1900. Objects in fitted wooden cases.

Maker/Donor: W. & S. Jones
Object entry information: Fig. 2, p. 90. Plate VII. In this instrument, made in the early part of the 19th century, the vertical semicircle is fixed to the alidade with its curved edge upwards, and the telescope rotates tangentially upon it. This arrangement permits nearly vertical sights to be taken and renders the instrument suitable for mine surveying. The vertical arc and telescope can easily be detached from the alidade for packing the instrument. The horizontal circle has a diameter of 4 in. and is graduated in degrees. The vertical arc has a diameter of 3 3/8 in. and is graduated in degrees on one side. On the other side is a scale of corresponding hypotenuse increments. Both circles but have no slow-motion fittings. The alidade also carries a compass box with a 2 in. ring, graduated in degrees. The telescope has a focal length of 5 in., a clear aperture of 0.5 in., and a simple inverting eyepiece with a cross-thread diaphragm. There is no focussing arrangement. A spirit level is mounted in adjustable bearings beneath the telescope. (See "Geometrical and Graphical Essays," by G. Adams, 1813, p. 231.)

Object entry information: lines, made of wire, may be used. A heavy plummet is attached to this line and allowed to swing freely; its oscillations may be damped by vanes moving in water. The position of the line is measured above ground by the theodolite in the normal manner and below ground by observing the oscillations and deducing the mean position, for which purpose the eyepiece of the telescope may be fitted with a special scale, or such a scale may be fixed beside the swinging plumb-line and observed through the telescope. Where it is necessary to fix a line, not merely a point, it is usual to employ a transit theodolite to sweep out this line. The ordinary mining theodolite can be adapted for this purpose by providing it with a supplementary telescope mounted above or at the side of the ordinary one, so that vertical sights can be taken. Another method often used is to set out the underground and surface lines by means of a delicate magnetic needle (see No. 237), but great care is necessary if the readings of the needle above and below ground are to be reliable.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 231.
Object name: MINER'S DIAL
Maker/Donor: Henry Barrow & Co.
Date of creation: mid-19th-century dial
Object entry information: The plain mine surveyor's dial is very similar to the old circumferentor and has been much employed in England owing to its adaptability to surveying in low galleries and suitability for traversing. The instrument exhibited is a mid-19th-century dial, with a 5-in. compass ring graduated in degrees and a vernier fixed to the movable alidade reading to 3'. The compass ring and base are mounted upon an axial socket perpendicular to their planes and can be rotated about the central axis which fits in this socket and terminates in a spherical ball. This latter is gripped by another socket and can be clamped in any desired position so that the plane of the compass faces any direction. A slit in the socket allows the compass to take up a vertical position for measuring altitude angles. When measuring azimuth angles, the plane of the compass is levelled by means of a pair of perpendicular tube spirit levels fixed to the alidade. This is attached to the compass case, and carries combined back-sights and foresights at each end. The alidade and compass case, with the internal vernier scale, can be rotated independently of the compass ring and angles measured as in a theodolite, or the case can be clamped to the compass ring and the two rotated together about the axis of the latter for taking magnetic bearings, as in the ordinary compass. In the former case, the alidade is fitted with a tangent screw for slow-motion adjustment. The sights are 6 in. high and fixed at a distance of 1 ft. apart on the alidade. Each sight has both a slit and a pin-hole backsight and a long single-wire and a cross-wire foresight. The aperture and cross-wire sights are for use in measuring altitude angles. For this purpose the compass needle is locked by operating the lifting lever, the plane of the compass is set vertical, and the lid is placed in position on the box, and a plumb-line suspended from a stud in this lid. The opposite edge of the lid is graduated in degrees up to 45° each way and has a scale of hypotenusal increments engraved on it.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1907–66.

Catalogue number: 230.
Object name: LEAN'S DIAL
Maker/Donor: W. & S. Jones
Date of creation: early part of the 19th century
Object entry information: Fig. 2, p. 90. Plate VII. In this instrument, made in the early part of the 19th century, the vertical semicircle is fixed to the alidade with its curved edge upwards, and the telescope rotates tangentially upon it. This arrangement permits nearly vertical sights to be taken and renders the instrument suitable for mine surveying. The vertical arc and telescope can easily be detached from the alidade for packing the instrument. The horizontal circle has a diameter of 4 in. and is graduated in degrees. The vertical arc has a diameter of 3 3/8 in. and is graduated in degrees on one side. On the other side is a scale of corresponding hypotenuse increments. Both circles but have no slow-motion fittings. The alidade also carries a compass box with a 2 in. ring, graduated in degrees. The telescope has a focal length of 5 in., a clear aperture of 0.5 in., and a simple inverting eyepiece with a cross-thread diaphragm. There is no focussing arrangement. A spirit level is mounted in adjustable bearings beneath the telescope. (See "Geometrical and Graphical Essays," by G. Adams, 1813, p. 231.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1908–120. S.M. 2197.

Continuation from previous page: FALSE
Catalogue number: 231.
Object name: MINER'S DIAL
Maker/Donor: Henry Barrow & Co.
Date of creation: mid-19th-century dial
Object entry information: The plain mine surveyor's dial is very similar to the old circumferentor and has been much employed in England owing to its adaptability to surveying in low galleries and suitability for traversing. The instrument exhibited is a mid-19th-century dial, with a 5-in. compass ring graduated in degrees and a vernier fixed to the movable alidade reading to 3'. The compass ring and base are mounted upon an axial socket perpendicular to their planes and can be rotated about the central axis which fits in this socket and terminates in a spherical ball. This latter is gripped by another socket and can be clamped in any desired position so that the plane of the compass faces any direction. A slit in the socket allows the compass to take up a vertical position for measuring altitude angles. When measuring azimuth angles, the plane of the compass is levelled by means of a pair of perpendicular tube spirit levels fixed to the alidade. This is attached to the compass case, and carries combined back-sights and foresights at each end. The alidade and compass case, with the internal vernier scale, can be rotated independently of the compass ring and angles measured as in a theodolite, or the case can be clamped to the compass ring and the two rotated together about the axis of the latter for taking magnetic bearings, as in the ordinary compass. In the former case, the alidade is fitted with a tangent screw for slow-motion adjustment. The sights are 6 in. high and fixed at a distance of 1 ft. apart on the alidade. Each sight has both a slit and a pin-hole backsight and a long single-wire and a cross-wire foresight. The aperture and cross-wire sights are for use in measuring altitude angles. For this purpose the compass needle is locked by operating the lifting lever, the plane of the compass is set vertical, and the lid is placed in position on the box, and a plumb-line suspended from a stud in this lid. The opposite edge of the lid is graduated in degrees up to 45° each way and has a scale of hypotenusal increments engraved on it.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1907–66.

This arrangement permits a fairly steep vertical angle to be measured, the angle being read by an index revolving with the rocking circle over a graduated semicircle fixed to the compass box. Catalogue number: 232
Object name: HEDLEY DIAL.
Maker/Donor: Made by B. J. Hall & Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The chief feature of this mining dial, which is a modern example of the type invented by John Hedley in 1830, is the use of a rocking circle, pivoted externally to the compass box, to carry either plain sights or a telescope. This arrangement permits a fairly steep vertical angle to be measured, the angle being read by an index revolving with the rocking circle over a graduated semicircle fixed to the compass box. The compass ring can rotate inside the box about the vertical axis, for measuring azimuth angles independently of the needle, or can be clamped to the box for taking magnetic bearings.
The compass ring has an outside diameter of 5 in. graduated in degrees for reading with the vernier, which is fixed to the box above one pivot of the rocking circle. The graduations extend to the inner edge of the ring, which has a diameter of 4 $\frac{1}{2}$ in. and is read by the needle. The base of the compass is also graduated every 10° and the cardinal points are marked on it. It also carries two spirit levels with their axes mutually perpendicular.
The vertical semicircle has a diameter of 5 in. and is graduated in degrees, with an inner scale of hypotenusal increments. The rocking circle has projecting lugs at right angles to its axis of rotation. The plain sights or standards for the telescope can be fixed to these lugs. The plain sights are 6 in. high and have both slits and wires for taking azimuth angles either way. In addition, one sight has a pin-hole aperture and the other a pair of cross wires for measuring vertical angles.
The telescope has a rack-focussing objective, of focal length 9 $\frac{1}{2}$ in. and aperture 1 in., a simple cross-wire diaphragm, and a slide-focussing inverting eyepiece. It carries a sensitive spirit level fixed to it by adjustable bearings. The compass ring, which has a tangent clamp and slow-motion screw, reads by vernier to 3ʹ. The compass box and upper part can rotate about a vertical axis and can be fixed by a tangent clamp. The socket is threaded to fit a pair of parallel plates for levelling.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1922-43.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 233
Object name: MINING THEODOLITE.
Maker/Donor: Made by F. W. Breithaupt & Son, Cassel.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: Theodolites with eccentrically mounted telescopes and vertical circles, which can be transited without requiring high standards projecting from the horizontal vernier plate, have been very generally employed by Continental mine surveyors owing to their suitability for work in low galleries. The example exhibited is of this type, the transit axis being mounted just above the vernier plate and carrying a telescope and vertical circle at one end, just clear of the horizontal circle.
Both circles are of 3 in. diam., graduated every 30ʹ and read to 1ʹ by opposing verniers. A 3-in. compass, mounted upon a large circular spirit level, is fixed to the upper part above the transit axis.
The horizontal circle and vernier plate have independent vertical axes of rotation for repeating azimuth angles, with separate clamps and tangent screws.
The axial socket of the circle carries a tribrach fitted with levelling footscrews, as is commonly the case in German instruments of this period—the latter half of the 19th century. The foot-plates rested on the tripod head, which was connected to the instrument by a central plunger screw. On loosening this, the theodolite could be accurately centred without moving the tripod.
A stout tubular supporting piece projects centrally above the vernier plate and carries the socket for the transit axis, and the ring for the compass and spirit level. The vertical circle is fixed to the transit axis socket and the telescope to an inner rotating vernier plate, which also carries a tangent clamp and slow-motion screw fitting. A spirit level is mounted on the telescope, parallel to the line of sight. The telescope has a fixed objective of $\frac{7}{8}$-in. aperture and a rack-focussing eyepiece tube carrying a fixed Huygens ocular, with a pair of cross wires fixed between the two lenses. A diagonal reflecting prism is screwed to the eyepiece for convenience in sighting. The compass ring is graduated in half-degrees, and a lifting lever is provided for clamping the needle against the cover, the glass cover of the circular spirit level forms the base of the compass box.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1896-1197.

Object entry information: parts from the dust and dirt inseparable from mine surveying, and the provision of means for taking sights at very short ranges and at extreme vertical angles.
The 4·5-in. horizontal and 4-in. vertical circles are graduated directly to 20′ and read by two opposing verniers and reading microscopes to 30″. Both circles are encased in metal, the verniers being protected by hinged glass covers, which can be raised for cleaning. The circles and the horizontal vernier plate have independent motions, and are provided with clamping and slow-motion screws, the two screws to each circle being distinguished by differently shaped heads. All the verniers have ground glass reflectors.
The main telescope, of 6·5-in. focal length and 1·1-in. aperture, transits at either end, and has an internal focussing lens actuated by a screw at one end of the transit axis. This arrangement permits the telescope tube to be rendered dustproof, and to be focussed down to 5 ft. An objective focussing auxiliary telescope, of 5-in. focal length and 0·9-in. aperture, can be fitted either on top or at the side of the main telescope, for use in taking steep sights, and is balanced by a counterpoise. Both telescopes and reading microscopes have screw-focussing inverting eyepieces. An additional diagonal erecting eyepiece is provided for use with either telescope. The diaphragm of the main telescope is of the web type, with 1 : 100 horizontal stadia lines, and can be readily withdrawn an interchangeable glass diaphragm is also supplied.
The standards supporting the vertical circle and telescope axis are fixed to the vernier plate, which carries a small circular spirit level and a long adjustable tubular one, with its axis parallel to the transit axis. A similar tubular level is mounted upon the telescope, and can be adjusted parallel to its optical axis.
The horizontal circle is attached to a tribrach, in the arms of which three foot-screws are provided with dustproof covers, and their feet are firmly fixed in a trivet stage, which can be screwed to the tripod head but has also three pointed feet for fixing it upon a platform independently of the tripod. The tripod head has a centring arrangement of 2½-in. range, permitting the instrument to be centred over the station point without moving the tripod legs.
A delicate compass of special design is attached to one standard and serves to give a magnetic zero line.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1921-558.

Catalogue number: 235.
Object name: BRUNTON MINING TRANSIT.
Maker/Donor: Made and lent by C. F. Casella & Co., Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This so-called transit is essentially a combined compass and clinometer designed for filling in the minor details of a survey, more particularly in mine surveying, as the sights can be adjusted to steep slopes without displacing the compass box from the horizontal. The position of the compass needle and the bubble of the clinometer can be read at the same time as the sight is taken by means of the mirror mounted inside the hinged lid of the compass box.
The instrument consists of a circular aluminium compass box, to which are attached on opposite sides a hinged lid and a hinged slit and aperture backsight. The inner face of the lid is a mirror and has a diametral line engraved upon it, which bisects an aperture pierced in the lid near the hinge ; this aperture serves as foresight for viewing any object, though the reflection of the slit of the backsight in the mirror, together with the line engraved thereon, serve to determine the exact bisection of the object viewed. In taking sights, the lid is inclined at an angle of 45° to the face of the compass, so that a reflected image of the compass ring and clinometer is seen.
The compass has a stepped ring, about 2½-in. diam., with its edge graduated in degrees. An edge-bar needle is pivoted at the centre and can be lifted from the pivot by means of a lever, actuated by pressing a button. The act of closing the lid of the compass depresses this button and clamps the needle. The clinometer arrangement is pivoted to the base of the compass below the needle and consists of a rotatable vernier arm upon which is mounted a small bubble level. The arm traverses a graduated arc engraved on the base of the box, and the vernier reads this arc to 10′. The movement of the arc is operated from outside the box by means of a small rotating arm having a milled button at its extremity. Two flats are filed upon the side of the compass box, which is rested on either of these when vertical angles are being measured by means of the clinometer.
The aperture plate of the backsight bracket is separately hinged to this, so that, when the bracket is adjusted to the angle convenient for taking a sight, the aperture plate can remain vertical.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1924-465.

Maker/Donor: Messrs. Cooke, Troughton & Simms, Ltd.
Object entry information: The requirements of minor and routine mine surveying, particularly in collieries, can often be met by a dial of this type, which has recently been designed by the makers to replace their Rand Model Mining Theodolite (see No. 234) where particular accuracy is not a necessity. A special feature of the dial exhibited is the sighting arrangement which is claimed to afford the advantages of open sights without the focussing difficulties of the latter. The compass box, mounted upon the tripod head by means of a ball and socket levelling arrangement, is designed for loose or fixed needle reading. It has a 5-in. horizontal circle, graduated in degrees, numbered 0-360° clockwise and read by opposing verniers to 1', and a needle circle also graduated in degrees, numbered 0-360° in the anti-clockwise sense. The readings of the two circles thus correspond and may be checked by comparison. The horizontal circle is provided with a clamp and slow-motion screw, whilst the compass box as a whole can be clamped to the base. The needle is 4·25 in. long and is mounted freely upon a steel pivot; it is provided with a lifting and clamping arrangement, designed to prevent shocks. Upon the rim of the compass box is pivoted a solid arm, carrying at its outer end the vertical circle with the sighting tube fixed thereto. The circle can rotate upon a horizontal axis in the arm, to which a vernier bracket is attached for reading the circle to 6'. The circle is of 3-in. diam., and is protected by a metal guard. The sighting tube is provided with a simple optical system of unit magnification, whereby the image of the target is brought into the same plane as the reference mark, which is a point or cross wires engraved on a glass diaphragm. The line of sight is above the centre of the compass box, and the supporting arm can be adjusted to enable vertical sights to be taken. (See "The Colliery Guardian," July 27th, 1923.)

Catalogue number: 237
Object name: MINE MAGNETOMETER
Maker/Donor: Messrs. Cooke, Troughton & Simms, Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: Many mining surveys, being based upon magnetic bearings, require an accurate determination of the magnetic meridian to serve as a periodical check and to connect them with the surface survey. The ordinary magnetic needle is not sufficiently sensitive to respond to the daily changes in the magnetic meridian, and the instrument exhibited was designed by Mr. T. Lindsay Galloway to enable the meridian to be fixed with the required accuracy. The instrument consists of a tribrach levelling stage, supporting a long cylindrical case within which is suspended an arrangement consisting of a plane mirror and a pendant connected by a fibre of unspun silk. Both mirror and pendant are mounted upon stems to which the ends of the fibre are fixed, and a small bar magnet is attached across the back of the mirror. Either the pendant stem or the mirror stem, or both together, can be clamped to the case by means of adjustable stirrup clamps, and the case can be inverted upon the tribrach levelling stage so that either the pendant or the mirror is uppermost. In using the instrument the case is first set up with the mirror above and the pendant below, and the latter is then unclamped and allowed to turn freely until it comes to rest, when it is clamped up again. By this means any twist is taken out of the fibre. The case is next inverted so that the mirror is below the pendant, whereupon it oscillates between two stops. If necessary, the case is rotated in azimuth to enable the mirror to come to rest with its plane in the magnetic meridian. If now a theodolite is directed on the mirror and adjusted until it centres the reflected image of a plummet suspended below its own axis, the line of sight will be perpendicular to the meridian. This type of magnetometer is now obsolete. (See "A Method of Determining the Magnetic Meridian," by T. Lindsay Galloway, Trans. Institute of Mining Surveyors, Vol. LVI, Part 4.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1925-8.

By this means any twist is taken out of the fibre. The case is next inverted so that the mirror is below the pendant, whereupon it oscillates between two stops. If necessary, the case is rotated in azimuth to enable the mirror to come to rest with its plane in the magnetic meridian. If now a theodolite is directed on the mirror and adjusted until it centres the reflected image of a plummet suspended below its own axis, the line of sight will be perpendicular to the meridian. This type of magnetometer is now obsolete. (See "A Method of Determining the Magnetic Meridian," by T. Lindsay Galloway, Trans. Institute of Mining Surveyors, Vol. LVI, Part 4.)

Catalogue number: 236
Object name: MINER'S DIAL
Maker/Donor: Messrs. Cooke, Troughton & Simms, Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The requirements of minor and routine mine surveying, particularly in collieries, can often be met by a dial of this type, which has recently been designed by the makers to replace their Rand Model Mining Theodolite (see No. 234) where particular accuracy is not a necessity. A special feature of the dial exhibited is the sighting arrangement which is claimed to afford the advantages of open sights without the focussing difficulties of the latter. The compass box, mounted upon the tripod head by means of a ball and socket levelling arrangement, is designed for loose or fixed needle reading. It has a 5-in. horizontal circle, graduated in degrees, numbered 0-360° clockwise and read by opposing verniers to 1', and a needle circle also graduated in degrees, numbered 0-360° in the anti-clockwise sense. The readings of the two circles thus correspond and may be checked by comparison. The horizontal circle is provided with a clamp and slow-motion screw, whilst the compass box as a whole can be clamped to the base. The needle is 4·25 in. long and is mounted freely upon a steel pivot; it is provided with a lifting and clamping arrangement, designed to prevent shocks. Upon the rim of the compass box is pivoted a solid arm, carrying at its outer end the vertical circle with the sighting tube fixed thereto. The circle can rotate upon a horizontal axis in the arm, to which a vernier bracket is attached for reading the circle to 6'. The circle is of 3-in. diam., and is protected by a metal guard. The sighting tube is provided with a simple optical system of unit magnification, whereby the image of the target is brought into the same plane as the reference mark, which is a point or cross wires engraved on a glass diaphragm. The line of sight is above the centre of the compass box, and the supporting arm can be adjusted to enable vertical sights to be taken. (See "The Colliery Guardian," July 27th, 1923.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1925-3.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 237
Object name: MINE MAGNETOMETER
Maker/Donor: Messrs. Cooke, Troughton & Simms, Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: Many mining surveys, being based upon magnetic bearings, require an accurate determination of the magnetic meridian to serve as a periodical check and to connect them with the surface survey. The ordinary magnetic needle is not sufficiently sensitive to respond to the daily changes in the magnetic meridian, and the instrument exhibited was designed by Mr. T. Lindsay Galloway to enable the meridian to be fixed with the required accuracy. The instrument consists of a tribrach levelling stage, supporting a long cylindrical case within which is suspended an arrangement consisting of a plane mirror and a pendant connected by a fibre of unspun silk. Both mirror and pendant are mounted upon stems to which the ends of the fibre are fixed, and a small bar magnet is attached across the back of the mirror. Either the pendant stem or the mirror stem, or both together, can be clamped to the case by means of adjustable stirrup clamps, and the case can be inverted upon the tribrach levelling stage so that either the pendant or the mirror is uppermost. In using the instrument the case is first set up with the mirror above and the pendant below, and the latter is then unclamped and allowed to turn freely until it comes to rest, when it is clamped up again. By this means any twist is taken out of the fibre. The case is next inverted so that the mirror is below the pendant, whereupon it oscillates between two stops. If necessary, the case is rotated in azimuth to enable the mirror to come to rest with its plane in the magnetic meridian. If now a theodolite is directed on the mirror and adjusted until it centres the reflected image of a plummet suspended below its own axis, the line of sight will be perpendicular to the meridian. This type of magnetometer is now obsolete. (See "A Method of Determining the Magnetic Meridian," by T. Lindsay Galloway, Trans. Institute of Mining Surveyors, Vol. LVI, Part 4.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1925-8.

Maker/Donor: F. Newton & Co.
Object entry information: This is a sextant of the usual type employed in marine surveying. It has a graduated arc of 8-in. radius, divided on silver to 10' and read by vernier and magnifier to 10". The arc extends from 0° to 150°, each numbered degree being really only half a degree. The vernier moves with the index arm, which is pivoted at the centre of the arc and carries the index mirror. A long telescope is mounted in the usual up and down piece on one outer radius of the arc and faces the horizon mirror, mounted on the other outer radius. Coloured glasses are provided for astronomical sights, and a handgrip is mounted on the under side of the frame.
