Object entry information: This sextant is believed to have belonged to the German surveying ship "Moewe." It is of the usual construction and has an arc of radius 20 cm., divided to 30' and read by vernier to 1'. The index arm, carrying the index mirror at its centre and the vernier at its extremity, is provided with a clamp and tangent screw for slow motion. A handgrip fixed beneath the frame is used when taking vertical angles, and has a screw socket beneath it for attaching a perpendicular handgrip used for taking horizontal angles. The telescope has two erecting eyepieces, of magnification 3 and 4 diam. respectively. A plain sight tube is also provided. The telescope supporting ring can be elevated or depressed by a fine screw in the usual manner.

The substitution of the prism for the horizon mirror enables angles up to 180° to be taken and also gives a clearer image at extreme angles, whilst the use of a complete circle and an index arm fitted with two opposing verniers, minimizes errors due to inequalities of graduation or inaccuracy in centring the index mirror and arm. The circle has a diameter of 13 cm. and is graduated to 10', corresponding to 20' of the angle measured. This angle is read by the vernier to 20". Maker/Donor: Pistor & Martins, Berlin. Lent by the Admiralty.
Object entry information: This instrument, which was salved from a German warship sunk at Scapa, has a complete graduated circle instead of a sextant, and a totally reflecting right-angled prism instead of the usual horizon mirror; it is of the type first made by Pistor and Martins in 1845. The substitution of the prism for the horizon mirror enables angles up to 180° to be taken and also gives a clearer image at extreme angles, whilst the use of a complete circle and an index arm fitted with two opposing verniers, minimizes errors due to inequalities of graduation or inaccuracy in centring the index mirror and arm. The circle has a diameter of 13 cm. and is graduated to 10', corresponding to 20' of the angle measured. This angle is read by the vernier to 20". Only part of the graduations, namely, those under one vernier, are numbered and in these a gap is left where the telescope and head of the observer foul the line of sight of the index mirror. This latter has its plane inclined at about 20° to the zeros of the index arm to which it is attached. The horizon prism is mounted with its reflecting face parallel to the index mirror when the verniers are at zero. It is opposite the lower half of the telescope, which is mounted in the usual " up and down " piece, the upper half of the field being left free from direct vision. The index arm has the usual clamp and tangent screw at one extremity, and a wooden handgrip for holding the instrument is attached beneath the circle. A reading microscope is fixed to a rotating bracket for magnifying the scales, and a set of smoked glasses for varying the illumination of the telescope field is attached to a rotating pivot near the supporting ring.

title: Brass reflecting circle.
description: Reflecting circle made by Pistor and Martins, Berlin, Germany, about 1870. Black-lacquered brass disc with a bright brass limb, the handle is missing. Signed on the limb: Pistor & Martins Berlin. Marked on the limb: 806. Marked on the knob fixed of the magnifier's arm: KM. | 5. (for Kaiserliche Marine, see notes). Inlaid silver scale indicating from 350° to 0° to 130° and from 180° to 240°; the entire scale is divided every 20' (digits engraved in the brass limb). Two silver verniers to 20", zeros at the right, at either end of the index arm. The tangent screw (missing) and clamping screw (missing) are at the bottom of the index arm. Three half-glass shades (two red, one green); no horizon shades. Index- and horizon glass without adjustment. Magnifier on a hinged 100 mm swivelling arm, serving the entire scale. Threaded telescope bracket, perpendicular adjustment by rising-piece and milled knob. Sight tube (63 mm); second sight tube (63 mm, incomplete). A prismatic eyepiece; an adjusting pin (perhaps from another instrument). Telescope and other parts are missing. In a square fitted mahogany box.
material: paper (fibre product); mahogany (wood); brass (copper, zinc alloy); glass; platinum (metal); iron

Maker/Donor: Presented by the Admiralty.
Object entry information: The station keeper is an instrument enabling an observer to keep himself at a fixed distance from another object, e.g., an observer in a boat from his ship, by keeping constant the angle which a known length on the distant object subtends at his position. In this type of station keeper, of which three examples are exhibited, a small glass prism of very small apex angle is mounted in a holder. The observer holds this at arm's length and views the distant fixed length partly through the prism and partly directly. If the direct sight of one extremity of the known length coincides with the image of the other extremity after refraction through the prism, his distance from the object must be invariable. The actual distance will depend upon the fixed length and the apex angle of the prism.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 242.
Object name: STATION KEEPER (Wharton Type).
Maker/Donor: Presented by the Admiralty.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This type of station keeper is essentially similar in construction to a box sextant, having a graduated arc of 6-in. radius extending over 20°. By measuring on this arc the angle subtended at his position by a fixed length on the distant object, the observer can calculate his distance from that object, or, having calculated the necessary angle, can set it on the instrument and keep his distance constant. The instrument consists of a sector-shaped box having its wider end open and its narrower end closed, save for a pin-hole aperture for sighting. At the open end, within the box, is mounted a fixed " horizon" mirror, whilst a movable index mirror is pivoted near the closed end and geared to an external rotating index arm, which moves over a graduated arc on the upper face of the box. The gearing is done by rack and pinion gear, which causes the index arm to rotate through twice the angle through which the index mirror moves. The arc is graduated in half-degrees from 0° to 20° and the index arm carries a vernier reading to 5′. In using the instrument the observer sights one end of the distant base directly through the space below the horizon mirror, and the other end by double reflection at the two mirrors, and moves his position or the index arm until the two ends appear coincident.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911–173.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 243.
Object name: STATION POINTER.
Maker/Donor: Made by H. Haecke. Lent by the Admiralty.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The arms of a station pointer are often fitted with sights which permit the instrument to act as a theodolite and thus to measure the angles subtended by three known points at the observing station. On detaching the arm piece from the circle and applying it to the chart like an ordinary station pointer, the position of the observing station can be plotted. The instrument exhibited is of this combination type, and was salved from a German warship sunk at Scapa Flow. It has a graduated circle of 11-in. diam., with its edge divided on German silver to single degrees. This circular plate can rotate within a hollow central axis which terminates below in a spherical ball; this ball forms part of a ball and socket joint connecting the instrument to a stand. The plate can thus be set in any plane and clamped by means of a threaded collar acting on the joint; it can then be rotated in this plane and clamped by a radial screw threaded in its outer axis and impinging on its inner one. The arms of the instrument are mounted on a separate circular ring which has a central pin fitting within a hole in the centre of the plate. Each arm is pivoted round this pin and can be turned

The plate can thus be set in any plane and clamped by means of a threaded collar acting on the joint; it can then be rotated in this plane and clamped by a radial screw threaded in its outer axis and impinging on its inner one. The arms of the instrument are mounted on a separate circular ring which has a central pin fitting within a hole in the centre of the plate. Each arm is pivoted round this pin and can be turned about it and clamped to the edge of the circular ring when the arm is directed towards the corresponding fixed point. The central pin acts as backsight for the observation, whilst each arm has a folding slit foresight fixed at its outer end. The subtended angles can then be read off on the graduated circle if required and the arm piece removed and applied to the chart. The bevelled edges of the arms are then made to pass through the corresponding fixed points on the chart, when the central pin marks the position of the observing point. This pin is mounted loosely in the arm piece and its point kept slightly above the plane of the arms by a spring. On depressing the head of the pin, its point makes an indentation in the chart and thus plots the position of the observing station. The arms are 14 in. long from central pin to sights, but can be extended to 20 in. by means of the three extension pieces shown. Two of the bevelled edges can be brought to coincide, but the third cannot be set less than 14° from the other two.

Catalogue number: 241.
Object name: STATION KEEPERS (Bell Type).
Maker/Donor: Presented by the Admiralty.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The station keeper is an instrument enabling an observer to keep himself at a fixed distance from another object, e.g., an observer in a boat from his ship, by keeping constant the angle which a known length on the distant object subtends at his position. In this type of station keeper, of which three examples are exhibited, a small glass prism of very small apex angle is mounted in a holder. The observer holds this at arm's length and views the distant fixed length partly through the prism and partly directly. If the direct sight of one extremity of the known length coincides with the image of the other extremity after refraction through the prism, his distance from the object must be invariable. The actual distance will depend upon the fixed length and the apex angle of the prism.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911–172.

Continuation from previous page: [FALSE]
Catalogue number: 242.
Object name: STATION KEEPER (Wharton Type).
Maker/Donor: Presented by the Admiralty.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: This type of station keeper is essentially similar in construction to a box sextant, having a graduated arc of 6-in. radius extending over 20°. By measuring on this arc the angle subtended at his position by a fixed length on the distant object, the observer can calculate his distance from that object, or, having calculated the necessary angle, can set it on the instrument and keep his distance constant. The instrument consists of a sector-shaped box having its wider end open and its narrower end closed, save for a pin-hole aperture for sighting. At the open end, within the box, is mounted a fixed " horizon" mirror, whilst a movable index mirror is pivoted near the closed end and geared to an external rotating index arm, which moves over a graduated arc on the upper face of the box. The gearing is done by rack and pinion gear, which causes the index arm to rotate through twice the angle through which the index mirror moves. The arc is graduated in half-degrees from 0° to 20° and the index arm carries a vernier reading to 5′. In using the instrument the observer sights one end of the distant base directly through the space below the horizon mirror, and the other end by double reflection at the two mirrors, and moves his position or the index arm until the two ends appear coincident.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1911–173.

Object entry information: The arms of a station pointer are often fitted with sights which permit the instrument to act as a theodolite and thus to measure the angles subtended by three known points at the observing station. On detaching the arm piece from the circle and applying it to the chart like an ordinary station pointer, the position of the observing station can be plotted. The instrument exhibited is of this combination type, and was salved from a German warship sunk at Scapa Flow. It has a graduated circle of 11-in. diam., with its edge divided on German silver to single degrees. This circular plate can rotate within a hollow central axis which terminates below in a spherical ball; this ball forms part of a ball and socket joint connecting the instrument to a stand. The plate can thus be set in any plane and clamped by means of a threaded collar acting on the joint; it can then be rotated in this plane and clamped by a radial screw threaded in its outer axis and impinging on its inner one. The arms of the instrument are mounted on a separate circular ring which has a central pin fitting within a hole in the centre of the plate. Each arm is pivoted round this pin and can be turned

Maker/Donor: Presented by C. F. Casella & Co., Ltd.
Object entry information: This modified form of sextant was designed by T. Nordenfelt about 1884 for rangefinding at sea. Observations are taken with the plane of the sextant vertical from a point on board ship at a known height above sea level upon the water line of a distant object and simultaneously upon the horizon. When the horizon and water line images are made to coincide by revolving the index arm, the reading of the index on the graduated arc gives the range of the distant object directly. The index mirror is not mounted upon the pivot of the rotating arm, but upon an eccentric pivot, connected to the arm by a cam and pin mechanism, which causes the mirror to rotate through a much smaller angle than the arm; this enables the angle swept out by the reflected ray to be varied very gradually between narrow limits, whilst the index traverses an arc of 60° or thereabouts. As the angle of depression of the distant object below the horizon varies inversely as the range, if the base—i.e. the height of the observer above sea level—is constant, the arc of the sextant can be graduated to read the range directly. Different arcs are, however, necessary for different observing heights, and three are provided, two for heights of 96 ft. and the third for a height of 47 ft. ; any arc can be fixed in the sextant frame by means of clamping pins. The effect of the dip of the horizon is allowed for on the graduated arcs. The rotating arm is provided with one fixed index mark and another index which can be displaced relative to the fixed one by means of a tangent screw; the arm has a separate clamp and tangent screw. Two telescopes, of different fields and magnifications, are provided. (See British Patent Specification No. 16029 of 1884.)

title: Rangefinder type sextant.
description: Naval rangefinder designed by Thorsten Nordenfelt in 1884, probably made by C.F. Casella and Company, London. Not signed, no marks. Anodized oval-pattern frame and anodized limb, wooden handle. Three exchangeable alloy scales, one is for an elevation of the eye of 96 feet, from 250-14,000 yards; one of for an elevation of the eye of 96 feet, from 250-20,000 yards; one if for an elevation of the eye of 47 feet, from 200-14,000 yards. No vernier, but two indicating lines; one is moved by a tangent screw, the other is rigid with the index arm. The tangent screw and clamping screw are on the back of the index arm. Index-glass adjustment by lever; adjustment of the horizon glass by screws. No magnifier. Threaded telescope bracket in two parts, fitted for correcting collimation error; perpendicular adjustment by rising-piece and a milled collar. Telescope (190 mm, large objective), erect image; telescope (124 mm, large objective, ocular missing), erect image. No box. This instrument was patented by Thorsten Nordenfelt, no. 16,029 of 1884 (copy in the object file). The instrument is held vertically (like a sextant) to meassure the angle between the horizon and the waterline of a floating body; the distance to the floating body in yards is then read from the scale.
maker: C F Casella & Company; Nordenfeldt, Thorsten Wilhelm

Object entry information: This instrument was designed for photographic surveying by Prof. E. J. Mills, F.R.S., about the year 1897. It consists of an accurately adjustable camera of nearly constant focus, fixed to the vernier plate of a 6 in. theodolite which gives the azimuth angle of the optical axis of the camera to 30", and is provided with an ordinary parallel plate four levelling screw mounting for attachment to the tripod. The photographic plates are 5 in. by 4 in. The camera box, which is made of teak, has a pair of perpendicular spirit levels and a 2-in. compass box attached to its top. The front consists of a brass plate mounted in horizontal and vertical slides, and adjusted in both directions by means of fine screws. It carries a centrally mounted Zeiss extreme angle (about 130°) anastigmat lens of 141-mm. focal length. The vertical and horizontal position of the lens is measurable by scales and verniers to 0.04 mm. The back of the camera can slide in the box and is moved by a twin rack and pinion arrangement, actuated by thumb wheels at each side. The focal length of the camera for any position of the back is read by a scale and vernier to 0.04 mm. The ground glass is graduated in centimetre squares, the central vertical and horizontal lines having millimetre graduations. Four triangular brass teeth are fixed in the centres of the edges of the back, and press against the front face of the plate during exposure. Their images on the plate after exposure serve to determine the horizon line and principal vertical line of the picture. The slides, twelve in number, are "single," and must be changed after each exposure. The base of the camera box has guides and screw threads for fixing it to the vernier plate of the theodolite, so that the principal point of the lens is vertically above the centre of the horizontal circle. This latter is graduated in half-degrees and read by opposing verniers to 30". Clamps and tangent screws for fine motion are fitted to both vernier plate and horizontal circle. The instrument is levelled by means of the spirit level on top of the camera box, and the four footscrews.

Pollack for engineering surveys in mountainous districts of Austria, the camera is centrally mounted above the horizontal circle and carries the telescope and vertical circle on one side, these being counterbalanced by a weight carried on the other side. Object name: PHOTO-THEODOLITE. Made by R. Lechner, Vienna. Lent by the Survey of Egypt.
Maker/Donor: R. Lechner, Vienna. Lent by the Survey of Egypt.
Object entry information: In this photo-theodolite, which is of the type designed by V. Pollack for engineering surveys in mountainous districts of Austria, the camera is centrally mounted above the horizontal circle and carries the telescope and vertical circle on one side, these being counterbalanced by a weight carried on the other side. To reduce the weight, the camera box, telescope tube and support for the latter are made of aluminium. The camera objective is a Zeiss anastigmat lens f/18 of focal length 21.2 cm., mounted in a movable plate which can be elevated or depressed to the extent of 5 cm. by means of a rack and pinion arrangement; the amount of elevation or depression is measured by a vernier and scale at the side of the plate. At the back of the camera box is a rectangular brass frame, 21 cm. by 15 cm., the inner edges of which are notched every centimetre. The photographic plate is pressed against this frame and the graduations are photographed round its edges; these serve to locate the principal and horizon lines on the picture and to discover any subsequent distortion due to development. The ground glass screen which normally fits in the back of the camera has a telescopic eyepiece mounted at its centre; this eyepiece, which is pivoted on a horizontal axis, forms a central telescope with the camera lens as objective.

Catalogue number: 247.
Object name: PHOTOGRAPHS OF A ZEISS-PULFRICH PHOTO-THEODOLITE.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Carl Zeiss, Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: Two views are here shown of a photo-theodolite designed by Dr. C. Pulfrich specially for use in stereo-photographic surveys. Above the camera is mounted a telescope which can sweep out a field of view perpendicular to the camera axis, so that, when the other station point of the base is sighted, the optical axis of the camera must be perpendicular to the base.
The camera box is of light metal and is mounted upon the rotatable limb of a graduated horizontal circle, which can in turn rotate within a levelling tribrach. The footscrews of the latter rest on a trivet plate, which can be clamped upon the tripod head after the vertical axis of the instrument has been centred above the station point. The camera objective is mounted in a sliding front plate and has a constant focal length of 127 mm. The plate rack takes 12 cm. by 9 cm. plates, upon which the horizon and principal vertical lines are automatically recorded during exposure.
The camera box can be detached from the tribrach by unclamping the screw which fixes the vertical axis of rotation. A similar tribrach, trivet plate and tripod is set up at the other base observing point and the camera can readily be transferred from one station to the other. In the tribrach which does not contain the camera, a signal pin can be clamped, centred above the station point, and observed from the camera station through the special telescope mounted above the camera box. This telescope has its optical axis parallel to the camera axis, but has a pentagonal prism mounted in front of its objective for deflecting the axial rays at right angles to the optical axis. The telescope fits within a sleeve rigidly fixed to the camera box, and can rotate within this sleeve about an axis coinciding with its optical axis. During this rotation it carries the deflecting prism with it, and also a vertical circle for measuring the amount of rotation. Any point viewed through the prism and telescope during this rotation must lie in the vertical plane perpendicular to the telescope axis, and therefore perpendicular to the optical axis of the camera.
To measure the length of the base, the telescope is sighted upon a horizontal rod of fixed length, which is mounted upon the tripod at the other base point, and the instrument rotated in azimuth by means of the tangent screw of the horizontal limb, which has a graduated screw-head for measuring the rotation necessary to traverse from one end of the distant rod to the other. By this means the base is measured tacheometrically.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–456, S.M. 910.

Catalogue number: 248.
Object name: PHOTOGRAPH OF ZEISS-PULFRICH’S STEREO-COMPARATOR.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Carl Zeiss, Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The stereo-comparator is a special type of stereoscope, designed by Dr. C. Pulfrich about 1901, for measuring the relative displacement of corresponding points in the two views of an area surveyed from each end of a base, and deducing therefrom the position of the corresponding ground point with respect to the base. The position of each ground point is separately measured in terms of its azimuth, altitude and range (perpendicular to the base) from the left-hand base terminal point.
The comparator consists of a binocular telescope, very similar to a stereoscopic rangefinder, mounted above a traversing frame which carries the two negatives. Each eyepiece of the telescope carries in its focal plane a fixed index mark. When the negatives are viewed through the twin eyepieces, the observer sees a combined image of the index mark apparently suspended in space above the country surveyed, which is presented in bold relief. By operating the mechanism controlling the movements of the negative and telescope carriages the mark can be made to “touch” any point of the landscape, and the readings of the scales then give the position of that point.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Carl Zeiss, Ltd.
Object entry information: The stereo-comparator is a special type of stereoscope, designed by Dr. C. Pulfrich about 1901, for measuring the relative displacement of corresponding points in the two views of an area surveyed from each end of a base, and deducing therefrom the position of the corresponding ground point with respect to the base. The position of each ground point is separately measured in terms of its azimuth, altitude and range (perpendicular to the base) from the left-hand base terminal point. The two negatives can be traversed together in a lateral direction parallel to their horizon lines by means of a rack operated by the wheel shown on the left of the instrument and known as the "direction" wheel, or the right-hand plate can be moved alone in the same direction by means of the wheel on the right-hand side of the instrument. The latter is known as the "parallax" or "distance" wheel. Each movement is registered by scales and verniers, whilst the "distance" wheel has a micrometer drum head for recording the smaller movements. The telescope can also be moved across the negative carriage in a direction parallel to the principal vertical lines of the views by means of the "height" wheel, shown in front of the middle part of the instrument, and the amount of motion measured on the "height" scale. The instrument is originally adjusted so that the mark appears to be at an infinite distance from the observer, in a direction coinciding with that of the principal point of the negatives, i.e. perpendicular to the base of the survey. When the mark is made to coincide with any point of the landscape, the readings of the direction, distance and height scales give the azimuth, range and altitude of that point with respect to the left base point. All the scales read to 0·01 mm. The instrument is designed to take negatives of dimensions 12 cm. by 9 cm., such as are used in the photo-theodolite, by Zeiss, illustrated in an adjacent photograph. (See "La stéréoautogrammétrie," by P. Corbin in "Revue générale des Sciences," Vol. 25, 1914. p. 231.)

The camera box can be detached from the tribrach by unclamping the screw which fixes the vertical axis of rotation. A similar tribrach, trivet plate and tripod is set up at the other base observing point and the camera can readily be transferred from one station to the other. In the tribrach which does not contain the camera, a signal pin can be clamped, centred above the station point, and observed from the camera station through the special telescope mounted above the camera box. This telescope has its optical axis parallel to the camera axis, but has a pentagonal prism mounted in front of its objective for deflecting the axial rays at right angles to the optical axis. The telescope fits within a sleeve rigidly fixed to the camera box, and can rotate within this sleeve about an axis coinciding with its optical axis. During this rotation it carries the deflecting prism with it, and also a vertical circle for measuring the amount of rotation. Any point viewed through the prism and telescope during this rotation must lie in the vertical plane perpendicular to the telescope axis, and therefore perpendicular to the optical axis of the camera.
To measure the length of the base, the telescope is sighted upon a horizontal rod of fixed length, which is mounted upon the tripod at the other base point, and the instrument rotated in azimuth by means of the tangent screw of the horizontal limb, which has a graduated screw-head for measuring the rotation necessary to traverse from one end of the distant rod to the other. By this means the base is measured tacheometrically.
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914–456, S.M. 910.

Catalogue number: 248.
Object name: PHOTOGRAPH OF ZEISS-PULFRICH’S STEREO-COMPARATOR.
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Carl Zeiss, Ltd.
Date of creation: N/A
Object entry information: The stereo-comparator is a special type of stereoscope, designed by Dr. C. Pulfrich about 1901, for measuring the relative displacement of corresponding points in the two views of an area surveyed from each end of a base, and deducing therefrom the position of the corresponding ground point with respect to the base. The position of each ground point is separately measured in terms of its azimuth, altitude and range (perpendicular to the base) from the left-hand base terminal point.
The comparator consists of a binocular telescope, very similar to a stereoscopic rangefinder, mounted above a traversing frame which carries the two negatives. Each eyepiece of the telescope carries in its focal plane a fixed index mark. When the negatives are viewed through the twin eyepieces, the observer sees a combined image of the index mark apparently suspended in space above the country surveyed, which is presented in bold relief. By operating the mechanism controlling the movements of the negative and telescope carriages the mark can be made to “touch” any point of the landscape, and the readings of the scales then give the position of that point.
Object/Inventory number: N/A

Maker/Donor: Presented by W. Watson & Sons, Ltd.
Object entry information: Early in 1907, Lieut. F. V. Thompson, R.E., at the School of Military Engineer- ing designed the instrument illustrated in these two photographs for the purpose of automatically plotting the positions of points obtained by a stereo-photographic survey. The apparatus consists of a Pulfrich stereo-comparator, with a pair of plotting boards traversed by rulers connected to its measuring mechanism in such a manner that the co-ordinates of the point viewed in the comparator can be automatically plotted on the boards. In the Pulfrich comparator the three co-ordinates of any point surveyed, namely its direction, altitude and range, are measured by the motions of the main slide, the microscope bridge slide and the parallax slide respectively. The two plotting boards of the stereo-plotter, which may be called the plan and ele- vation boards respectively, are provided with one common "ordinate" ruler and separate "abscissa" rulers. The two latter are geared respectively to the main slide and microscope slide mechanism of the comparator, and are moved automatic- ally over their boards by the operation of setting the comparator on the view point. The ordinate ruler has to be set by hand at a distance from the plan equal to the "range" of the view point as recorded on the range drum of the comparator, which drum is operated by the mechanism of setting the parallax slide. After this setting of the ordinate ruler, its point of intersection with the abscissa ruler of the plan board gives the plan point of the view point, whilst its intersection with the abscissa ruler of the elevation board gives a reading upon a scale fixed to the ordinate ruler which registers the elevation of the view point above the camera station. (See "Geographical Journal," Vol. XXXI, 1908, pp. 534–551.)

Object entry information: The two negatives can be traversed together in a lateral direction parallel to their horizon lines by means of a rack operated by the wheel shown on the left of the instrument and known as the "direction" wheel, or the right-hand plate can be moved alone in the same direction by means of the wheel on the right-hand side of the instrument. The latter is known as the "parallax" or "distance" wheel. Each movement is registered by scales and verniers, whilst the "distance" wheel has a micrometer drum head for recording the smaller movements. The telescope can also be moved across the negative carriage in a direction parallel to the principal vertical lines of the views by means of the "height" wheel, shown in front of the middle part of the instrument, and the amount of motion measured on the "height" scale. The instrument is originally adjusted so that the mark appears to be at an infinite distance from the observer, in a direction coinciding with that of the principal point of the negatives, i.e. perpendicular to the base of the survey. When the mark is made to coincide with any point of the landscape, the readings of the direction, distance and height scales give the azimuth, range and altitude of that point with respect to the left base point. All the scales read to 0·01 mm. The instrument is designed to take negatives of dimensions 12 cm. by 9 cm., such as are used in the photo-theodolite, by Zeiss, illustrated in an adjacent photograph. (See "La stéréoautogrammétrie," by P. Corbin in "Revue générale des Sciences," Vol. 25, 1914. p. 231.)
Object/Inventory number: Inv. 1914-456. S.M. 909.

Catalogue number: 250.
Object name: PHOTOGRAPH OF ZEISS—VON OREL'S STEREO-AUTOGRAPH (1911 Model).
Maker/Donor: Lent by Messrs. Carl Zeiss, Ltd.
Date of creation: 1911 (Model)
Object entry information: In 1908, Lieut. E. von Orel, of the Military Geographical Institute, designed the first model of his stereo-autograph, by means of which the points of a stereo- photographic survey could be viewed in a Pulfrich stereo-comparator and auto- matically plotted, one by one, by the movements used to set the comparator. In this early model, which resembled Thompson's stereo-plotter, the altitudes of the various points had to be separately calculated, but in 1909 Messrs. Zeiss, in conjunction with von Orel, constructed a new model in which the contours could also be automatically plotted upon the plan. In 1911 the instrument represented in the photograph exhibited was evolved. It performs all the functions of the 1909 model and in addition permits the trace of any line upon the photographs, i.e., upon the ground surveyed, to be plotted directly upon the plan ; thus contours, lines of rivers, roads, fences, etc., can all be automatically plotted by simply causing the index mark of the comparator to traverse such lines. Moreover,
